PROCTEXT.PARA: The PRESIDENT (Senator the Hon. Douglas McClelland) took the chair at 2 p.m., and read prayers.

TALK.START.PARA: —Petitions have been lodged for presentation as follows:

PETITION.TITLE: Provision of Aids for Disabled People Program
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled.

Your petitioners urgently request the Honourable Senator Grimes, Minister of Community Services, to include Communication Aids on the equipment list funded through the `Provision of Aids for Disabled People's programme.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Chernobyl Nuclear Disaster
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President, and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:

1. That following the Chernobyl nuclear disaster of 26th April 1986, the Soviet Union has not yet adequately explained to its citizens or those of the Soviet-occupied Baltic States, Ukraine and other areas affected by the radiation fall-out the potential short-term and long-term health hazards and the available modes of prevention or reduction of radiation poisoning. Neither have the appropriate medicines for substitution therapies to minimise bodily accumulation of radioactive elements been adequately provided.

2. That the Soviet Union operates many nuclear power stations without the elementary structural safeguards against radioactive spillage regarded as mandatory in the West. Of particular concern is the safety of the largest Soviet nuclear power station at Ignalina in Soviet occupied Lithuania, of similar design to Chernobyl, which already has a record of operational problems. Radioactive spillage at Ignalina would quickly contaminate the whole of Latvia, Lithuania as well as vast areas of Europe.
We request that the Australian Government will,
1. Through the World Health Organisation, provide medical aid and broadcast medical information to the victims of radiation exposure following the Chernobyl disaster.
2. Through the United Nations Organisation request the Soviet Union,
(a) to close down all nuclear power stations similar to Chernobyl till protective structures are built.
(b) permit international inspection of such safety structures.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Chernobyl Nuclear Disaster
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President, and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled:
This petition of concern to Australian citizens asks that:
1. The Australian government exert pressure on Moscow to-
a. Allow the International Atomic Energy Commission full expert investigation of the Chernobyl nuclear disaster and its human consequences;
b. Allow Australian Ukrainians to send medical aid to family and friends in Soviet Ukraine; and,
c. Allow free communication between Australian and Soviet Ukrainians.
2. The Australian Government-
a. Launch a public appeal to help the Chernobyl victims;
b. Support the removal of Russian nuclear weapons out of Ukraine;
c. Support the decolonization of the USSR so that captive nations like Ukraine and the Baltic states are not exploited for Soviet Russian nuclear purposes.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray:

PETITION.TITLE: Medicare Legislation
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President, and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled: The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth that-

There is a threat to medicine by an alliance between some greedy doctors, private health funds and private hospitals who, since the inception of Medicare have run a campaign to destroy Medicare. People, especially pensioners, are suffering.
We call on the Government to investigate why our taxes are being spent to prop up private hospitals.
To carry out an overhaul of the Medicare legislation to close the loopholes to prevent this exploitation.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Bill of Rights Legislation
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled. The petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth that:
Whereas the Australian Bill of Rights Bill 1985:
(i) does not include many of the rights which are fundamental to Australian society such as the right to own property and the right not to join a trade union.

(ii) by virtue of the extremely wide powers which it will give to the Human Rights and Equal Opportunities Commission, will take away many of our traditional rights such as the right to legal representation, the right to be confronted by one's accuser and the right to be heard in public; and
(iii) will therefore change many of the basic aspects of Australian life without people being given the opportunity to decide the Bill's fate at a referendum.
Your petitioners therefore pray that the Senate will reject the Bill of Rights in its present or any future form.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Superannuation Schemes
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in the Parliament assembled. The petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia showeth:
That many Australian wage and salary earners and self-employed persons do not enjoy secure retirement incomes provided by superannuation; and

That the Government issued in December 1985 Guidelines for the implementation of the proposed productivity decision by the Conciliation and Arbitration Comission and draft Operational Standards for Superannuation schemes.
Your petitioners therefore humbly pray that the Government:
1. Guarantees to every employee the right and freedom to select the superannuation scheme of his/her choice.
2. Protects the individual exercising that freedom of choice from any coercion, influence or other pressure which may be applied by any employer, association or trade union.
3. Will recognise only those schemes which provide genuine superannuation and reject those schemes which do not provide for-
preservation of benefits to retirement
vesting of employer contributions
equal employer and employee Trusteeship control to ensure security of investments.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Pine Gap Defence Space Research Facility
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled:
The petition of the undersigned shows:

(1) The Agreement between the United States of America and Australia concerning the Joint Defence Space Research Facility at Pine Gap may be terminated by either Government on one year's notice from 19 October 1986.
(2) In the event of war between the United States and the Soviet Union, access by the United States to Pine Gap's facilities makes it a probable nuclear target.
(3) Access by all nations to Pine Gap's capacity to monitor and verify compliance with existing and future nuclear limitations treaties could contribute to world peace and security.
(4) The people of Australia are entitled to be consulted, through their representatives in Parliament, on any extension or modification of the Agreement affecting their lives, security and welfare.
And your petitioners humbly pray that:
(1) The Agreement between the United States and Australia concerning the Joint Defence Space Research Facility at Pine Gap be terminated one year from October 1986.

(2) Public discussion and inquiry be instituted into the feasibility of negotiating a new agreement with the United Nations during the International Year of Peace offering the verification facilities of the Pine Gap base to all nations.
(3) Any agreement concerning the future use of Pine Gap be referred to Parliament for ratification.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Plant Variety Rights
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled.

The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth that: Upon evidence from within Australia and overseas, the introduction of Plant Variety Rights legislation would not be in Australia's best interests because:
1. Plant genetic resources should remain a public resource;
2. Australia's public plant breeding programmes could be undermined;
3. Such legislation may lead to a reduction in the genetic diversity of commercial varieties;
4. There is reason to fear that choices of seed and other plant propagation materials may be restricted due to the controls placed on their use;
5. Plant Varietal Rights legislation could lead to higher costs for the grower, the consumer, the plant-breeder and the tax-payer;
6. Plant Variety Rights will lead to a further increase in foreign control of Australia's plant genetic resources.
Your petitioners therefore humbly pray that Parliament ensure that it recognises the widespread public opposition to PVR and promote alternative means of royalty collection for plant breeders.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Industry and Employment in Tasmania
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled.

We the undersigned citizens of Australia humbly pray that the Federal Government join with the Tasmanian Government and institute an independent review of the Callaghan Report into the Structure of Industry and the Employment Situation in Tasmania.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Aboriginal and Islander Languages
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled.
The petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth that whereas:
(a) Aboriginal and Islander languages, which numbered approximately 260 when Europeans first arrived, are even more seriously endangered-already 145 have become extinct.
(b) English-speaking population expansion and English-speaking mass media expansion threatens the survival of the remaining languages of Australia.

(c) Aboriginal languages reflect an ethos that is truly Australian and unless steps are taken to implement language maintenance, this ethos will be lost not only to Aborigines but to non-Aboriginal Australians, and to the world.
We humbly pray the Government to:

1. Through the Prime Minister's Department, provide $300,000 per annum for a guaranteed period of ten years to enable the Aboriginal community of Australia to establish a co-ordinating body to implement steps to prevent the extinction of the remaining languages, and to introduce programmes which will enable these languages to continue into the future for the sake of all Australians. This body will enable us to maximise existing financial, material and human resources, and is the least expensive way of implementing urgently needed maintenance programmes.
2. Through the Prime Minister's Department, provide finance for the establishment of Regional Language Centres-ten are urgently needed-cost $200,000 each.
And we pray you may be conscious of God's sovereign purposes for our Nation.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Taxation
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in the Parliament assembled. The petition of certain citizens of Victoria respectfully showeth:
that all legitimate business expenses incurred in earning or producing assessable income should be allowable deductions;
that the Hawke Government's Capital Gains Tax is an unwarranted burden on the small business and rural sectors, which will severely affect their long-term viability.
Your petitioners humbly pray that the Government withdraws the Capital Gains Tax legislation without delay.

PETITION.TITLE: Bill of Rights and Human Rights and Equal Opportunity Legislation
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled. The petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:
1. That the Bill of Rights will have the power to override and negate our Common Law within five years of its enactment.

2. Because the Bill of Rights is based on an Inter- national Covenant, this will take the control of our country out of the hands of the people and their democratically elected representatives, giving the power to those outside Australia.
Your petitioners therefore pray:
1. That the Senate rejects the Australian Bill of Rights and all cognate Bills.
2. That as our representatives, you protect our Australian Heritage and Christian culture and values, both in the Education System, and through the media.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.
PETITION.PRESENTER.BLOCK: by Senators Knowles (from 82 citizens) and Robertson (from 347 citizens).

PETITION.TITLE: Bill of Rights Legislation
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled.
Your petition of the undersigned shows: That we urge you to oppose the Australian Bill of Rights Bill because:
We get no legally enforceable rights under the Bill

The Bill does not guarantee vital rights such as the right not to belong to a trade union, the right to own private property and not be deprived of it without just compensation and the right of choice between Government and non-Government schools.
The Bill gives Canberra extra powers to change our Federal system by the back door without a constitutional referendum.
The Bill gives dangerous new powers to a Federal Government Commission.
Your petitioners ask that the Senate, in Parliament assembled, should vote against the Bill of Rights, support Opposition amendments and seek a genuine public debate and a referendum on the Bill.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Foreign Military and Intelligence Facilities in Australia
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate assembled. The petition of the undersigned respectfully showeth that:

1. The Watsonia Army Barracks contains electronic communication facilities, operated by Australian and American personnel, that gives the United States the ability to pin-point Soviet nuclear submarines, hidden in the Oceans.

2. This would make it possible for U.S. killer-submarines to destroy all Soviet nuclear submarines, while the U.S. nuclear submarines launch their missiles in a ``first strike'' attack. This makes Watsonia a potential nuclear target. A nuclear attack on Watsonia would have a disastrous effect on Melbourne.
3. The ``joint U.S.-Australia'' bases in Australia endanger rather than protect us. They also add a new menace to nuclear arms race, that must be stopped.
Your petitioners most humbly pray that the Senate in Parliament assembled should close the ``joint Australian-U.S.'' electronic communication facilities in the Watsonia Army Barracks.
PETITION.PRESENTER.BLOCK: by Senators Cooney (from 234 citizens) and Zakharov (from 90 citizens).

PETITION.TITLE: Pornography
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled.
The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:
That we the undersigned, having great concern because of the spread of moral pollution in our nation call upon the Government to introduce immediate legislation:

1. To provide strict controls over importation, production, sale, hire or mailing of video-cassettes with the open sale of only G, PG, and M rated video-cassettes; and the total prohibition of the sale of R rated video-cassettes so that R rated films can only be viewed in an adult theatre by persons over 18 years. We totally reject the concept of ``X'' rated video-cassettes which would allow the legal sale of hard-core pornographic films for screening in the homes of our nation, which endanger our children.

2. To dramatically improve the Federal Attorney-General's Guidelines for Classification of Video tapes/discs which restrict the importation, production, sale or hire, screening in private homes and mailing by Australia Post so as to include the total prohibition of any pornographic, obscene or blasphemous video cassette, or film containing child pornography, bestiality, sodomy, group sex, violent sex acts with women, such as rape and pack rape, sadism and torture, etc.
Your petitioners therefore humbly pray that your Honourable House will protect our society, especially women and children from moral pollution and its harmful effects.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: English as a Second Language Program
PETITION.PARA: To the President and honourable members of the Senate of the Australian Parliament assembled. The petition of the undersigned residents of Australia respectfully showeth:
We the undersigned residents of Australia totally reject any move to cut funding to Australia-wide English as a Second Language program in schools.
We request that the Australian government restore funding to the 1985 level in the 1986-87 budget.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Schools: Fringe Benefits Tax
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled. The petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth that:

Whereas the fringe benefits tax will place a costly and unfair burden on independent schools, the fringe benefits tax will have the most damaging impact upon schools which provide boarding accommodation for children as they are also required to provide accommodation for staff members to live in and supervise the boarders. Independent schools have limited resources and this additional impost will ultimately have to be passed onto parents, many of whom are already heavily committed to the financing of their children's education.

Your petitioners therefore call the Parliament to recognize that the future of Australia depends upon the education given to its children and to exempt schools from the operation of the fringe benefits tax.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Pensioners' Pharmaceuticals
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled: The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth that-
There should be no introduction of payment for pensioners pharmaceuticals.
All pharmaceuticals for pensioners and the general public should be through Medicare.
There should be no substituting of cheaper drugs for those prescribed by the Doctor.
There should be full testing of all pharmaceuticals by the Australian Authorities before they are released on the market.
And that Australia should develop its own manufacturing industry in Pharmaceuticals and stop relying on all overseas multinational drug companies.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: South Pacific Nuclear Free Zone
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled.
The petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth that:
(1) France continues to test nuclear weapons at Mouroroa atoll contrary to the wishes of all the people of the South Pacific.
(2) Australia is a signatory to-(1) The Treaty on the Non-Proliferation of Nuclear weapons and the Antarctic Treaty.
(3) Australia is currently pressing for a comprehensive Nuclear Test Ban Treaty in the United Nations.
Your petitioners must humbly pray that the Senate in Parliament assembled should:
(1) Condemn and demand the cessation of French or any other Nations nuclear testing in the South Pacific or the use of such area for long range missile tests (e.g. the U.S.S.R. or U.S.A.)

(2) Declare Australia will join with New Zealand and other South Pacific countries in a treaty to make the South Pacific a Nuclear Free zone in line with that section of the world recognised Antarctic treaty which expressly forbids-The placing, stockpiling, testing or carriage of Nuclear weapons and the establishment of military bases.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Nursing Homes
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled-the petition of the undersigned show that patients in nursing homes are not being cared for with the dignity they deserve.
We call on the Government and Opposition to put a stop to this widespread abuse of the elderly in nursing homes throughout Australia.
That a freeze on the exorbitant nursing home fees in all States as already operating in two.

That the Government should own and operate care facilities for the aged, such as nursing homes and hostels, this guaranteeing a higher standard of care and at a cheaper cost to the taxpayer by not fulfilling the profit motive of private owners.
That strict legislative action should be adopted as a matter of urgency to restrict private ownership of nursing homes, hostels and private hospitals.

PETITION.TITLE: Pharmaceutical Benefit Scheme
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled-the petition of the undersigned shows:
We, the people, object to the elimination from the pensioner free list of certain medications previously on the Pharmaceutical Benefit Scheme.
Your petitioners ask that the Senate, in Parliament assembled, should review the situation and restore the free list to its original state.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Gold Tax
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and Members of the Senate in Parliament assembled-the petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth that:
(i) the welfare of many employees and their families depends upon a healthy, expanding gold mining industry;
(ii) the success of many small businesses in gold mining towns also depends upon the continued profitability of gold mining and prospecting operations;

(iii) the Federal Government's proposal to introduce a tax on gold mining and prospecting represents a threat to the profitability of these industries and will therefore cause widespread unemployment and depression throughout the whole gold mining industry.

Your petitioners therefore call upon the Federal Government to reject any proposal to introduce a tax on gold mining or prospecting thereby ensuring that the spectacular growth of the industry over recent years is continued.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Identification Cards
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled.
The petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully shows that whereas:
(1) Identification cards and numbers severely threaten our freedom to live unfettered by excessive bureaucratic surveillance;
(2) the Government has been unable to present any realistic justification for the introduction of ID cards and numbers;
We humbly pray that the Senate, in Parliament assembled should reject any proposal to inflict ID cards and numbers on the freedom loving people of Australia.

PETITION.TITLE: Fringe Benefits Tax
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled. The petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth that:
(i) the fringe benefits tax will place enormous cost increases on employers throughout Australia;
(ii) in so doing, the fringe benefits tax will raise the cost of employing labour particularly in remote locations and it will inevitably worsen the already high level of unemployment in Australia;
(iii) much of the cost of the tax will be carried by employees as employers reduce benefits; and
(iv) the cost of the tax will harm small business particularly as these businesses will be unable to pass on the cost of the tax and as a result many may be forced to close.
Your petitioners therefore call upon the Government to repeal this unfair tax before it damages Australian business and thereby reduces the standard of living of all Australians.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Notice of Intention to Withdraw Notice of Motion

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Giles Sen P.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —On behalf of Senator Cooney, and at his request, I give notice that it is my intention at the placing of business today to withdraw Business of the Senate, Notice of Motion No. 1 standing in the name of Senator Cooney for disallowance of the Export Control (Unprocessed Wood) Regulations. I seek leave to make a statement.

SPEECH.PARA: Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —When the Standing Committee on Regulations and Ordinances examined the Export Control (Unprocessed Wood) Regulations it was concerned that licence applicants who were refused licences should automatically be given an explanation for that refusal, to the extent that this was possible without prejudicing the secrecy of Cabinet's deliberations on wood export licences. The Committee was also concerned that if the relevant Minister's power to reconsider a decision was lawfully capable of being delegated to officials, no ministerial delegate should reconsider an initial administrative decision that he or she had taken.

SPEECH.PARA: The Minister for Primary Industry (Mr Kerin) has undertaken to amend the regulations to accommodate the Committee's concerns on these two matters. The Minister has also agreed that after 12 months he will review the regulations in consultation with the Committee to see whether these amendments are working adequately and determine whether any further adjustments are needed to protect rights. The Minister and his officials have been helpful to the Committee in its examination of the regulations. The Committee commends the Minister for his decision to act decisively today to meet the Committee's concerns that these important regulations should, as far as possible, protect the rights of licence applicants. Normally when the Committee has settled a matter it seeks leave to incorporate its correspondence in Hansard. In this case the correspondence is somewhat lengthy and I therefore seek leave to table it for the information of honourable senators.
Leave granted.

TALKER.NAME: Senator BUTTON
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the Government in the Senate)

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-I inform the Senate that the Minister for Foreign Affairs (Mr Hayden) left on 19 September for the United States, primarily to attend the United Nations General Assembly in New York. He will return on 8 October. In his absence, the Minister for Resources and Energy (Senator Gareth Evans) is the Acting Minister for Foreign Affairs until 25 September. From 25 September to 8 October the Deputy Prime Minister (Mr Lionel Bowen) will be the Acting Minister for Foreign Affairs.

—Does the Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce agree that left and right wing dissatisfaction with his industry policy was a significant factor in the Victorian branch of the Australian Labor Party's decision to dump him from first to third spot on the Senate ticket? In view of the fact that the preferred candidate is a leading union official who has been very critical of the Minister's approach to industry policy, does the Minister intend making any changes to that policy in response to ALP dissatisfaction?

—The causes of dissatisfaction with me or with any members of the Government cannot be susceptible to analysis by journalists or, indeed, Opposition politicians. These are internal party matters which are resolved in one way or another. They are not matters which go directly to my ministerial responsibility. The Government, since it came to office, has made a number of decisions regarding industry policy and it will continue to do so on the basis of judgments by the Government itself, not by any sections of the community, whether they are in the Labor Party or outside, who would seek to impose alternative views on the Government. I do not think that the assumption can necessarily be made that, although there has been some criticism by so-called left wing circles in Victoria of some aspects of Government policy, those criticisms in any way imply that those people would be anything but more dissatisfied with what emerges from the Opposition in this Parliament.

—My question is directed to the Minister for Resources and Energy. Is Australia an importer of the platinum group of metals from South Africa? In addition to gold, what is the potential for production of platinum group metals at Coronation Hill? What is the likely resource potential of the surrounding area based on known information? Will the exploration and development of these metals serve to reduce the dependence that Australia and other Western nations have on South Africa for these metals and therefore assist in bringing about more meaningful and effective sanctions against the South African regime?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I have already given some information on this to a Senate Estimates committee.
—Find out what Senator Zakharov has to say about that.

—I will bear that with as much fortitude as I can command. Australia imports some 70 per cent-that is 13,000 ounces in 1985-of its platinum group metal requirements from South Africa. Australian demand for platinum group metals will increase with the increasing use of catalytic converters for motor vehicles using unleaded petrol. As to the resource potential at Coronation Hill, according to Broken Hill Proprietary Co. Ltd, exploration at that site has demonstrated between 350,000 and 380,000 ounces of gold within an area of 18,000 square metres. This mineralisation is open with potential for one million ounces of gold, 170,000 ounces of palladium and 80,000 ounces of platinum. Regionally, the total potential, including Coronation Hill and five other prospects of which we are aware and on which we have some information, invites speculation of the following level of resources: 2,650,000 ounces of gold, 200,000 ounces of platinum, 410,000 ounces of palladium and 475,000 ounces of silver. The platinum group metals discovered at Coronation Hill appear to be in a new type of deposit and could well indicate that the region is a significant new platinum province.

ANSWER.PARA: It is evident from what I said at the outset about the total amount of our platinum imports at the moment that Coronation Hill has the potential to meet in excess of our current and future platinum and palladium requirements. However, I should add that production from Coronation Hill cannot be expected much before 1989. In the meantime, Australia's requirements will be met by imports. However, this project, if it goes ahead, will clearly give Australia a self-sufficiency and export capacity from the production of rare and strategically important platinum group metals. I emphasise that the Government's commitment, made last week, to allow the Coronation Hill project to proceed is subject to a very important proviso, that is, that it meets the necessary environmental and other relevant preconditions, including within those crucially the protection of the South Alligator catchment area from any pollution. The final point to make, and this follows also from what I said at the outset, is that the development of the mine, if it can pass those hurdles, will be a very important step in reducing Australia's reliance on South Africa for these metals.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is addressed to the Leader of the Government in the Senate. Does he agree with the Prime Minister's comment in the Weekend Australian that the way in which the Minister canvassed the possibility of further spending cuts was `not wise'? Has the Minister noted yesterday's criticism by the Committee for the Economic Development of Australia of the level of Government spending, and the condemnation by the National Australia Bank Ltd of the 1986-87 Budget, particularly the way in which spending cuts were achieved? Does the Minister still believe that there is a need for further spending cuts, as he clearly indicated in interviews two weeks ago?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Button Sen The Hon J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —I have not seen the reported interview with the Prime Minister in the Weekend Australian. If he said that my comment was not wise, that is right; I totally accept that. But what the Prime Minister was probably saying was that the comment was not wise in the sense that it was open to misinterpretation. Of course, the misinterpretation was seized upon very quickly by the shadow Treasurer, Mr Carlton, and by the Leader of the Opposition, Mr Howard. Those two people both seized on that statement made by me and were very quick to provide a misinterpretation of what I had said. I understand that the degree of desperation which possesses the Opposition parties sometimes leads them into that course of action, and I note that more in sorrow than in anger.
—This is all very insulting to the chief political correspondent of the Age.

—Senator Chaney says that I am insulting the political correspondent of the Age. I would not do that; I would not dare. But let me just say that anything the political correspondent of the Age wrote was not of the same order as the comments made by Mr Howard and the shadow Treasurer, Mr Carlton. In respect of the comments made at the weekend by the Committee for the Economic Development of Australia about the level of Government expenditure, they, of course, are not relevant to the recent Budget; they are relevant to the question of ongoing Government expenditure and the philosophical assumptions which underlie that. Those people who saw the early morning television this morning would have seen Mr Tim Besley, who was associated with the CEDA group and who prepared that study, saying quite categorically that in these matters the present Government was proceeding in the right direction.
—He said the Opposition was good, too, didn't he? He went on to say that.

—An even-handed afterthought, I thought, Senator; it was not the burden of what Mr Besley was saying, as I interpret it. The important point about this question of expenditure restraint is the fact that, as in everything else, the Government provides a sense of direction and leadership on these issues. I just note in passing that the assessor for Moody's Investor Services Inc., which assessed the Australian credit rating, made this comment in terms of that reassessment:

ANSWER.PARA: One of the positive features of the Australian scene is the intelligent guiding of the ship of state.

That may be a flamboyant analogy, I concede, but nonetheless, of course, true. It is in light of these matters that the CEDA comments have to be seen and that is the light in which they will be taken account of by the Government.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question without notice is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Transport and relates to the considerable publicity on the grounding of the TNT Alltrans on Lady Musgrave Reef in March last year and the subsequent finding of the court of marine inquiry that the consumption of alcohol was a contributing factor in the grounding. Will the Minister outline current steps being taken by the Government in relation to that finding and could he tell the Senate what the current maximum penalty is, under the relevant disciplinary code, for being under the influence of alcohol on board or in charge of a ship?

—The Senate may be aware that a marine inquiry is taking place into the circumstances surrounding the grounding of the TNT Alltrans on Lady Musgrave Reef, which happened on 25 March 1985. It is true that, to date, the conclusion that has been reached is that the consumption of alcohol was a factor in the grounding of that particular vessel. I am able to advise Senator Coleman that the Minister for Transport has set up a special committee of advice to report as a matter of urgency on the safety and other aspects arising out of the use of alcohol aboard ships. I think honourable senators will be aware, of course, that ships are at sea for considerable periods and therefore the use of alcohol is one of the means by which the crew members are able to find a certain relief and leisure. A consequence of that, of course, is that it is not conceivable that alcohol on ships should be banned. However, it is a disciplinary offence to be on duty under the influence of alcohol aboard ships-I think that goes without saying-and under the regulations is punishable by instant dismissal. It is covered in the new code of conduct being progressively introduced aboard ships. However, as this matter is still under consideration, I will draw the Minister's attention to the matter to see whether he has any further information and wishes to amplify the answer.

—I ask a question of the Leader of the Government in the Senate. I refer to the Minister's announcement of a part time Australian Space Board. Could the Minister advise what new funding and new projects are involved in the program beyond what has been funded in either current or past Budget allocations? Has the Government given the part time Australian Space Board the five-year funding commitment recommended by Sir Russell Madigan and without which he said the Government should not start at all?

—Funding for the Australian Space Board and for space programs was announced in the Budget. The total funding amount, which is $5.2m, is to fund three ongoing international programs in which various Australian scientists are involved. The commitment of that amount, together with an approximate amount of $6.5m being spent by the Commonwealth Scientific and Industrial Research Organisation, is the total amount of explicit funding for space related programs. Of course, there are a number of other government programs which assist in the development of space technology and which are of general application. It is quite apparent that the funding commitment in no way meets the suggested Madigan levels. The reason for that is the need for overall government fiscal restraint. The Madigan recommendations are discussed in the back of the Press release which the Minister for Science, Mr Barry Jones, and I put out on this matter.
—I ask a supplementary question. Do I take it that no new money and no new programs are involved and that the Madigan recommendations are not being met?

—The honourable senator can take what he likes. I have told him what money is being made available for financing these programs. I answered the second part of the question by saying yes, the Madigan recommendations in respect of funding are not being met.

—I direct a question to the Minister for Education. Is it a fact that Kormilda College is to be transferred from the Northern Territory Department of Education to the Presbyterian Church? If so, does the Minister believe that such a move is in the best interests of Aboriginal education? What implications will such a move have for funding arrangements between the two governments? Is the proposal in line with agreements reached regarding Aboriginal education in the memorandum of understanding?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Ryan Sen The Hon S.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —It appears that it is a fact that the Northern Territory Government intends to transfer Kormilda College to the Presbyterian Church. The Northern Territory Government took that decision unilaterally and I was somewhat surprised and concerned that it proceeded in this fashion without consulting the Commonwealth. Of course, technically speaking Kormilda is now Northern Territory property. It was originally a Commonwealth institution, established when Mr Beazley was Minister for Education. On the transfer to the Northern Territory it came under the administration of the Northern Territory Government.

ANSWER.PARA: The college was founded as a vocational education hostel for teenage Aboriginal children from remote communities. It has had a modified success. There has been some success; there have been many failures. So the Commonwealth was not opposed to changes in the way Kormilda was being run. However, in the first instance the Northern Territory Government decided to change the institution into a fee-paying body, which raised some questions about the Government's responsibility to pay the Aboriginal secondary allowance to the Aboriginal students. That matter was negotiated satisfactorily between the Northern Territory Government and the Commonwealth in that the allowances will be paid to the Aboriginal students so that they can now afford to board at Kormilda, but there will be a corresponding reduction in the States grants to the Northern Territory.

So far that arrangement seems satisfactory. However, the new decision to put the college outside Territory education administration and with the Presbyterian Church is one about which I would like to have further information before I could say that I was confident there would be no disadvantage to Aboriginal students. It may well be that the group is competent to run an institution such as this to accommodate Aboriginal students. It may be that it is not an appropriate group. I have sent Errol West, the chief adviser on Aboriginal education to the Commonwealth, to the Northern Territory to have discussions with Mr Manzie to see what will happen.

One of the other changes is that Kormilda will now accept non-Aboriginal students. That will dramatically change the character of the institution. Our concerns are that any changes should be in the interests particularly of the Aboriginal students, though of all students studying there. At this stage we are still finding out what the consequences will be for Aboriginal students. Our main concern is to preserve any educational benefit they may have had.

TALK.START.PARA: —I ask the Minister a supplementary question. I draw attention to the last section of my question, which I admit was fairly long. Is the proposal in line with agreements reached in the memorandum of understanding regarding Aboriginal education?
—It appears that at this stage it is not, but we need further information before I can come to that conclusion.

—I direct my question to the Minister representing the Minister for Health. Has the Minister seen reports of the appalling breach of security in the Department of Social Security in which confidential personal information held by the Department has been offered to debt collectors and credit agencies? Will the Minister confirm that the Federal Government, in its submission to the Joint Parliamentary Committee on the Australia Card, conceded that `it is recognised that no identification system can be 100 per cent secure'? In the light of this recent breach of the much greater potential for invasion of privacy with the Australia Card, can the Government justify the long-held view of the Minister for Health that the Health Insurance Commission has the capacity to develop and maintain a system of high security and integrity, particularly given the leaks that have been made earlier from that Department about New South Wales doctors' incomes? If so, can the Minister say how a repetition of such a serious lapse would be avoided in the future?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Grimes Sen The Hon D.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Government is very concerned about the report in the National Times on Sunday. It is true that a person has been charged with possessing a social security microfiche. He is not a departmental officer. At the moment the Minister for Social Security, Mr Howe, is seeking a full report on the matter. In the last five years I think three or four people have been charged with misusing social security microfiche and providing such information, but I am also well aware that in my time as Minister, and in more recent times in even more cases, officers of the Department of Social Security have reported attempts to bribe them to give information to debt collecting agencies and all sorts of operators in this community who would take action of this type to seek such information.

ANSWER.PARA: Senator Haines relates this to the Government's proposals for the Australia Card and how this recent breach will affect the proposals in future for the Australia Card. I point out that in the Department of Social Security in this case and in other cases that have been detected the problem has been the stealing of microfiche, which is notoriously difficult to keep secure. Despite the fact that microfiche has been used for so long in the Department of Social Security, very few breaches of security have been detected. In the case of the Australia Card, with the use of computers, with, I hope, the development of a data protection agency and with more sophisticated methods, in fact it will be much more difficult to breach that system than it has been to breach the social security system in the past. With the use of Stratplan and the modern computers in the Department of Social Security now, it will become increasingly difficult to breach the confidentiality there.

In developing the Australia Card the Health Insurance Commission will have to have a far more sophisticated system of both identification and security than it has at the moment. No one is arguing with that; the Government has always said that. I believe that such a system can and will be developed. It will certainly be far superior to any system that we have now. Confidentiality is always a problem in departments such as the Department of Social Security, but mechanisms for overcoming the difficulty are to provide a greater certainty of detection when such breaches occur and to provide adequate penalties. The penalty for any officer in the Department of Social Security who breaches confidentiality is now a fine of $5,000 or imprisonment for a period not exceeding two years, and it is an indictable offence. It is that sort of thing, plus the certainty of detection, which keeps the level of breaches down now. It is that plus modern security techniques which will keep breaches down, or eliminate breaches, in the case of the Australia Card.

TALK.START.PARA: —Has the attention of the Minister representing the Treasurer been drawn to an advertisement in the Australian this morning by the Australian Federation of Employers on the fringe benefits tax? Can the Minister say whether the claim is accurate that a $10 donation to the AFE campaign could save the average small business some $6,000 per annum if the fringe benefits tax legislation were repealed? Is the figure quoted of $6,000 per annum possibly one measure of the extent of tax avoidance which has been occurring in some quarters in the community? Does the Minister agree that the long overdue crackdown on tax avoidance through the fringe benefits tax is one key to the financing of the Government's income tax cuts which will apply to most Australians in December?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Walsh Sen The Hon P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the last part of the question is yes, as is the answer to the first part-I did see this advertisement. It has photographs of Mr Bob Ansett, who a couple of months ago was widely advocating that the law should be broken, and Mr Andrew Hay, who of course is noted as a former private secretary to Mr Lynch. I do not know whether in that capacity he organised the tax free gains that came from the corrupt Stumpy Gully land deal, but he probably would have known about it. The other photograph is of Mr McLachlan, and I will say something about Mr McLachlan in a while.

ANSWER.PARA: The claim that the average small business could save $6,000 is patently false, as I would expect a claim coming from those three gentlemen to be. If one were to take the number of small businesses in Australia to be 300,000, which is a fairly conservative estimate on the assessment most people would make, that would mean that the fringe benefits tax would yield $2 billion. If that were true, it would illustrate, as Senator Maguire's question suggested, that the incidence of tax avoidance-cum-evasion in this area is very much greater than the Government estimates it to be, because the Government estimates that it will be $325m in this year and $575m in a full year.

In respect of Mr McLachlan and the National Farmers Federation's high profile participation in an issue which has nothing to do with the interests of the great majority of people it claims to represent, I have this to say: The great majority of farmers will not be affected by the fringe benefits tax at all, but the response of the National Farmers Federation, when this issue first arose, was to join Mr Ansett and to advise its members to defy the law and not to pay the tax. As I said, the NFF ran a high profile media campaign against the tax. It published advertisements which were packed full of misinformation, and the NFF President, in his capacity as a member of the Australian Federation of Employers, continues to do that. The NFF advised its members to burn the Australian Taxation Office information booklet. More recently it complained about the lack of knowledge of fringe benefits tax administration, a lack of knowledge to which, of course, the National Farmers Federation's exhortation to its members to burn the information booklet would have contributed substantially. But even more alarming are the reports that the National Farmers Federation will endorse the Federal Opposition's flat tax proposal under which, according to the NFF's own estimates of farmers' incomes and the more reliable estimates which are put out by the Bureau of Agricultural Economics, the overwhelming majority of farmers would pay more tax than they do at present.

A flat tax might suit very well the interests of the National Farmers Federation President and his fellow IXL directors, but it would be difficult to devise a taxation change more punishing to the people he purports to represent. Indeed, we are in the extraordinary position where the National Farmers Federation President vehemently opposes the tax which few farmers will pay and simultaneously advocates a tax which will require the great majority of farmers to pay more. My advice to any farmer who thinks it might be worth contributing the $10 to the Federation of Employers' campaign to oppose the fringe benefits tax should ask himself whether it is he, or someone else such as Mr Hay, Mr Ansett or Mr McLachlan, who really stands to benefit.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Science. I ask: Does the Government accept that a sound patent system contributes as an integral part of industry policy and can positively contribute to economic growth and development? Have both the 1984 report of the Industrial Property Advisory Committee in Australia and the 1986 United Kingdom White Paper on Intellectual Property and Innovation strongly recommended expanded access, especially for small business, to patent databases? If so, can the Minister explain and justify the Government's recent decision to close the Technology Information Branch of the Patents, Trade Marks and Designs Office, a decision which will hamper the vital process of technology transfer and be a particularly savage blow to small businesses which will need access to current patent information.
—I will direct that question to the Minister for Science and obtain an answer as soon as I can.

QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: ENGLISH AS A SECOND LANGUAGE PROGRAM

TALK.START.PARA: —I refer the Minister for Education to an article which appeared in the Sydney Sunday Telegraph on 21 September 1986 and which reported that teachers and students who were upset about the English as a second language program intended to march on the electorate office of the Treasurer. In that article the New South Wales Teachers Federation multicultural co-ordinator was reported as having said that the Minister did not seem to have any conception of the importance of the ESL program or how outraged the ethnic community was. Can the Minister inform the Senate of the results of meetings held last week with members of the New South Wales and Victorian parliaments and the Federation of Ethnic Community Councils?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Ryan Sen The Hon S.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am able to report a satisfactory outcome to those very significant meetings. I am also able to report that there has been constant discussion between my office and the State Ministers' offices about a satisfactory resolution of the problems created by the cuts since the Budget was announced. So the suggestion by members of the New South Wales Teachers Federation that the Commonwealth is not informed about concerns in the community is absolutely wrong. As there have been members of several delegations to me and to my colleagues, they must know it to be wrong. I note too that they intend making some sort of demonstration outside Mr Keating's electorate office. I really think they would be better advised to have rational, sensible discussions with the New South Wales Government. The outcome of the discussions which the Prime Minister and I held with Premier Unsworth, Mr Debus, the Minister Assisting the Minister for Education in New South Wales, and Mr Cathie, the Minister for Education in Victoria, was that money was available unallocated--
—Tell them to demonstrate in front of Mr Keating's Sydney residence. They will not have to go so far.

—Senator Chaney has no interest in these matters at all. I have made it clear to the Senate before, but it was made very clear and understood by the Victorian and New South Wales governments, that money is available through the extra general recurrent program and can be allocated to the ESL area if the State governments give a high enough priority to it. Some $38m is available under this element of the Commonwealth's program, and the cut in question was $27m. Further, $4m has already been allocated to the ESL program. The top priority for submissions under the participation and equity program will be for projects serving the needs of children with non-English speaking backgrounds. Of course there is $24m available under that program.

ANSWER.PARA: It is clear to those honourable senators who have a genuine interest in this matter-I know that many, at least on this side of the chamber, do-that there is an adequate provision of resources that can be directed to the ESL area. Indeed it is the Commonwealth's wish, and it will be a requirement, that the allocation of extra recurrent money will take into account the ESL needs of children from non-English speaking backgrounds.

The outcome of that meeting and of the subsequent meeting with FECCA, the Federation of Ethnic Communities Councils of Australia, I think, was most satisfactory in making it clear to these bodies that the money is available and that it is really up to the State governments to allocate a sufficient priority to them so that it can be used for those purposes.

I would like to take this opportunity to lay to rest some of the very mischievous rumours in the ethnic communities about this matter. For example, there are rumours that the Commonwealth wishes to see the training of ESL teachers reduced to a derisively short period. That is quite wrong. The Commonwealth has expressed no view at all on the training of ESL teachers. Indeed, of course, the employment of ESL teachers, their in-service training and so forth, are very much matters for State governments. The Commonwealth has no direct or indirect role in the employment or in-service training of teachers in this area or any other area. I do not know why some people see it as in their interest to start running around with these silly rumours, but I am concerned about them because they cause genuine distress and anxiety among the ethnic communities.

It has been a long answer, I appreciate that, but the Commonwealth does take very seriously the need to find ways of giving adequate resources to this very important program. We have done so, and the ball is now in the court of the State governments. I am happy to report that I believe that all State governments will respond and accord a sufficiently high priority so that the level of services involved in ESL to children of non-English speaking backgrounds can be retained.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Brownhill Sen D.G.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister representing the Treasurer. In reply to Senator Parer on the last sitting day, the Minister indicated that for fringe benefits tax purposes log books for motor vehicles would need to include only private usage. I ask the Minister whether he is aware of taxation ruling No. MT2026 which states:

QUESTION.PARA: To establish this private use proportion, it is a requirement of the law that records evidencing the total kilometres travelled by the car during the relevant period be maintained. The total number of private kilometres is determined by deducting from that the kilometres travelled on business journeys, which are required to be evidenced by log book entries.
So that the confusion and uncertainty in the community can be cleared up, would the Minister clarify for the Senate who is correct-the Treasurer or the Commissioner of Taxation?

TALK.START.PARA: —As I recall it, when I was asked that question Senator Parer stated that the Treasurer had said this. In my reply I think I said I believed that to be so, that the Treasurer had said this, and that I understood it to be correct but I would seek a more definitive response from the Treasurer. I am sorry I do not have one yet; I will try to get one.
—I wish to ask a supplementary question: Who is correct-the Treasurer, who has been reported as saying that, or the Commissioner?

—Overlooking the implication that one or the other is incorrect-I do not accept that as being the case-Senator Brownhill will have to wait for the definitive answer that I said I will seek from the Treasurer.

—Has the attention of the Minister for Finance been drawn to a copy of a speech made by Mr Charles Copeman, Chief Executive of Peko-Wallsend Ltd and a leader of the New Right, to a Liberal Party lunch in Perth on 1 September 1986? In particular, has the Minister's attention been drawn to a proposal contained in this speech on a new form of structure and power sharing of government where the States would be given additional and enlarged powers? I ask the Minister: Firstly, what would be the economic and social consequences to the people of Australia if the Government adopted this proposal? Secondly, has a similar or like proposal ever been attempted before and, if so, when? Thirdly, who was the architect of this proposal and are the people of Australia still paying for these errors? Fourthly, has the Minister seen Press reports concerning the statement by the Leader of the Opposition that he supports the policies of the New Right?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Walsh Sen The Hon P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —I have seen reports of Mr Copeman's speech and, indeed, I think I have read it all the way through. If I may say so, I read it with some amazement. What really amazed me was that such a speech could have been delivered to a meeting sponsored by the Western Australian branch of the Liberal Party. According to Press reports, that speech was extraordinarily well received. As the question implies, Mr Copeman floated an idea that had once been floated but not proceeded with by a former Prime Minister, Mr Fraser, and I will say a little more about that later.

ANSWER.PARA: Two things were particularly notable in Mr Copeman's speech, in respect of his suggestions on government and the division of constitutional responsibility. The first was he said that the Commonwealth would have residual functions after most of its present functions had been devolved to the States and that the funding for those residual functions would be on a basis of a per capita levy at a rate agreed by the States. Just as a matter of political organisation, Mr Copeman's prescription was unworkable because having deprived the Commonwealth Parliament of the power to levy its own taxation for its own revenue, as he would if the States could not agree, there would be no way in which the per capita levy could be applied. More importantly, particularly in the Western Australian context, if such a policy were to be implemented, it would remove entirely the present financial equalisation policies which are carried out by the Commonwealth Government, normally on the basis of recommendations by the Grants Commission, policies which pay to the State of Western Australia, for example, $250 a head more from Commonwealth sources than the six-State average. In other words, Mr Copeman's policies, if actually implemented, would deprive Western Australia of some $375m in income.

I find it quite astounding that that proposition could have been enthusiastically received, if one is to believe the Press, by the Western Australian branch of the Liberal Party. So let it be noted, if that is the case, that the Western Australian branch of the Liberal Party is committed to policies which would deprive Western Australia of some $375m in income. As I indicated before, a similar proposal was floated in 1975 by the former Liberal Prime Minister, Mr Fraser. It was not implemented because in the end Mr Fraser was not an extremist. I note in the last part of Senator McKiernan's question reports that the present Leader of the Opposition supports this and other policies of the New Right. I believe that to be so not necessarily because Mr Howard actually believes in those policies but because he is a captive of the right wing extremists who are on the brink of taking over the Liberal Party and he does not have the strength to resist them. It does not surprise me that he endorses those policies but it would surprise me if he believed in them.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Walters Sen M.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question to the Minister for Education relates to an answer that she gave Senator Coleman during Budget week concerning cuts to the bicentennial program on Australian studies at the tertiary level. The Minister in her answer correctly said that the tertiary studies project had not been cut, but added:

QUESTION.PARA: . . . the Chairman of the Bicentennial Authority and I have agreed today that there will be an additional $1m for new work in the Australian studies area.

That is not accurate. Is it not a fact that no additional money has been allocated to any area since the board made its decision on where the cuts should be made? Is it accurate to say that the Chairman of the Australian Bicentennial Authority in that media release following the Budget said that there had been a $7m cut to programs involving special interest groups, including education, Aboriginal affairs, unions, women, youth, multicultural interests, the aged and people with disabilities? Is the $1m to which the Minister referred the money that the board decided to allocate more than three months ago, long before the Budget decision to make cuts in this area?

TALK.START.PARA: —I am not sure of the purpose of Senator Walters's extremely long-winded question. The outcome of a series of discussions between the Australian Bicentennial Authority and the Cabinet with regard to reductions in the program was that there were cuts in a number of areas, as Senator Walters has pointed out, but in the case of Australian studies the tertiary element was not cut and there will be an additional $1m-that is, $1m more than the amount allocated in the previous Budget. That $1m may, indeed, have been agreed earlier by the board and the Chairman but it would not have been proper to announce that allocation because all the bicentennial estimates were up for consideration by the Expenditure Review Committee. Until the Budget was finalised, the question whether a program was or was not to be cut was not settled.

—My question is to the Minister for Veterans' Affairs. Last week, in the hearing of Senate Estimates Committee F, the Minister confirmed that he had `some reservations' regarding the decision-making processes of the Australian War Memorial, a statutory authority under his control. Will the Minister comment on the sources of his information? Has the Returned Services League been involved in discussions on this matter?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Gietzelt Sen The Hon A.T.

TALK.START.PARA: —Under the Australian War Memorial Act 1980 the control of the Australian War Memorial is vested in the Council, to which the Minister of the day has the opportunity to nominate 10 members. As well, there are three ex-officio members from the armed services in their capacities as Chiefs of Staff of their respective service areas. In respect of administration of the Australian War Memorial, the Minister's powers under the Act are fairly restricted, so the managerial responsibility rests clearly in the Council's hands. Within the past year, certain information came to my attention that showed that some matters had not received the sort of care and attention that should have been within the responsibility of the administration of the Australian War Memorial. Those matters were drawn to the attention of the Council. In addition, I took certain steps which were available to me, within the restrictions of the Australian War Memorial Act, as the Minister responsible to Parliament for the care, control and management of the Australian War Memorial.

ANSWER.PARA: In April this year, I referred some of those matters to the Auditor-General and I will shortly receive a confidential report in respect of not only those matters to which I drew the Auditor-General's attention but also other matters which he subsequently discussed with me. In addition, I found that, in respect of a number of matters which involved responses by me or by the Minister representing me in the House of Representatives and other matters, the information provided to me by the Director was such that I had to say to the Council that I had lost confidence in the Director. To give but one example, a question was asked of me following a report in the Canberra Times in September last year. When I replied in this place to the question, the information which had been provided to me by the Director was clearly at variance with the facts. At this stage I will make no more comment on that other than to say that that is one of the many matters I have referred to the Australian War Memorial Council and to Mr Greg O'Connor of the Department of Veterans' Affairs for investigation, some of those matters being in response to questions placed on notice by the shadow Minister in the other place, Mr Tim Fischer.

All I can say at this stage is that those matters, the subjects of reports from the officers of the Department of Veterans' Affairs and the Australian War Memorial Council, which is delegating its executive officer to consider these and other matters, are the subject of further consideration by the Council, on which I place total managerial responsibility for these matters. It would be unfair of me to detail for Senator Sibraa the issues which are still the subject of further investigation except to say that in my judgment those matters are sufficiently serious to require investigation and to be referred to the Australian War Memorial Council. I am sure that in due course the processes will resolve the issues.

TALK.START.PARA: —I address my question to the Leader of the Government in the Senate. Following the second successive quarterly fall in manufacturing output in Australia, revealed last week by the Australian Bureau of Statistics, and the survey carried out by the Confederation of Australian Industry and Westpac Banking Corporation showing further deterioration in manufacturing industry in the September quarter and a worse outlook for December, when does the Minister expect the desperately needed general recovery for Australian manufacturing industry to take place, particularly in the face of the high interest rates, anti-business taxes and excessive labour costs-the burden of which is to increase by at least a further halfpenny after this weekend-that are the consequences and centrepiece of the Government's present economic policy?

—Senator Baume has quoted from several sources. When he speaks, he quotes from several sources; he speaks with a forked tongue. He might be Steve Martin on one occasion, Patrick Partners on another and Senator Michael Baume on a third. But the two sources from which he quoted are now a little older than some more recent sources.
—But I was always No. 1.

—Yes, in the honourable senator's own estimation. The recent survey by the Australian Chamber of Manufactures, which is one document to which the honourable senator did not refer, is a little more encouraging than the earlier information to which he did refer. DEBATE.TITLE: JOINT SELECT COMMITTEE ON ELECTORAL REFORM

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Carrick Sen The Hon Sir J.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate take note of the paper.

The Joint Select Committee on Electoral Reform, of which I am a member, brought down a report in November last year entitled `Determining the Entitlement of Federal Territories and New States to Representation in the Commonwealth Parliament'. The Committee had the knowledge that the Commonwealth Constitution gives the Parliament very wide powers indeed with regard to representation of such Territories in the Parliament. Section 122 of the Constitution states:

The Parliament may make laws for the government of any territory surrendered by any State to and accepted by the Commonwealth, or of any territory placed by the Queen under the authority of and accepted by the Commonwealth, or otherwise acquired by the Commonwealth, and may allow the representation of such territory in either House of the Parliament to the extent and on the terms which it thinks fit.

The important point that the Committee considered was the fact that the Parliament may allow representation of the Territory in this House and in the other place to the extent and on the terms it thinks fit. Clearly, although the condition of the Constitution has not been abused, it would be possible for a government having a majority in both places to make provisions for the Territory quite outside the population demands, thereby stacking the Parliament.

The Committee directed itself to ways and means by which this could be avoided. Clearly, the only way it could be avoided would be to have a device which, having been submitted to the electorate by referendum, would be embodied in the Constitution. The Committee felt that that should be so in the long run, but that there should be an interim measure; that is, that the Parliament should be invited to pass legislation which would set out the terms of representation of Territories. Whilst that in itself would be capable of being altered by another parliament, nevertheless it would be there both as a sanction and as a guide. Therefore, the Committee has decided, and the Government has agreed, to make a series of recommendations which, according to the Government, will be brought into this Parliament as law. At the same time the matter will also be referred to the Australian Constitutional Convention. On a number of recommendations the Government has said that the Parliament will have the appropriate legislation before it and that the Constitutional Convention will look at the constitutional nature of the legislation and report back to the Parliament. The basis of the representation of the Territories is the one on which representation in the various States is decided; that is, a quota is struck for the whole of Australia and, as a result, is applied to the Territories.

Time does not permit me to outline this matter in any detail. The Committee is happy that the main recommendations are to be adopted by the Government. One provision has for the moment been set aside and is a question for the future; that is, whether the Australian Capital Territory should have self-government. I think that matter can be reasonably set aside for the moment. I commend the response of the Government and I commend the report of the Committee to the Senate.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Macklin Sen M.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Government's response is welcome. It was made relatively rapidly, certainly compared with responses to a number of other reports. The major recommendation of the Joint Select Committee on Electoral Reform with regard to the admittance of new States is really not dealt with, because it is provided that the Australian Constitutional Convention shall consider this matter. I am not at all sure how beneficial that will be. Essentially the Joint Committee canvassed all the various positions that I think it was possible to canvass on that issue. When it comes down to it, there are only two major positions. One was the recommendation of the majority of the Committee members, that is, that no State be admitted to the Federation on terms and conditions which are more favourable than the recommendations for the representation of the Territories. The other position, which was the one that I took in the minority report, is that any new State which is admitted to the Commonwealth should be admitted on the same terms and conditions as the current States. Quite frankly, I think there really are not any other viable positions. I am not quite sure what the Constitutional Convention will do. I expect it will go over the entire ground again and come up with exactly the same answers.

SPEECH.PARA: On the other recommendations to which the Government has responded positively, I think the response will be useful, particularly its decision to amend the Bill with regard to the representation of the Territories in the House of Representatives and the Senate. The only item which I wish to raise again and which was one that I raised in the Committee is that by packing ourselves into a firm structure we have to be careful that we do not pre-empt possible developments in terms of Territories. While I cannot foresee our having any other Territories, the possibilities in terms of any legislation, particularly with regard to the Constitution, or items with regard to the Electoral Act should be written in more general terms. I believe they should be written with regard to population. For example, the Committee's second recommendation dealt with quotas for the House of Representatives. The Committee recommended that at least half the quota should be achieved before a Territory is entitled to have a member of the House of Representatives.

I simply wanted to add my response on this and to thank the Government for the speed with which it responded to the Joint Committee's report. I hope the legislation which is foreshadowed with regard to recommendations 2 and 3 is forthcoming rapidly.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Harradine Sen B.

TALK.START.PARA: —As a member of the Joint Select Committee on Electoral Reform I, too, would like to join Senator Sir John Carrick and Senator Michael Macklin in discussing this motion to take note of the responses of the Government to our report.
