TALK.START.PARA: —The Loans Bill 1986 is very similar to a Bill introduced by the present Government in 1985 which sought to change the basis upon which the Government sought authority from the Parliament to carry out its borrowing program. In 1985 the Government decided in its wisdom to propose legislation which gave perpetual authority to the Government to carry on its borrowing program notwithstanding that for many years the practice had been for the Government to come to the Parliament each year and seek specific authority for each year's borrowing program. Last year the Opposition, together with the Australian Democrats, successfully amended that piece of legislation so as to return to the system of annual approval of the loans. I give notice that the Liberal Party and the National Party will move to amend this Bill so that annual approval for the Government's borrowing program remains within the control of the Parliament rather than a blanket authority being handed over to the Government for it to undertake its borrowings as and when it sees fit. This is in line with the basic propositions of the democratic system under a Westminster style of government which goes back to the days of the Stuarts and earlier in the development of our democratic process. For that reason, during the Committee stage of this debate we will propose specific amendments to the legislation.

SPEECH.PARA: I also give notice that, at the end of the motion for the second reading of this Bill, we will seek to include the following words:

but the Senate notes with concern the continuing increase in the nation's indebtedness, the continuing balance of payments and trade crisis, the continuing high levels of interest rates and the Government's cosmetic approach to the reduction of its spending outlined in the recent Budget.

It is true that this Bill encompasses the whole range of matters involved in the Government's Budget. That is because the Bill specifically raises funds in order to meet the Government's revenue deficit. As a result, all of the measures to raise moneys that are authorised by this Bill have a direct relationship with the outlays side of the Budget, that is, all the expenditures that are undertaken by the Government. By implication, of course, it also relates directly to all the taxes raised by the Government to finance its expenditure. The difference between the two, which this year will be a deficit of some $3.5 billion, is the subject of this legislation. For that reason we will move an amendment to the second reading so as to draw attention to the shortcomings of the Government's management of the economic and financial affairs of this country.

Over the last several weeks we have observed a dramatic change in this Government's approach to the management of the economy. Until about May of this year we saw on the part of both the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) and the Treasurer, Mr Keating, a `she's all right' approach. All of the Ministers and back benchers went around the country parroting the line that Australia was going quite well. I think Senator Aulich also had a hand in this. Quite clearly, that has now been seen to be an illusion. In fact, the Government has pointed out quite clearly that we are at war in the economic management of this country. The Hawke Government is leading us in a campaign to restore the economic health of this nation as though the country was at war. The Prime Minister has pointed out to us time and again that we should be on a wartime footing. In the campaign in the lead-up to the Budget of 19 August we were conditioned to think that we all had to don our tin helmets, pick up a rifle and get to the trenches to protect Australia against the overseas hordes that were pouring in upon us. When the Budget was brought down, it was some wimpish document which did not attempt to deal with the fundamental problems in the economy but rather cosmetically dealt with some of the expenditure aspects and some of the needs within the economic framework in this country, such as our industrial relations and work practices problems.

Let us look at the background to our present economic scene. We lack competitiveness with the rest of the world. That is why we are unable to sell our goods on world markets as well as we should. There has been a fall off in demand, and consequently in the price that we obtain, for our traditional exports, such as minerals and agricultural goods. There has been no offsetting income from the export of goods manufactured in this country because we have been unable, through cost pressures, to sell those goods on world markets. The reason for that is that we need not only to lift our technological basis to increase our ability to sell in world markets but also to improve our marketing and management capacities in industry. But, more than anything else, we need to realise that, whenever we pay ourselves an increase in wages, adopt work practices that are inefficient or assume that the world owes us a living, we will not find it easy to sell those goods on world markets. Is it any wonder that we have seen our exports fall to the levels of recent months and that our imports have tended to rise, although in the most recent months they have tended to level off due to a lack of demand in the Australian economy?

It is interesting that that has led to a situation where every month we face a deficit on our overseas trading account of more than $1,000m. In order to make up that deficit we have to borrow about the same amount from overseas. Naturally, this leads to an increase in our overseas deficit and our total overseas borrowings. When this Government came to power in 1983 the total overseas indebtedness was about $35,000m. We now find that that level is in excess of $80,000m and is expected to rise to near $100,000m by the end of this financial year. What this Government has done in the last three years is to pump up the economy by borrowing, by stimulating demand and thereby bringing more imported goods into Australia. It has created a demand for those goods and stimulated the economy in a way that it promised it would do at the 1983 election. This has led to a colossal balance of payments problem the like of which we have never seen in this country's history and which is proving very difficult to deal with.

The fact is that the answers to our economic problems lie in dealing with the fundamental questions which have not been dealt with in this Budget. They relate, of course, to our inability to compete and our lack of technology. We have seen in the immediate area around us, in the Pacific and in the Asian region, the growth in recent years of nations such as Taiwan, Korea, Thailand, Malaysia, the People's Republic of China and India. There we have seen developing technologies taking those countries ahead in terms of production and providing jobs for people in those countries, and leaving even the technology of Australia way behind. We need only consider the impact of technology in a country such as India where there have been enormous steps forward in recent years in the nuclear industry, in communications and in other areas. But probably the most significant area is the leap forward in Indian agriculture where, through increased technology and investment in agriculture, we now see for the first time in its history India exporting grain. We all remember in earlier times the fact that India always seemed to be plagued by famine. Now we find that country being a net contributor to the world's markets in grain, rather than being a customer for other producers.

Is it any wonder that Australia is finding itself in difficulties dealing with countries that have decided to take all the risks in the world and invest heavily in technology of various kinds to develop their economies? Yet we have failed in this country to face that challenge. That, I think, is because-we have seen this in the last three or four years-of the development of a closed mind by this Government to that kind of development. Rather we have seen this rearguard fight against the possible loss of jobs in some industries instead of a new, positive approach in industrial development towards what might be achieved. The reasons for this are quite obvious. Instead of seeking to encourage investment in these kinds of industries which we have been talking about, those that have technological futures and a future in the world, we have turned our back on that.

One might well ask: Where is the evidence for that? The fact is that we have allowed our interest rate structure to build up to the highest level, in real terms, for 50 years, thus putting a tremendous brake on investment in this country. Clearly that investment, which is so necessary to provide jobs for ordinary Australians, is not occurring because we are providing massive disincentives for people to do so. The Government has consciously, deliberately, kept a high interest rate policy, based on the need, of course, to protect a very weak Australian dollar, which has tended to fall over recent times and which has required even higher levels of interest rates in order to maintain some semblance of value for it.

TALK.START.PARA: —What about the Government's encouragement to invest in paper profits?

—The honourable senator has a certain obsession about that matter which I think deserves a separate argument. But I draw attention to one other aspect of the interest rates question. The fact is that the matter of interest rates is not only an overseas question, in that the Government is forced to keep interest rates high deliberately to protect the Australian dollar; it is also keeping its own Budget deficit at a very high level in order to maintain some semblance of interest rate feasibility. Up until this year, the Budget deficit has been very high indeed and, in fact, ran some $800m over the Budget estimate up to the year ended June 1986. That in itself has created enormous pressure on the money markets in this country which has put more and more pressure on interest rates.

SPEECH.PARA: It is quite clear that these two things together-the Budget deficit, which is the subject of this legislation, and a deliberate policy of having to maintain high interest rates to keep up the dollar-are part of a deliberate scheme totally within the control of this Government. It is not a question of pointing to trends in our overseas markets and blaming everybody else in the world for this situation. The fact is that we have seen the massive disincentive that high interest rates bring caused by this Government's own deliberate economic policies, which are totally within its own control. For that reason we have not seen the great leap forward in new industrial investment in this country which we could have expected in the last three and a half years that these people have been in power. That is what they are supposed to have brought us, but we have not seen that at all. All we have seen is heavier and heavier borrowings which have brought us to the brink of economic crisis with our balance of payments. That is a situation that will have to be retrieved by the Howard government after the next election.

The failure of the Government in this area has been of absolutely monumental proportions. It is only now that the Australian people are starting to realise the extent to which this Government has brought them to a situation of crisis. The answers, of course, rest on encouraging new investment in green fields areas, new technologies and the development of new industries, to provide jobs for ordinary Australians. That is what the next government's policies must be about. The incentives for that have to be found by reference to the basic economic facts of life. The truth is that if we are to stop the huge, mammoth investment by Australian investors on overseas markets, which, of course, means that that money is not finding its way into Australian investments, we have to provide people with the incentive to want to invest here. The Government's own Budget has told us that there will be a fall this financial year, an actual reduction, in the overall investment rate by companies and other employers in this country. What we need is exactly the reverse. Yet we are seeing superannuation funds and insurance companies-I cite the AMP Society and the National Mutual Life Association as examples-investing up to 40 per cent of their current investable funds on the New York stock exchange or the Tokyo stock exchange rather than in new investments here in this country which would provide jobs.

TALK.START.PARA: —Isn't that an absolute tragedy for the country, a scandal?

—It is an absolute scandal and a tragedy, and it is a direct result of this Government's policies. The reason for that is that there is no incentive for people to invest in this country and obtain a return. We cannot blame those funds and insurers for investing off-shore, because they have a charter to ensure that their policy holders get the best possible return for their investment. Consequently, if they see investments off-shore that are far superior to those available in Australia, they have a duty, not just a right, to make sure that they take advantage of it. Indeed, that seems to be the rationale of the Government's policy in opening the exchange controls a few years ago.
—Could I just ask what your reference is to the 40 per cent of superannuation funds being invested off-shore?
—Forty per cent of current investable funds is my information. That refers to new moneys becoming available as opposed to the total amount of money which is actually invested by those organisations.
—It is an incredibly high figure.

—It is a very high figure and a very concerning one to most members of this Parliament, if not to all in the Government. These concerns, I think, lie at the basis of the economic problem in Australia. What we have to do is to reverse the total sentiment towards investment in Australia to create jobs. It is largely a psychological problem. Yet we find this Government coming along with major disincentives to investment, such as the capital gains tax. Let us just strip away all the rhetoric that we hear from Ministers in this place about capital gains and so-called tax avoidance. Let us look at it just in pure and simple terms. This Government's capital gains tax is the highest and most difficult tax of its kind anywhere in the world. It applies to future, not past, investments. Consequently, it is a tax on the future and a deliberate attempt to take away from people the incentive to invest in this country. Those who already have investments will not be subject to the tax, thus the rich get richer and the poor get poorer. That is this Government's approach. The major effect that this has is to act as a disincentive to those who would have invested and created jobs in the future. Is it any wonder that people who might be contemplating investment in this country should be frightened when they see this kind of capital gains tax lobbed on them? Is it any wonder that they believe that this Government does not really understand what it is doing when it talks about giving encouragement and incentive to investment at a time when this is most necessary?

SPEECH.PARA: It is quite clear that this Government fails to recognise the psychological need to lead this country out of the economic downturn that we have been experiencing since last Christmas. Clearly we are in a recession, by all normal measures of that term, and consequently we have circumstances which must be reversed. Psychology is the key to this, particularly in the area of investment. Yet we see more and more attempts by the Government to bring in various things to stop that incentive. Let us think back to the period around 1 July this year when the Government raced into print to introduce a new withholding tax on dividends paid overseas. A month later, when the dollar had crashed as a result of that, the Government whipped off the tax before it had actually had a chance to put it into effect. There is no coherent pattern for the development of a kind of psyche towards a better investment atmosphere in this country at all. There has been absolutely no attempt to think through what is required. Rather, the Government keeps rushing around like rats in the bottom of a bin trying to chase every little question mark that arises and accusing everyone else in sight of being evil people or the devils causing the problem, rather than facing the very real questions that it needs to face.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Government has done no long term planning at all.

—Clearly, there is very little long term thinking at all about what could be done to stimulate incentive for Australians to get on and develop this country. One only has to look at the Budget Papers themselves to understand the nature of our problem. Just a moment ago I talked about the capital gains tax. This year the Government will take 25.5 per cent of the gross domestic product by way of taxation. That is the highest level of taxation ever taken by any government since Federation. That is a measure of this Government's attitude to incentive. All it does is seek to impose higher and higher taxes on Australians, rather than to lower taxation and provide more and more incentives. It can tell us how much it is doing in the tax avoidance area, but all of that falls to ground against the primary benchmark of that simple fact-that this Government is taking a greater proportion of this nation's total production than any government has ever taken before. That is in line with the high tax policy of this Government and is tied down directly to the fundamental psychology and philosophy of the Australian Labor Party.

SPEECH.PARA: Let us look at the approach which this Government has adopted to the management of the outlay side of the Budget. There we find great shortcomings in its attitude as well. The total expenditures have remained steady compared with the previous year and that is something to be applauded. But it is necessary for the Government to take the real scalpel to the job and try to reduce expenditures rather than merely to defer them. A very large part of the Budget savings, as spelt out in the Budget Papers, is mere deferrals of expenditures that will occur and recur in the forthcoming financial year. From that point of view the Government has done little to attack the fundamental problems of this nation and is certainly not facing up to its real challenges in that area.

We see, too, that the Budget itself has been put forward as an attempt to obtain a better market sentiment amongst financiers in the hope that interest rates will be kept down. That failed on this ground as well, because the financial markets saw straight through the Budget. They saw that it was an impossible statistic to predict that the overall level of unemployment this year would rise by only 36,000 persons in net terms. It is quite clear that, after a rise of some 60,000 unemployed in the last two months, that figure will be very hard to meet by the end of the year, especially in light of the contractionary nature of this Budget. Quite clearly that figure is understated. Also there are very serious doubts-and we have raised them in this place before-about the 8 per cent figure for inflation when it is already seen from within the Budget Papers that the underlying rate of inflation, unaffected by such things as Medicare and discounted values of wages obtained in the Australian Conciliation and Arbitration Commission last year, is running at about 10.5 per cent, even at the moment. All these things are being seen through-the deferrals of expenditures rather than reductions, the lower inflation rate than might be expected by the markets and the fact that unemployment appears to be out of line with expectations. Quite clearly all this is working against the sentiments that this Government sought to achieve in favour of its Budget. Clearly the markets are saying that every day as they deal with the problems of our economy.

Obviously, the money markets were the target of this Government. It has unashamedly admitted that the main purpose of the Budget was to make sure that the markets gained a positive impression of the Budget and the direction in which the nation's economy was headed. We know how the Government raced around in the last few days trying to find expenditure cuts and increased taxes in order to get the deficit down to $3.5 billion just before it introduced the Budget. This was done to meet those expectations of the market-place. But the Government has failed and it has failed dismally to convince the money markets, both in Australia and overseas, that it has the solutions in this Budget. For that reason we on this side of the Senate have great feelings of shame about this Budget, both in terms of its presentation and in terms of this Loans Bill 1986 which governs the overall borrowing programs of the Government. We have considerable concern.

As I mentioned at the outset, we will seek to amend the Bill itself in the course of the Committee stage of the debate in order to return to an annual approval of government borrowings rather than to allow the Government to proceed with its measure to provide perpetual authority for its borrowing program. That is of fundamental importance and we will develop those arguments later. At this moment I wish to move formally the Opposition amendment to the second reading. I move:
At end of motion, add:

`but the Senate notes with concern the continuing increase in the nation's indebtedness, the continuing balance of payments and trade crisis, the continuing high levels of interest rates and the government's cosmetic approach to the reduction of its spending outlined in the recent Budget'.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Colston Sen M.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Senate is debating the Loans Bill 1986. The purpose of the Bill, among other things, is to make provision for the financing of the prospective Budget deficit in the financial year 1986-87. Because of this I would like to make some remarks about the Budget to which this Loans Bill refers and upon which this legislation has been built. In mid-August the Hawke Labor Government introduced a remarkable Budget. It was remarkable in that, although it was a tough Budget, it was and still is widely accepted by the Australian people, who expected, and maybe even demanded, the type of Budget which was introduced. It was a remarkable Budget in that it had no increase in real outlays and the deficit of $3.5 billion was less than most economic observers thought was possible. I am pleased to speak in this debate as a member of a government which has had the courage and resolution to rise to the challenge Australia now faces due to a large extent to the dramatic slump in world commodity prices. I am also gratified, as a member of the Australian Labor Party, to relate my remarks to the Federal Budget in which the Government has maintained its commitment to the most needy while asking for restraint from all sections of the community.

SPEECH.PARA: Since the early days of European settlement, Australia has been a trading nation. Its fortunes have depended to a large degree on the health of the international economy and how much other nations have been able to pay for our exports. Over the years we have not diversified our export mix and nowadays we realise that a major restructuring is essential. Our export dependence on primary products has remained high. Even today, commodities account for 79 per cent of our exports. Other major countries do not have a similar level of dependence on commodities for their economic well-being. For example, the proportion of Canada's exports which are agricultural and mining products is 36 per cent compared to the 79 per cent I mentioned earlier for Australia. For the United Kingdom, the proportion is 31 per cent, and for other major nations the proportion is even less. I seek leave to incorporate in Hansard a table headed `Commodities as proportion of total exports-1985', the figures for which were provided by the Parliamentary Library.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the Senate. The table indicates, firstly, the proportion that agricultural products represent of total exports for eight nations and, secondly, the proportion that agriculture and mining represent of those nations' exports. The figures in these tables clearly indicate Australia's far higher dependence on agricultural and mining products than the other seven countries-Canada, France, Italy, Japan, United Kingdom, United States of America and West Germany. This higher dependence carries with it a higher risk of a reduction in national income if commodity prices fall. In this respect, our resource-based exports have always been prone to fluctuations in international markets and susceptible to the long term decline in the value of commodities, relative to processed goods and services.

SPEECH.PARA: For a decade or more our terms of trade-export prices relative to import prices-have been declining by an average annual rate of one per cent. This long term trend accelerated dramatically over the last 18 months because of the sharp slump in world commodity prices. In real terms, the International Monetary Fund non-oil commodity price index reached a post-World War II low in 1986. Compared to the long term average decline of around one per cent per annum, our terms of trade have fallen 14 per cent over the last year alone-10 per cent of which has occurred since the June quarter. Quite clearly, this represents a staggering decline in the value of Australia's exports and thus the nation's income. This decline is evident from an inspection of price movements for the particular commodities which form the bulk of Australia's exports. Since mid-1984, just over two years ago, international prices for wheat and aluminium, measured in United States dollar terms, have fallen by 20 per cent. Coal prices have dropped by 14 per cent. In this year's June quarter alone, wheat prices fell by 23 per cent. Measured against a basket of world currencies, metal prices fell by an average of 17 per cent during the last financial year.

What these changes in world prices have meant to Australia is a reduction of about $6 billion, or about 2 per cent, in our national income. The decline in our terms of trade has caused the current account deficit in 1985-86 to be $4.25 billion greater than it otherwise would have been. It turned 1985-86 from being a year of significant improvement in our balance of payments position to being a year almost as bad as the record set by John Howard in 1981-82. There are numerous reasons why world prices for commodities have fallen. A major cause is the questionable, if not corrupt, trading practices of the United States of America and the European Economic Community. This may have been turned around slightly over the past couple of days in meetings in which the Minister for Trade, Mr John Dawkins, has had some remarkable success.

It should be realised that our diminished export earnings are the result of external factors over which this Government has very little, if any, influence. As I have outlined, however, Australia has long been extremely vulnerable to such a price collapse because of our heavy dependence on primary exports. Our economy has been geared towards selling primary products to the rest of the world at high prices and buying manufactured goods at low prices. The world is no longer like that, and we cannot sit back and hope that the old days will return. Much of the responsibility for our trade imbalance must rest with those governments of the past which lacked the foresight to develop a sound manufacturing industry and lessen our export dependence on primary products and the mining industry.

The sharp fall in Australia's capacity to maintain its living standards may thus be traced to decades of coalition neglect-neglect of our manufacturing industries and neglect of our need to expand and strengthen Australia's industrial and export base. Indeed, one of the greatest tragedies of Australia's economic history has been the underperformance of our manufacturing sector. The conservatives regarded assistance to the agricultural sector as some form of holy writ but stifled the manufacturing sector with an overvalued exchange rate. The overvalued Australian dollar made our manufacturers uncompetitive, eventually resulting in imports flooding in, wrecking Australian jobs and industry.

To put our balance of payments problem into an historical perspective, it is necessary to look back to the Menzies-McEwen era, when protection was increased to a wide range of industries. The long term results of those policies are all too evident in our current balance of payments difficulties. More recent coalition governments have also left their sorry mark. In particular, the Fraser-Howard team institutionalised import quotas in our most highly protected industries-textile, clothing and footwear. Assistance to the motor vehicle industry was also increased significantly under the Fraser Government, mainly via import quotas. Equally significant was the Government's inaction when faced with the opportunity to reform Australian industry. What did the Fraser Government do about the Industries Assistance Commission report, `Approaches to General Reductions in Protection', which recommended ways of reducing protection across the broad spectrum of industries? It did absolutely nothing.

Rather than take a realistic, reasonable look at Australia's economic base, the conservatives preferred to ride on the sheep's back and the prospect of the resources boom. For years after I entered the Senate in 1975, the governing coalition saw a forthcoming resources boom as the answer to Australia's economic problems. Scarcely a week went by without the boom being hailed as the nation's salvation. Of course, the boom never materialised. Thirty years of tired coalition policies fostered a complacent Australian industry. By the late 1970s the protectionist policies of a succession of so-called free enterprise governments had had their effect. Industry was dealt a further heavy blow in the 1980s by our predecessors, whose policies led to an economic recession. In contrast, the Hawke Government over the last three years has shown itself willing and able to make the necessary and sometimes hard decision to assist Australian industry and Australian people to meet the challenges we face. We have taken the necessary steps to encourage the development of strong, healthy, internationally competitive manufacturing industries in Australia.

In this respect, it is pertinent to examine the floating of the Australian dollar and how this has assisted our manufacturing sector. Since early 1985, the Australian dollar has depreciated about 25 per cent against the United States dollar, 40 per cent against the trade weighted index and 50 per cent against the Japanese yen. Coupled with wage restraint-an estimated 8 per cent decline over four years-this has given Australian industry a level of international competitiveness unknown in at least 20 years. Already there is clear evidence that our policies are having the desired effect. During the last financial year there was a 7.4 per cent increase in the volume of Australian exports and import volumes declined at an annual rate of 10 per cent in the first half of 1986. In 1985-86 investment in manufacturing grew by 40 per cent. The floating of the exchange rate means that our economic problems can no longer be hidden away in the balance sheet of the Reserve Bank of Australia, as was previously the case. As a representative of Queensland, I am pleased that my State is particularly well endowed to take advantage of the growth in international tourism resulting from our dollar's devaluation and the resulting increased attractiveness of Australia as a holiday destination.

That the Hawke Government has already established first-class economic credentials is another reason why I am confident that this Government is better equipped than any other in Australia's history to match the challenge we now face. A quick comparison of the Hawke and Fraser governments' economic records will illustrate my point. The Fraser Government actually created negative economic growth of minus one per cent in 1983. The Hawke Government has created several years of strong growth. In 1983-84 and 1984-85, the first two years of the Hawke Government, economic growth reached 5 per cent, and 4.5 per cent in 1985-86. During 1986-87 the economy is expected to grow at a rate of more than 2 per cent. During the Fraser years unemployment reached double digit figures, while the Hawke Government has created 713,800 jobs since March 1983. Employment has grown by around 12 per cent in the last three years and most of this employment growth has been in the private sector. The increase in employment in 1985-86 was the largest growth in the 20 years since official labour market surveys began.

The Hawke Government has halved the number of days that were lost in industrial disputation under the Fraser Government. Under the Fraser Government profits were slashed, reaching a low of 12.7 per cent of gross domestic product in 1982-83. Under the Hawke Government profitability has been restored to the levels experienced in the 1960s, reaching 15.6 per cent of GDP in the first half of 1985-86. Mr Howard, as Treasurer, started off with a Budget deficit of $1.4 billion in 1982 and 18 months later left the incoming Labor Government with a prospective $9.6 billion deficit. I mention those matters to give a comparison of the previous Government with the present Government; a Government which is working to bring prosperity to Australia.

As the Hawke Government has picked up and repaired the coalition's economic legacy, we are now in the process of accomplishing the long needed restructuring of an imbalanced economy. It is ironic that the Opposition is now suggesting that a decline in manufacturing and manufacturing exports which took place over 20 years should be reduced overnight. The Hawke Government has made enormous progress in the past three years in modernising and freeing up the economy. We now have a much lower wage cost structure and an energetic financial sector, making us vastly more competitive than we were a few years ago. We have also accomplished something without precedent in Australia-a comprehensive and integrated basis for consistent long term economic planning. We have brought about the basis of change which will enable Australia to adjust and become more responsive to future change.

Accordingly, the Hawke Government's fourth consecutive Budget represents our commitment to facilitating Australia's adjustment to changed economic circumstances. Restraint in spending is essential to align our living standards more closely with our capacity to produce. The Budget has spread this adjustment fairly across the community and the community has accepted that these adjustments had to be made. As a government, we have cut expenditure by nearly $3 billion, leaving us with a Budget deficit of $3.5 billion, compared with the $9.6 billion legacy of the previous Government. This was only the third time in 30 years that there has been no real growth in outlays. The Government has deregulated the financial sector, provided positive incentives for industry to increase research and development, removed the double taxation of dividends, established Austrade, expanded the Australian Industry Development Corporation, removed State purchasing preferences and relaxed foreign investment guidelines. The Government's policies for Australia's future are based on sound budgetary, monetary and wages policy and specific restructuring programs for Australian industry. The Government is to be commended for its Budget, upon which the Loans Bill is built. As one of the Government members who will be speaking on the Appropriation Bill, I commend this Bill to the Senate.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Siddons Sen J.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —We are debating the Loans Bill 1986. It is important to realise that this Bill is almost identical in wording to a Bill which was introduced into the Senate last year and which was substantially amended by this Senate. This Loans Bill is a blatant attempt by the Minister for Finance, Senator Walsh, and the Government to get this Parliament to sanction the Government's borrowing program forever. It has been customary to have the loans program for a particular year debated by the Parliament, as well it should be. If this Bill were passed by the Parliament it would take that responsibility from the Parliament and would allow the government of the day to borrow as it saw fit, without any debate as to the size or the burden of debt that the government of the day was placing on the people of this country. The fact that the Minister for Finance is prepared to bring in an identical Bill of such far-reaching importance is nothing more than an attempt by the Government to treat this Parliament and this Senate, as the Minister repeatedly does, as a kindergarten.

SPEECH.PARA: The Senate made it abundantly clear to the Minister for Finance last year that it was in no way prepared to pass a Bill which took from the Parliament its responsibility to debate and to comment on the loan program of a government in the year in which that loan program was brought down. Yet we have another blatant attempt by this Government to do just that. I believe it is incumbent on the Government to explain to this Senate why it has again attempted this year to do what the Senate clearly rejected last year. It is very significant that the Minister for Finance, who is responsible for this piece of legislation, is not in the chamber. Presumably he does not consider it important enough to sit through this debate and take note of the points that the Senate raises on this vitally important piece of legislation.

We have just sat through a disgusting spectacle during Question Time. The Minister for Finance indulged in the most blatant and almost unforgivable piece of character assassination in relation to the late Sir Phillip Lynch. He is quite happy to indulge in the character assassination of people who are no longer living, but he is not prepared to face up to his responsibilities in regard to legislation of this importance. Let me place on record that in my six years of involvement in the Federal Parliament I have yet to meet a politician who had a greater understanding of Australian industry than did the late Sir Phillip Lynch. He was an extraordinarily hard-working politician. If he had led a government-I believe his record gave him every right to do so at some stage-I am sure Australian industry would be in a much better position than it is today and many of the problems that we are facing right now would not have to be faced and would not be a burden on the Australian people.

The Opposition asserted that the Budget is fundamentally flawed, that it does not raise or address the fundamental problems relating to the Australian economy today. On behalf of the Australian Democrats I can only say that we could not agree more. I have said before and will say again that this Budget has not attacked the problem, which is our balance of payments. The fact of the matter is that over the last 30 years we have been borrowing money to balance our trading account and today we cannot afford to pay the interest. We have to stop borrowing money. This Government has made no attempt to address that problem, either directly or indirectly. It has said: `We will grind the economy into the dust. Maybe that way we will stop people importing goods that we do not have the funds to finance'. The Government is saying that we have to screw the economy and to place enormous burdens on average working Australians so that they just cannot afford to buy imported products, rather than saying: `We have a responsibility to manage the economy. We will manage it and we will take whatever measures we see fit to restrict the flow of imports into this country which the Australian nation can no longer afford'.

I was also interested to hear Senator Messner's comments along the lines that the Government had to encourage investment. The Democrats could not agree more. We do have to encourage investment. However, Senator Messner stopped short of saying that the Government has a responsibility to encourage investment in the right sorts of areas which are, clearly, productive areas. It is almost ludicrous and it never ceases to amaze me that, whilst we talk about the size of the Government's deficit-let me remind the Senate of the deficit of $3.5 billion which is, no doubt, a large amount of money and which I will come to later-an amount of $7.7 billion was borrowed, very largely from overseas, by those attacking and defending Broken Hill Proprietary Co. Ltd. Nearly twice the amount of the deficit that we are so concerned about was borrowed overseas by private investors without the Government considering it was necessary even to have an inquiry as to where this money was coming from and the terms of repayment. All Australians will have to accept the responsibility of meeting the interest commitments. There was no inquiry; the Government showed no concern and nearly twice the amount of the deficit was borrowed overseas.

The Bill before us enables the Government to borrow the money to finance its deficit. As I indicated previously, this is a very important responsibility. When the Government borrows money it puts debt on the shoulders of every Australian. It is vital that this Parliament should have the opportunity every year to scrutinise those borrowings and formally to give the Government the leave to incur the debt in the name of the Australian people.

We are dealing with very large amounts of money. In 1984-85 the deficit was $6.74 billion; in 1985-86 it was $5.726 billion; and the figure for 1986-87 is likely to be $3.5 billion. These are huge figures. They are beyond the comprehension of most Australians. However, the fact of the matter is that the total debt incurred by governments to 1986 is $93 billion. That represents $6,200 for every man, woman and child in this country, which is a very considerable burden on average Australians. There is no way that the Democrats can let the Government take away from this Parliament the power to oversee debt management.

It is significant that when this Bill was introduced into the House of Representatives last year the Opposition passed the legislation without an amendment, without a murmur and without any considerable criticism. It was not until the Bill got to the Senate last year that the Democrats raised the point that the Bill, as it was worded, gave the Government the responsibility to incur debt forever without ever referring that debt to the Parliament for debate. The Opposition in the Senate has again joined with the Democrats to ensure that such a responsibility is not given carte-blanche to the Government. We have circulated amendments to be moved in the Committee stage which will take away the power this legislation gives the Government never again to debate in this Parliament the size of its annual deficit. I stress that there is no way the Democrats will block this legislation. We are committed to allowing the Government to govern, and we will certainly not be doing anything that will block Supply. But it is fundamental that the Government should stand up to the criticisms and comments that are reasonably put before it.

I would like to make just a few comments about debt and whether the Government is right in borrowing money to finance its activities. I stress that debt, whether it is private or government, is not in itself wrong, provided that the money that is borrowed is wisely used and wisely invested. Since the radical free marketeers have taken control of the Australian Labor Party, as unfortunately they also control the Liberal Party of Australia, it is now conventional wisdom to say that all government debt is somehow inherently bad and that private debt is inherently good. This position, I would suggest, is obviously ridiculous. Those who attack the Government for borrowing money, for incurring debt-business people and others make this point-do not practise what they preach. Most company managers borrow money to finance their own companies. They run into debt and wisely and carefully invest the money that they borrow. Without debt people cannot buy the things they need, such as cars and houses; companies, likewise, must operate with a reasonable and managed amount of debt to enable them to expand, as governments have to borrow money to expand. The country is like a company; it has to operate with a certain level of debt. The fundamental questions are: Is that debt reasonable? What is the money to be spent on?

The Government and indeed the Opposition are saying that we must cut back on government borrowings to make room for the private sector. The Government is a government that was elected to represent working Australians. It is not a point of view that I thought a Labor Government would embrace. The theory runs something like this: If the Government borrows money it crowds out the private sector, and then there is not enough money available for the private sector to borrow and to invest wisely, on the basis that the Government always invests money unwisely. In fact the truth is the opposite. If one looks at the figures, the Government's debt as a percentage of gross domestic product is historically low in this country now. The debt has fallen from, would you believe, 181 per cent of gross domestic product in 1947.

TALK.START.PARA: —After the war.

—Indeed, after the war. In 1969 that had fallen to 56 per cent of gross domestic product. The figures do not bear out the fact that the Government is borrowing money and crowding out the private sector. Of course, it is very important for governments to borrow money and invest in such things as the building of roads and infrastructure generally. While the Government is castigating industry now on the basis that it is not investing in capital and development, the same criticism could be applied to the Government; it is not investing money in things that are the Government's responsibility, such as the building of roads and the infrastructure. If the Government is not prepared to give a lead it cannot really blame the private sector for being unhappy to invest in the future of this country. Again, as the Opposition has pointed out, at the current extraordinarily high interest rates it is a very, very good investment that can make a sufficient return to beat putting money into speculative paper investments, such as on the stock exchange, putting money into fixed investment and so on. When one can get interest rates of the order of 18 per cent or more, who would put money into machinery or developing productive resources?
—Private fixed term investment is down to billyo.

—The honourable senator will have his turn in a minute. I am just putting a point of view which I think the figures make indisputable. Without capital investment wisely invested we will not be able to climb out of the hole in which we find ourselves. That is a fact. We say that the fundamental strategy of this budget is flawed. It is cosmetic in the sense that it has played up to the international money markets. It was said by them that the only thing that mattered was a low deficit. Certainly the Government came up with a small deficit for this year. That is not solving our fundamental problems, which are: We are borrowing too much money; we have to get interest rates down, and we have to encourage investment in productive areas.

SPEECH.PARA: To summarise, I notice that the Opposition, without reference to the Australian Democrats, has moved an amendment to the second reading motion which states that the Senate notes with concern the continuing increase in the nation's indebtedness. Certainly the Democrats are concerned about the increase in the nation's indebtedness. However, we are more concerned about how borrowed money is invested. It is very hard for us to assess whether the purpose of this second reading amendment is purely to draw attention to the size of the deficit or whether it is directed more to some of the other things that it raises, such as the balance of payments and the trade crisis. Certainly we support that as the area which has to be focused on by the Government. Certainly we abhor and criticise the continuing high levels of interest rates. Certainly we will agree with the part of the Opposition's amendment that refers to the Government's cosmetic approach to the reduction in its spending in the recent Budget. This Budget was cosmetic. Very largely the deficit was got down by failing to index personal income tax rates. The much vaunted $2 billion cut in personal taxation rates will mostly be dissipated due to the fact that the Government has failed to index the threshold for personal income tax.

On balance the Democrats will support the Opposition's amendment at the second reading stage. I believe the emphasis on the nation's indebtedness can be misleading and can be misinterpreted by the Australian public, but on balance it raises matters which are of great concern to the Democrats. In the Committee stage of this Bill, as I foreshadowed, we will move amendments which have been circulated and which will take away from the Government the power to bypass the Parliament in getting approval for its annual debt commitment. I notice that the Opposition also has circulated an amendment which is to be moved in the Committee stage and which is not dissimilar to the Democrats' amendment. I have had the opportunity to discuss that matter with Senator Messner on behalf of the Opposition. We had to discuss it because it is such a vital matter. We have agreed that parts of our amendment will be moved by the Democrats and parts of the Opposition's amendment will be moved by it. Certainly there is no way that the Government will get away with this subterfuge of trying to bypass the Parliament on the vitally important question of whether we, the Senate, the Australian Parliament, should have a say in the annual debt commitments of the Government.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Foreman Sen D.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise today to speak on the Loans Bill 1986 because the extent of Commonwealth borrowings is an important feature of both domestic and international economic policy. In the supply and demand scene the demand on funds determines what interest rates will be. If excessive government borrowings take place, the availability of these funds for private investment is limited. Competition for loan funds, primarily determined by the extent of Commonwealth borrowing, can drive interest rates too high and hence damage to the economy can result. It is for this reason that I commend the Government on its restraint in this area, and I believe the background to our present economic situation needs to be explored to understand why this restraint has become possible.

SPEECH.PARA: The economy of Australia is the real provider of the benefits and standard of living which Australians enjoy, and when this economy is threatened then so too is the standard of living. When the Hawke Government came to power in March 1983 there was double digit inflation and double digit unemployment. The employment participation rate was at an all time low and the provision of new jobs in the 1982-83 financial year was at a disastrously low level. Consumer confidence in 1982-83 was also at a level such that retail sales were low. In the dying days of the Fraser-Howard Government the economy was experiencing such a rapid decline that real fears were held by Australians from all walks of life for the economic future of this country.

In 1975, at the inception of the Fraser Government, the level of unemployment was almost 200,000. At the time of its removal by the Australian people in 1983, the level of unemployment had risen to over 700,000. Throughout the period of the Fraser Government the level of employment slowly drifted downwards, sometimes in great rushes, such as in the last quarter before the March 1983 election and at other times in a slow relentless drop. At no stage did unemployment drop below those 1975 figures during the life of the Fraser Government. It was not only a case of a government which promised a great deal and never delivered, or never seriously looked like delivering; it was a government which stood on an industrial relations record that was abysmal. The number of working days lost was over the three million mark per annum from 1977 until 1981. The level since this Government has taken over has been on average less than half of that figure, despite an upswing in the economy which has seen significant inroads into unemployment and dramatic increases in the participation rate. The judgment on the Fraser-Howard years, written so convincingly in March 1983 by the public of Australia, was that of a government which had promised so much and delivered so little-I repeat, promised so much and delivered so little-with consumer confidence shattered, unemployment skyrocketing, interest rates at disastrous levels, industrial disputation levels ludicrously high, and no idea of what policies to pursue to turn around this bleak picture.

Upon the election of the Hawke Government in 1983 the policies which have been so successful were put in place. The creation of 680,000 new jobs has meant a vastly improved labour market and a significant reduction of the order of 200,000 in the number of people who are currently unemployed. In percentage terms, the level of unemployment has dropped almost a full 3 per cent on the figures of 1982-83, the last year for which Mr Howard was responsible for the Treasury. It should also be pointed out that in so many of the Fraser years inflation was identified as the first priority of the economy. It took this Government to put the lid on inflation and bring about its significant reduction. This is also an important ingredient in net Commonwealth borrowings that are part of the Bill before the Senate today.

In terms of industrial disputation, the 1.26 million working days lost in 1985 represents the lowest figure for any year since 1968. It will be of benefit to us to have a look at the circumstances under which these figures have been achieved. The Federal Government-Australian Council of Trade Unions accord has been the cornerstone on which these economic successes have been founded. The conservatives in this country have always sought to attack the trade union movement and have constantly attempted to wage a war of attrition with the unions. Sadly, rather than seeing the folly of this approach culminating in the end of the Fraser-Howard years, this abrasive policy of confrontation has been re-emphasised or recycled in an ever more aggressive form. The Hawke Government has believed strongly in the principle of working with the trade union movement and not deliberately against it. This constructive approach has meant a sharp decline in disputation, a renewed confidence in the economy and much better outcomes in wages and profits than would otherwise have been the case.

I note with interest a booklet from Broken Hill Proprietary Co. Ltd received in my office, with a letter attached signed by the Manager of Corporate Affairs, Mr McGregor. In that letter Mr McGregor made the following point:

BHP recently completed a financial year unprecedented in the amount of media attention due to the activity on its share register. This has tended to hide what has been the most successful year in the company's history with an Australian record profit of $1,009 million achieved.

I think this figure needs to be emphasised once more. BHP has had a record profit of over $1 billion and the most successful year in the company's history. Many other companies have registered record profits, which is one of the many benefits that have followed the accord between the Government and the ACTU. It is, of course, important to have substantial levels of profitability to ensure reinvestment in Australian industry. The ability to have good rates of profitability and reliability of that profit share, which is guaranteed by better industrial relations, has been the reason for our improved economic performance.

Now, it is true that some factors have worked hard to slow down this economic performance. What the Bill before us is really about is the extent to which government has to borrow to fulfil its obligations. It is pleasing to see that the amount of money required to finance a reduced deficit is now well below 2 per cent of gross domestic product. This reduction has meant that funds can now be made available for renewed economic activity. It should be remembered that whilst record rates of economic growth have meant that the domestic economy has fared well, the same is not so in the international arena. The continued international recession, with serious gluts of most commodities, has meant that on the international scene growth has been low or non-existent. The expansion of trade has been minimal or non-existent. The resultant contraction of international economic activity has been and will continue to be a big influence on Australia.

As a trading nation Australia depends for a substantial share of its economic wealth on healthy trade markets overseas. Unfortunately, despite record growth in the volume of Australian exports, the value of these exports has fallen dramatically. The glut in the commodity market overseas has meant a decline of over 14 per cent in prices and a decline of 3 per cent in Australia's national income. This serious erosion of Australia's national income over the last 12 months has followed a slow decline in commodity prices over many years. The difference in the 1985-86 financial year was the suddenness and magnitude of this decline.

During the Fraser-Howard years we were constantly being told that manufacturing in this country could go. The principle of the resources boom was that, by making Australia into a quarry, all imports could be paid for and a vibrant manufacturing sector was unnecessary. It was that attitude by the conservatives which meant that Australia was, indeed, adopting the features of under-development. A sophisticated economy derives its international trading position from a variety of exports, and not just an increased volume of exports of the same type. This Government has attempted, with considerable success, to rebuild a vibrant manufacturing sector which concentrates on exports. This job has been greatly helped by the depreciation in Australian currency which has brought about a new competitiveness not envisaged by countless conservative governments over many years. The greatest insulator of Australia's trading wealth is variety-variety of exports.

The 1986-87 Budget is, in my view, a document worthy of praise. The reduction in the deficit to $3,503 billion was a figure hardly contemplated. It underscores a determination that this Government has to overcome the problems which have accrued over many years of conservative mismanagement. I point out also that the demand on loan funds has diminished accordingly. The general thrust of the Budget and the Hawke Government's economic strategy has been to build an economically stronger and more vibrant Australia. The measures in the Budget spread the burden of Australia's dramatic trade decline fairly.

In summing up, the strategy of this Government has been sound. The Hawke Government has shown what benefits can be derived from a consensus approach to industrial relations and from the development of a stronger manufacturing sector. The Budget is a key part of that strategy and it shows the determination that this Government has to put the Australian economy back on the rails. Consequently, I commend the Bill to the Senate and re-emphasise that it was the responsible approach of the Hawke Government in its demands for Commonwealth borrowing that brought about the situation that we are in today-a situation in which Commonwealth borrowing is not at the level at which it is destroying investment and driving up interest rates.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Crichton-Browne Sen N.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Senate is debating the Loans Bill 1986. The Bill is designed to permit the Government to borrow $2.6 billion to finance, in part, its anticipated deficit of $3.5 billion. The $3.5 billion deficit which the Government is projecting as the real figure for this financial year is as unlikely to happen as is my finishing this speech by 5.30 p.m. By any measure, the Government is understating in major proportions the real deficit that this country and the taxpayers will face in 12 months time. Every indicator shows the contrary; yet the Government tells us that the economy will grow by 2.5 per cent in the coming financial year. Of course, that will not happen. As a result, there will be a significant shortfall in taxation receipts and a significant increase in the levels of unemployment benefit paid out and the other social welfare benefits that flow from a decline in real growth in gross domestic product.

SPEECH.PARA: In the past, it has been common for governments to pass Loan Bills each year to finance their deficits. However, as is shown by our amendment, this Bill goes one step further: It seeks to give standing powers to appropriate money from the loan fund. Of course, in doing so, it will remove from Parliament the ability it has always had-namely, carefully and conscientiously annually to scrutinise and comment critically on the raising of loans by the Federal Government. The Opposition has moved an amendment to the Bill so that it will do no more than authorise borrowings for this financial year, not for future financial years. In this way, the Opposition will ensure that the raising of loans by the Government is always subject to examination and scrutiny by the Parliament.

I shall take the opportunity, which by way of this Bill the Government seeks to deprive members of parliament of the future from taking, to comment on the Budget and the resultant need to borrow the $2.6 billion which the Loans Bill seeks to accommodate. This year, the Commonwealth Budget deficit is expected by the Government to be $3.5 billion. We are witnessing the extraordinary situation of the Government congratulating itself because it is spending only $3.5 billion more than it is raising. If one can find some light relief in that extraordinary claim of self-congratulations, it is that the Government has reduced the deficit from last year's $5.726 billion. Nevertheless, it is certainly not the basis, in any circumstances, for the self-congratulations in which the Government has been indulging.

The fact remains that the Government has projected outlays of $3.5 billion in excess of that which it expects in receipts. To finance that amount, the Government has had to raise enormous sums, such as those authorised by the Bill. In effect, this means that the Labor Government's extravagance today will be carried on the backs of our children and their children in the future. It is they who will have to repay the legacy of this Commonwealth Government's debt which the Government intends leaving to them.

Let us look at the history of this Government's economic mismanagement and demonstrate how it has betrayed the trust that the Australian people placed in it when it was elected. When the Australian Labor Party came to office it did what seems to be the fate of all Labor governments-past, present and, I have no doubt, future. It managed the Australian economy as though there would be no tomorrow. It took advantage of the upswing in the Australian economy and governed as though the upswing would go on forever. Now that the international economic climate has turned against the Government, we are faced with the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) telling the country that it faces a crisis as great as it would be if wartime were upon us. Australia is paying the price of the early extravagance of the Federal Government.

When the Labor Party came to office, it was blessed with the breaking of the worst drought in Australia's history and an upturn in the world economy. As might be expected, that led to an increase in Commonwealth Government taxation receipts. For example, in 1984-85 sales tax revenues increased by 19.2 per cent over the receipts of 1983-84. Similarly, income taxes increased by 25 per cent for companies and by 18.6 per cent for individuals. The interesting thing is that the breaking of the drought was worth $4 billion to gross domestic product. This Government had a windfall of $4 billion. What did it do with it? It squandered it; it wasted it; it spent it.
