That the Senate take note of the statement and papers.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! Before I call Senator Alston, I remind honourable senators that this is his first speech in this chamber and I ask that the normal courtesies be extended to him.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Alston Sen R.K.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is a great honour to be chosen to represent the people of Victoria. It is my privilege to enter the Federal Parliament at a parlous time in Australian history when many are claiming either that there are no solutions to our economic woes or that such solutions lie outside the parliamentary arena. Indeed, in many quarters there are calls for direct action and mass mobilisation by farmers, small business people and others. It is important to understand the reasons for such frustrations if we are to make an effective political response.

SPEECH.PARA: At the outset I would like to pay tribute to the Senator whose place I have recently taken. Alan Missen attained his life-long ambition in 1974 when he was elected to the Senate. Thereafter, he served with distinction until his sudden and untimely death on 29 March 1986. He was in many ways unique. His political ideology never wavered. He was passionately concerned with human rights issues and fought tirelessly to address political and social injustices, especially through his long involvement with the Parliamentary Group of Amnesty International, of which he was the Chairman at the time of his death. Through all of his political battles he had the strong support and admiration of his wife, Mollie. He was indeed a very fine human being and the Parliament is much the poorer for his passing.

I would like also to pay tribute to my many friends within the Liberal Party of Australia in Victoria. I was honoured to be President of the Party through a period of far-reaching administrative change. Through that difficult transition and beyond I was fortunate to have the help and support of many fine people who know the necessity for a successful political party to be able to rely on a united and effective organisational structure. Finally, I would like to thank my wife Megs and our children, Amy and Nicholas, for their love and support.

In an age where there is no shortage of superstars in the corporate arena, on the sporting fields or in the entertainment industry, statesmen remain in very short supply and politicians rank not far ahead of snake oil merchants in terms of public respect. It is therefore of vital importance that the national Parliament remain the crucible of democratic activities. The Senate offers a unique opportunity to pursue issues of national importance in a responsible, rational and, if necessary, courageous manner.

Whilst I come to the Parliament with a background of almost 20 years in private practice at the Victorian Bar, for almost all of that time I have had a keen and active interest in the political process. For almost a decade I was a senior office-bearer in a range of national organisations, including the United Nations Association of Australia and the Australian Council for Overseas Aid, the peak body for over 70 overseas aid agencies and of which I was the National Chairman from 1978 to 1983. Through my activities at both a national and an international level, I had the opportunity to travel widely, especially in the Third World, and to see at first hand the plight of many people less fortunate than ourselves and the many man-made rather than natural disasters which often account for poverty and underdevelopment.

My involvement in non-government organisations has made me acutely aware of both the power and the significance of extra-parliamentary groups. Whilst responsible community organisations are an essential safety valve in a democracy, they must never be allowed to usurp the role of government and the Parliament. In many ways this has happened by default. We have seen Federal governments of all persuasions which have been cowed by the headlines of the day, the squeals of vested interests, the naked blackmail and intimidation of the abusers of power. But what is needed is not merely a strong determination to stand firm but a set of principles by which to be guided.

I believe the Liberal Party has now developed a very clear and coherent alternative to the politics of expediency. We will restore the primacy of self-reliance, incentive and healthy competition rather than the debilitating and ultimately self-destroying reliance on the walking frame of government. As Professor Ralf Dahrendorf has argued, liberty involves the fostering of individual life chances.

In many ways Australia can be seen as a heathen society, constantly aspiring to material improvements and acquisitions without counting the social costs and without seeking the holistic integration of body, mind and soul. `To have or to be', said Erich Fromm. Many Australians unknowingly opt for the former. Many of our social dislocations can be attributed to a lack of spiritual purpose in life and a too ready resort to short term palliatives. To some extent progress is about means as much as ends. The mere accumulation of riches is an empty pursuit. But the striving for personal success and willingness to contribute to economic growth are vital for a dynamic yet caring society.

I do not want an Australia in which its major institutions are overthrown, the social safety net removed and the strong left to exploit the weak. But I do want a more thrusting, vibrant, challenging society in which individuals strive to maximise their potential to achieve worthwhile social and human goals rather than sheltering behind strong unions or big government.

Over the last several years the political debate in this country has been transformed. After decades of concentrating on the social consequences of government actions and the politics of handouts, regulation and protection, all of which are narcotics designed to destroy self-reliance, even the dominant factions in the Australian Labor Party have now grudgingly conceded the centrality of economic growth as the sine qua non for human progress. Capitalism world-wide has made a very strong comeback with many developing countries embracing privatisation, China firmly on the capitalist road and even the eastern European bloc striving for the competitive edge. It is little wonder that even a New South Wales senior Cabinet Minister recently suggested that socialism has failed.

I was indeed fortunate to grow up in the lucky country. World War II and the following two decades were periods of great development and steady progress in the growth of the Australian economy, and we were all able to take for granted the occupations of our choice. Perhaps the seeds of our current predicament can be found in the rejection of the 1966 report of the Vernon Committee of Economic Inquiry, a group of eminent Australians who said:

The trend of national productivity is of key importance in the economic growth of a country and in the improvement of its living standards. The study of this trend is vital for the discussion of wage trends and their relation to price stability, and to the competitive position of industry in relation to that of the country's principal competitors.

It is a great pity that such advice was not taken and has on a number of occasions been wilfully ignored by the Conciliation and Arbitration Commission, which has preferred to genuflect and at times grovel before the realism of industrial peace rather than take the responsible approach by having regard to an employer's capacity to pay, the economic consequences of indexation, the crippling effects of extravagant work practices and other forms of largesse unrelated to productivity and therefore to the competitive market-place. Productivity will improve only when there is less of a cold war mentality between management and union leaders and a marked attitudinal change that recognises the mutuality of interest in the success of an enterprise.

The ostrich approach to economic reality has its executive counterpart in the pusillanimous refusal of governments of all persuasions to recognise the beneficial incentive effects of low income tax regimes. At a time when the United States of America is moving to a top individual marginal rate of 28c in the dollar and when France and Ireland are the only two industrialised countries with higher corporate tax rates on distributed income, the present Federal Government persists in retaining a tax structure which can only drive the most productive enterprises off-shore or underground.

I regret the instant negative reaction to the concept of privatisation from those who are too cautious to recognise the obvious benefits of smaller government and competition within the public sector. The object of such reforms is not some crude moral crusade or ideological binge but rather a desire to enable individuals to have greater control over their lives and incomes. In many ways, a quiet revolution is occurring within Australia, in large measure as a response to an uncertain international trading environment but perhaps also reflective of the desire to maintain traditional ethical values in a period of rapid technological change.

The capacity of government to influence people's lives must not be underestimated, and it is now clear that in many ways the responsibilities of government are being redefined. Australia must always remain a generous nation, ready and willing to protect and support the weak, the poor and the needy and to strive for equal opportunities for all. But it does not follow that it is necessary to have an ever-increasing bureaucracy maintained by higher taxes and charges in order to achieve a just society. Whilst a balance must be struck between incentive and compassion, the pendulum can swing too far either way. The time has come when it is more important to emphasise freedom than mere equality.

Over the years I have been fortunate to have visited many countries in Africa and Asia as a member of official project aid missions. In my experience it is very difficult to make a quick quantitative assessment of the worth of many projects. Often it is necessary to attempt to gauge the development ethos and personal philosophy of aid workers and recipients. Almost invariably, the success stories are those where there is a high level of personal commitment and active involvement and a minimum of government intervention or assistance. The same lesson can be learnt at home. Those who lead the most worthwhile lives and achieve a measure of success are usually not those who merely inherit riches or rely on others to generate wealth. The real achievers are those who strive to improve the spiritual and material quality of their own lives and those of their families. However, it should never be forgotten that, whilst there is a very important humanitarian basis for an overseas aid program, it is also in our enlightened self-interest both in maintaining influence and good relations with our neighbours and in facilitating trade flows. For example, whilst we currently provide $300m to Papua New Guinea for budgetary assistance, the balance of trade is almost four to one in Australia's favour.

I am determined that in the course of my parliamentary career I will work for government initiatives which enable individuals to take control of their own lives and provide maximum opportunities for worthwhile employment. In many ways the carnival is over. By now all thinking Australians realise that we have had it too good for too long. Thanks to all-round protection, buoyant agricultural and mineral commodity prices, a high level of capital inflow and an administered currency regime, we have been sheltered from the harsh need for industry and sectoral restructuring. We have slipped from having a gross domestic product per capita 100 years ago which was 70 per cent higher than that of the United States of America to a point where we fell to 25 per cent below the United States some 50 years ago, and we have remained there ever since. Even worse, from having the world's highest per capita income at Federation, now we are barely in the top 20.

For too long Australia has consistently taken the easy way out. Although inward looking trade policies were designed to encourage domestic production and employment in manufacturing, they simply led to import substitution when other newly industrialising countries were embarking on export oriented policies. As a result, Australia's share of world trade has fallen. Whilst manufactured goods account for 60 per cent of world trade, Australia's manufactured exports comprise only about 15 per cent of our total exports, with 80 per cent being constituted by mineral and agricultural products subject to considerable fluctuations in demand and chronic oversupply.

Thanks to wage indexation myopia, the wage share of GDP rose from 57.4 per cent in the mid-1960s to 63.5 per cent in the late 1970s, at the expense of profits. The Australian labour market operated as though it was in a closed economy until the floodgates of deregulation opened to expose our inadequacies so painfully-excessively rigid wage and benefit structures which are totally unaffordable, especially in tough times.

Instead of spending vast sums on make-work programs such as the community employment program, on which $290m was spent last financial year and over $1 billion has been spent since 1983, we should be investing much more in youth education and training and creating a more conducive climate for acquiring relevant skills and fostering entrepreneurship. Perhaps the most damning indictment of artificial job creation schemes is that whereas in 1983-the worst year for employment under the previous coalition Government-the average period of unemployment was 34.3 weeks, now it is 51.9 weeks. Over the last 10 years the proportion of those in receipt of unemployment benefit for more than six months has risen from 19.3 per cent to 53.4 per cent.

It is imperative that we endeavour to provide long-lasting jobs for all who seek work in our society. During the last 10 years, 10 million new jobs have been created in the United States-nearly all in the small business sector. Technological innovation is one of the main driving forces behind job creation and productivity increases. A recent Brookings study indicated that 44 per cent of the productivity increase in the United States since the war could be related to technological innovation, about 16 per cent to tangible capital investment, 16 per cent to economies of scale, 12 per cent to improved education and 12 per cent to better allocation of resources. Australia has led the way in some biotechnology and genetic engineering developments but generally tends to rely on imported, and therefore lagged, derivative technology. Telematics, robotics and fusion energy will bring substantial social change, but Australia's response to date has been essentially passive and inward looking, even with increased research and development tax incentives.

Australia has been described as a rent seeking society where the best human resources are devoted to seeking rewards from the political system rather than increasing the production of goods and services. Business finds import quotas much more attractive than becoming internationally competitive, unions devote their energies to inducing the Conciliation and Arbitration Commission to grant wage increases rather than optimising output and bargaining for productivity gains and governments raise taxes rather than cut expenditure. All are victims of the sheltered workshop syndrome-the easy way out, the soft options.

In speaking of the Australian commitment to egalitarianism, a recent major United States survey of the Australian economy noted that a pervasive distrust of markets `seems to suggest that Australians prefer government determined outcomes in many cases to market solutions even if efficiency is sacrificed'. It is little wonder that the newly industrialised countries of South East Asia have beaten us pointless in recent years in the growth stakes. It is often seen as un-Australian to be outstanding. Risk taking must involve some failure. But we fail at the outset if we do not try. Competition is the essence of the human spirit-striving to be a better human being, striving to build a better political and social climate. We live in a century of towering achievements in science and technology-quantum mechanics, the unravelling of the DNA molecule, nuclear fission, space travel, the information explosion, fourth generation computers and the green revolution. Most of these breakthroughs are the result of higher education, increased research and development and more adventurous risk taking.

It is not the role of the government to pick winners, but it can set the scene which will encourage winners to emerge. Post-secondary retention rates in Australia are low. Less than 30 per cent of our 20 to 24-year-olds are in post-secondary educational institutions, compared to almost 60 per cent in the United States. To compound the problems facing a more dynamic private sector, 25 per cent of the labour force is in the public sector-almost the highest proportion in the Western world and in marked contrast to 17 per cent in the United States and 7 per cent in Japan. Academic entrepreneurs and university-based science parks are very thin on the ground in Australia. Increased emphasis on technical education is needed, especially in science and mathematics, at primary and secondary levels if we are to eliminate institutional barriers to future demands. Whilst Australian manufacturing can and will become more outward looking, perhaps the greatest prospects for export growth are in the services sector. With a stable political system, well-developed communications systems and higher educational standards, we are well placed to expand exports of technical services, agricultural services, financial services and off-shore banking services. Already we export more than $140m per annum of management consultancy advice, most of it to the east Asian region-but we are still light years behind aggressive leaders such as France and Japan.

Rather than dwelling for too long on our past mistakes and present inadequacies, I prefer to look ahead. There is no reason why by the year 2000 Australia cannot be the centre of trade and commerce in the Asia-Pacific region. It is undoubtedly the fastest growing region in the world. At the beginning of the 1960s the GDP of Japan was less than 10 per cent of that of the United States; by the 1980s it had risen to about 40 per cent. In 1962 east Asia accounted for 9 per cent of world GDP; 20 years later it had climbed to over 15 per cent. By the year 2000 there is every prospect of east Asia accounting for around one-quarter of world GDP, with east Asia and north Asia together providing one-half. Whilst there are serious difficulties in the Philippines economy and the growth rates of a number of east Asian countries are likely to be somewhat reduced over the next few years, China's emergence as a new force on the regional and world economic stage will substantially offset these effects for east Asia as a whole. Continuing regional growth is likely to be accompanied by increased demand for industrial raw materials, food and manufactured products.

During the last 30 years the share of Australia's exports to east Asia has risen from 14 per cent to 47 per cent while imports from these countries have increased from 9 per cent to 36 per cent. However, Japan, Korea and Taiwan now have agricultural sectors which are among the most protected in the world. Australia's efforts should be devoted to trade liberalisation-gaining greater access in exchange for less protection of Australia's labour intensive industries, such as textiles, clothing and footwear. Already a 30 per cent devaluation against the United States dollar over the last three years has significantly increased our export competitiveness. Wage moderation, productivity based increases, elimination of unaffordable work practices and profit sharing incentives can help to restore Australia's trading position. There are already indications of new and progressive export oriented Australian companies taking advantage of our enhanced competitive position. Australia is about to export 30,000 locally produced Ford motor vehicles a year to the United States and we are already exporting ferries and small ships to Europe and Asia. Australia can become a regional centre of excellence, with a commercial disputes forum, the leading securities futures and currency markets and the most sought after education system based on quality of learning, rather than mere quantity of facilities.

The magnitude of Australia's economic crisis, as exemplified by the $14.3 billion current account deficit, has transformed the political landscape. I salute the Government's courageous decision on currency deregulation. More than any other single factor, it has compelled Australians to confront the harsh economic realities which have been a product of flaccid attitudes, beliefs and practices which have been allowed to develop since World War II. But now the moment of truth is upon us: Do we want to compete with the rest of the world or throw in the towel and become the poor white trash of Asia?

Whilst the Budget remains the cynosure of public attention and debate, I cannot avoid the observation that the Government has missed an historic opportunity. Having created a favourable climate and a general expectation of significant spending cuts, it opted for a public relations approach to deficit management by imposing $1.4m of new taxes, sleight of hand deferral of welfare increases and a $600m windfall gain on currency speculation rather than biting the real bullets. The reduced deficit has been achieved through increases in government receipts of 4 per cent in real terms, leading to a record 28 per cent of gross domestic product. Moreover, despite the tax cuts from 1 December, net PAYE taxation will increase by more than 10 per cent, well above the forecast increase in earnings and employment. As a result, we are left with a $14.3 billion current account deficit which is 6 per cent of GDP compared with 2 per cent throughout the 1970s and is now the largest of any economy in the Organisation for Economic Co-operation and Development.

We also have the worst relative position on inflation amongst the industrialised nations in the last 25 years, with a rate three times the OECD average, four times that of our major trading partners and almost five times that of the United States. We also have rising real unit labour costs to the highest level since 1981-82; a public sector percentage of GDP over 42 per cent compared with around 33 per cent barely 15 years ago; a $21 billion social welfare program which has almost doubled in cost in the last five years with no appreciable decline in poverty levels; and foreign debt currently at $69.3 billion and expected to exceed $80 billion this financial year, with a debt service ratio as a proportion of exports of almost 16 per cent-approaching the International Monetary Fund danger line for developing countries of 20 per cent and up from 4.5 per cent 10 years ago. Most importantly, $30 billion is public sector debt, which has outstripped private sector debt since 1983.

The outlook for 1986-87 is for prices of domestically produced goods in Australia to rise more than three times faster than those of our major trading partners so that more than one-third of the increase in competitiveness deriving from the 13.5 per cent fall in Australia's trade weighted index in 1985-86 will be eroded in the coming year by our high inflation rate. This makes it imperative that there be no more wage compensation for devaluation effects and that the superannuation push be deferred until more affordable times. More than ever before, Australia requires leadership which is prepared to undertake at times radical economic surgery. More than ever before, Australia's economic future is dependent upon the world economy, and an incremental approach to change will not be sufficient to see us through the harsh realities. Unless we are prepared to face the world we will get what we deserve. I remain confident that there are enough men and women of good will, foresight and determination in the Australian community to deliver us from ourselves.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! Before I call Senator Powell, I remind honourable senators that this is her first speech in this chamber and I ask that the normal courtesies be extended to her.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Powell Sen J.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —Last Tuesday I took my seat in this place as a senator for Victoria, filling the vacancy created by the retirement of the Honourable Don Chipp. I welcome the opportunity to pay tribute to Don Chipp and his contribution to Australian politics. He served the Parliament and the Australian people for 25 years-an outstanding achievement in itself. But more than that, in that time he made a significant impact on the Parliament and on the face of Australian politics. As Minister for Customs, he liberalised the nation's censorship laws and struggled to alert us all to the dangers posed by addictive drugs and organised crime. He was always a passionate and colourful character, yet he was readily given a great deal more trust and confidence by the public than most politicians usually manage. That is a tribute to his open, direct and honest approach.

SPEECH.PARA: It was not surprising that when, in 1977, he decided to resign from the Liberal Party of Australia, many of the people who had for some years been working in their various ways towards a new reformist direction in Australian politics were able to come together under his leadership and establish a new political party. Many thousands of other previously uncommitted Australians-including myself-took up the challenge and the Australian Democrats were formed. Of course, the experts-journalists, political analysts and other politicians-all said that it would not last, that it could not survive. That was almost 10 years ago and we are still here. We have increased our numbers at each Federal election that we have faced in those 10 years, against all the odds which are stacked against new parties in Australia's entrenched two-party system. There is no doubt that this success would not have been possible without the leadership of Don Chipp. Somehow he managed to combine an extraordinary physical energy with a sensitive and perceptive approach to project new ideas into the public arena and to weld together the various groups looking for an alternative approach to Australian politics. In doing so, he was able to nurture the fully participatory process which was so important to the emerging Australian Democrats.

I have often thought over the years, as decisions were being made in a somewhat cumbersome way, that Don Chipp could have been excused for wishing that he was leading a party on which he could have imposed his will from the top. But he did not do that; indeed, he could not, none of us can. That is the essence of the Democrats. Don Chipp has done more than simply ensure the survival of his new party for 10 years; he has also helped build a party which can survive beyond the term of his leadership. The processes of the party are well established and through those processes an extraordinarily capable parliamentary team has been built which can readily carry on the task and will do so.

Naturally, the outstanding public presence of Don Chipp very often overshadowed the genuine teamwork and breadth of the base that was being built. This is not the way that he wanted it himself. No one could have been a more generous or supportive political mentor. Many hundreds of Australian Democrats candidates around Australia have shared my experience of his willingness to lend a hand in campaigns, and especially of the advice he so readily gave to budding politicians from an old pro. The tag `Don's Party' which the media consistently tried to attach to the Australian Democrats never did justice to his generosity of spirit or to his vision of a party belonging to all its members and forging a new political path to take this country into an uncertain and challenging future. Now, more than ever, that vision is needed and more and more people are turning to the Australian Democrats as the only parliamentary voice for the disenfranchised, for those left stranded outside the politically powerful vested interests of big government, big unions and big business and, of course, for those who work for a nuclear free future. Don Chipp made this happen in 1977 and he has given it his all since then, always doing what was right, never what was expedient. It is an honour and a great challenge to take up the seat he vacated.

I was interested in a comment made by way of interjection last week when I was on my feet proposing a notice of motion-a comment from somewhere on the Government benches, I think-which referred to me as a typical Democrat. Perhaps I am. I was one of the many thousands of Australians with no past political allegiance who found the prospect of a new political party attractive in 1977 -a party which looked beyond the entrenched two-party adversary system, a party which offered its members the opportunity for a direct say in determining polices and in choosing candidates, office bearers, leaders, and even replacement senators. No other Australian political party provides this direct access to the political process and, with it, the opportunity to initiate reform.

From the very beginning the Australian Democrats have seen it as our major role to free political thinking and political action from the shackles of vested interests and to make it possible to translate basic human values into political decisions. The people who, like me, were to become `typical Democrats' were those who were concerned to find long term solutions to society's major problems, rather than the usual short term band-aids dictated by political expediency. We believe that environmental, social and moral concerns should have equal weight with political and economic factors when the hard decisions have to be made. We want to replace confrontation and polarisation with effective and sensible conflict resolution, while recognising that some moral issues must be non-negotiable.

In such an environment we seek the development of a sustainable economy, with priority for personal initiative and hard work in small business, the development of co-operatives and small scale individual enterprises, rather than the monopolies of either private or public juggernauts. We recognise that the way to social and economic justice is to provide more equality of opportunity through more information, more skills and greater mobility. We therefore reject both the indiscriminate handouts approach and the survival of the fittest attitude to welfare in favour of creating the conditions for improving the capacity of individuals to live a better life. Clearly, redistribution of wealth alone is not enough because ultimately wealth flows back to those who control the system. An individual can be oppressed at least as much in a socialist system as in a capitalist economy. The answer is to empower people to take part in the decisions which shape their lives and which will enable society to cope with the fast-moving changes and threats which face us all.

For these `typical Democrats' of whom I am speaking there was always the clear recognition of the greatest threat of all-the nuclear threat. The very first policy we set in place, with every individual having a direct say, was our anti-uranium, anti-nuclear policy. We were quite unequivocal right from the outset that, having committed ourselves to political action towards a better world for the future, for our children, we must first act against the threat to any future at all. We have never wavered from this position and have concentrated a good deal of our effort on trying to move Australia out of the global nuclear power plays of the super-powers. We will persist with this course. We must, for all our sakes. There was particular significance for me in the fact that the day I was sworn in in this place was designated International Day of Peace. I could not have thought of a better way of beginning.

So, yes, I am happy to agree with the suggestion that I might be a typical Democrat. Indeed, I hope that will be the case. However, I would not want anyone to imagine that I might be a stereotypical Democrat. In fact, I would say that it is not possible for there to be such a thing, at least in the parliamentary sense. I say this because there is no compulsion for Australian Democrat parliamentary representatives to vote in accordance with caucus decisions. In the case of the major parties, decisions are often dictated by the interests of a powerful lobby group rather than the interests or wishes of the voters who put the person into Parliament as their representative. The issues of uranium mining and nuclear disarmament have been betrayed by every party except the Democrats, largely due to party discipline exercised by the party machine muzzling the sincerely held beliefs of many politicians and forcing them to vote against their consciences. Now, of course, we have the absolute sell-out in the most recent decision to sell Australian uranium to France which is causing so much heartache to many members of the Labor Government.

How could I expect my family to accept the many sacrifices and frustrations of sharing their lives with a politician and how could I face the people who worked hard to put me here if, in the end, my own firm beliefs and principles were to be overridden by the will of caucus? I do not believe I could. I have mentioned my family and my concern for the future of all our children. I have four-two who are now young women, and two small boys-who, with my husband, and our parents, have been a major source of strength, inspiration and support to me as I have worked in many ways for almost a decade, helping to ensure the survival and develop the effectiveness of the Australian Democrats. Our family life has, of necessity, been a model of the very kind of co-operation and individual initiative so supported by Democrat philosophy. Their love and understanding has been of utmost importance to me at all times, and I thank them for it.

As Australians we lay claim to a belief in a fair go for all. For the Australian Democrats this means that there is an obligation to provide equality of opportunity as a matter of justice. For those who are unable to look after themselves at any point in their lives, we believe there should be a safety net to support them. As a nation we are not doing well. Ownership of assets and opportunities for access to education, income and essential services are still extremely uneven for a society which prides itself on being one of the most egalitarian in the world. Long term unemployment and poverty are increasing. Three million people, 800,000 of them children, are now living below the poverty line. Almost a quarter of our young people aged 15 to 19 are without jobs. By contrast, there is evidence that at the other end of the scale 10 per cent of the population own 50 per cent of the nation's wealth, that taxpayer-subsidised company takeovers yield hundreds of millions of dollars, and that luxury imports are thriving.

This situation is intolerable to the Australian Democrats, as it ought to be to all Australians. It is particularly important that at this time, when the whole economy is in difficulty, largely as a result of mismanagement by successive governments which have failed to establish long term goals and which have now left our fate in the hands of foreign money markets, we accept responsibility for those who are not able to help themselves. Indeed, for many it is really just a matter of removing impediments, which is what the poverty traps legislation was designed to do. It is now more critical than ever that these measures be implemented. For the unemployed, it is not sufficient simply to pay a benefit and believe that our obligation is met. We must make it possible for them to move back into productive work. For many this will mean retraining, and they will need to be paid while this is undertaken. For others it will mean being able to take up opportunities in community work, their own enterprises, co-operatives, or part time employment. This will be possible only if we lift the free income limit to at least $80 so that the new opportunities can be taken without loss of support.

It makes no sense at all that so many of our children live deprived lives below the poverty line. We must give priority to increased support for families with dependent children. The Australian Democrats have consistently pushed for higher child allowances for single parent families, pensioners and the unemployed. We have deplored the reduction over time of the real value of the family allowance. We have opposed the introduction of sales taxes on the necessities of life. We have pushed for the provision of affordable and accessible child care facilities and voted against child care funding cuts because we recognise that the very best way out of poverty for single parent families is through the opportunity for employment.

The Australian Democrats have always recognised the need for greater flexibility in working patterns and we see this as essential in getting more people back into work. As we have done in the past, we will continue to pursue moves towards job sharing, permanent part time work and paid retraining. Quite apart from the problems currently escalating because of the general economic crisis, there are major changes ahead in the nature of work because of the introduction of new technology. To cope with what are quite dramatic changes we will need an increasingly well educated and highly trained work force. Access to education at all levels must, therefore, be a very high priority. It is staggering to find that government does not apparently see it this way. To the Australian Democrats, education is an investment in the future and should not be seen as a cost on the community. We therefore believe that it should be available free of cost at all levels to all people throughout their lifetimes.

We deplore as a most retrograde step the latest move to introduce the $250 levy on students. Since the abolition of fees in 1974 there have been marked changes in participation rates of people from non-traditional blue collar families, and particularly of women. In 1970, 18 per cent of students were women; in 1983, women made up 44 per cent of university students and 48 per cent of students at colleges of advanced education. The number of mature age students also increased by 10 per cent between 1970 and 1980. Reintroduction of fees will have cruel effects on the ambitions, dreams and aspirations of part time tertiary students, mature age students and especially women and country students. The question of fees comes on top of a situation where income support for students is inadequate in any case. The Australian Democrats have consistently called for raising assistance under the tertiary education assistance scheme to at least 120 per cent of the poverty line income level, and will continue to do so.

It is a disturbing feature of the current economic situation that so much of the burden and, even worse, so much of the blame seem to be falling on those who have not been in any way the cause of the crisis. Simplistic calls of work for the dole might give some people a sort of perverse satisfaction, but artificial make-work schemes are not going to pay our overseas debt or improve our balance of payments. Certainly all people have the right to a satisfying job and we must establish procedures, as we have suggested, to make this possible. But the responsibility for the economic position of this nation lies with the community, not with the individuals who are the victims. Governments could begin by recognising that a deregulated economic system is not the be-all and end-all; that speculators and company promoters must be made to contribute to the wealth of this country, not just their own; and that business must be encouraged to invest in future development in Australia rather than off-shore. For solutions we need to look at the whole picture, not blame and victimise groups and minorities which are not in a position to defend themselves. In fact, it is these people we should support and defend.

By becoming a senator I became a member of a minority because I am a woman. Of course, women do not constitute a minority in the community at large-in fact, at the moment we constitute about 51 per cent of the community. However, only 10 per cent of Federal parliamentarians are women, although the Senate manages to do a little better. I consider this to be an imbalance which is a decided disadvantage to our society. Of course, there have been advances for women in recent times. I certainly count the election to the leadership of the Australian Democrats of Senator Janine Haines, Australia's first woman parliamentary leader, as one of those advances. But what does that event say? Does it say that there are not others who are capable of that role, that there never have been others, in any other party? I think not. I think it actually says that we have here a party which is capable of recognising talent and ability and which, having done that, does not have the disadvantage of a history and structures, both formal and informal, which shore up the male dominated power bases of our society. Bearing in mind the fact that the decision was made by a vote of Party members, I would suggest that it is a most encouraging sign for women as a whole that a group of ordinary Australians have reached a stage where they are prepared to take this kind of step.

I believe that most of my female colleagues in the Parliament and women in other decision-making and non-traditional roles would agree with me that we do not want to be labelled; we simply want to be seen as equal people and to be able to get on with the job. Unfortunately, I do not believe that the time has yet come when that is possible. There are some traps into which women in our position can fall. We can say: `Well, I have made it and that proves that any women can-end of argument, end of problem'. If we are honest with ourselves we will know that that is not the case. I believe that we must act in every way possible to ensure that we achieve equality of opportunity for all women.

For me it is simply this: It is very important for society as a whole that all individuals are able to shape their lives in accordance with their capacities and personal choices, but we have ascribed to males and females quite limited and limiting roles in our industrial society and we have prevented real choice in very many cases. We have locked our men into the breadwinner, achiever role and in doing so we have shortened their life span relative to women, denied them the caring and sharing experiences of close ties with their children and discouraged them from expressing the full range of their emotions in a natural way. On the other hand, we have not acknowledged the wealth and variety of talent which women have, while we have encouraged and expected them to limit their lives largely to the home. As we move to face the challenges of the future we can ill afford to ignore any assets that any of us might have to offer.

In addition, there is the issue of equity. Because of our attitude to women and our limited view of their role and potential, we have now reached a position where the negative effects on individuals are palpable. It is young women who suffer the highest unemployment rates. The vast majority of single parent families living in poverty are headed by women. In spite of high rates of participation in higher education, women are grossly under-represented in administrative and decision-making roles in education. Women are still not making their mark in the upper echelons of business across the spectrum and only 10 per cent of parliamentarians are women. It is important, I believe, for equity and balance which will benefit all peoples that all possible steps are taken to ensure that women are part of all community decision-making, that we are not restricted to the areas which have been traditionally ours and that men are not excluded from those areas. I am quite sure that the sorts of decisions which are made by government could be quite different, more compassionate and less remote from reality if the balance were more even. For those reasons, I see it as very important for me, as a woman in a decision-making role, not to take the attitude that my responsibility to other women has ended, but to make it clear that I will act in the interests of equity and balance.

As I said at the beginning, the attraction into politics for me was the prospect of a new, innovative and independent political party. I believe that is certainly what we have achieved as Australian Democrats. So I watch-it would be with some amusement if it were not so serious-the political `experts' trying to fit us into the traditional political pattern, the Left-Right spectrum. It was a real problem when, the media having decided that we fitted neatly in the middle, the Hawke Labor Party moved quickly to that position, nudging out the Liberals who were trying to look as though that was where they belonged. Of course, the answer then was that the Democrats must be a little bit left of centre, but as the Labor Government moved even further to the Right-selling uranium, knocking the pensioners, castigating the unions and cutting foreign aid-what about the Democrats? They must, of course, have moved much further to the Left! That is given sagely as the answer, yet if any of the experts took the trouble to look at what we were saying back in 1977 they would have to think again.

From the very beginning the Australian Democrats have been about reform, about new ways, new ideas, about bringing people into the decisions which affect their own lives; about a world which will survive and justice for the individual. This is why we have consistently acted in the Parliament on the nuclear issue, why we went to the polls in 1983 on a platform of saving the Franklin River, why we support a Bill of Rights for Australians and effective affirmative action, why we fight for land rights for Aborigines, why we stand up for the right to free education and why we will not tolerate further burdens being placed on the poor. These are the reasons why we will not allow the wealth speculators and company takeover merchants to play their games without opposition and why we will continue to push governments to accept their responsibility for the kind of forward thinking that is needed to get Australia into a safe and viable future.

Political dogmatism will not remove inequity, put food on the people's tables or find them jobs. The Democrats are not interested in dogma; we are interested in people. We will take up issues as they arise, making decisions as we see them in the light of our long-standing objectives and policies and in the interests of the community as a whole.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Crichton-Browne Sen N.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —Before the interruption of the debate on the Loans Bill 1986 I was making the point that during the flush period of 1983-84 when there was a break in the drought and the Government was the beneficiary of an additional $4 billion coming into the economy, the Government, rather than reducing taxation and providing us with a sound base for our economy, capriciously spent the money. What did the Government do with its windfall money? Did it reduce taxation? Did it reduce the Government deficit? No, of course it did not. It did what all governments of this political persuasion do-it spent more and more. Budget outlays increased by 15.7 per cent in 1983-84 and by 12.9 per cent in 1984-85. This Labor Government, as a result of its extravagant expenditure, is now going to incur a deficit of $3,500m at a time when the country and the economy are fast moving into recession. This is after a Budget which is allegedly as tough as one might expect in a crisis as bad as if the country were at war.

SPEECH.PARA: The fact is that there was no need for this Government to lead the country into the situation that we now have. The pain which has been inflicted upon so many people is not as the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) and the Treasurer (Mr Keating) would have us believe-that it is simply a matter of bad luck. It is simply a matter of bad management. In looking at the balance of payments deficit one may ask: `Why is it, other than the fact that there has been a glut and a reduction in prices in the rural and mining sectors, that we are suffering worse proportionately than most other countries?' It is because of our lack of competitiveness against our trading partners. When 50 per cent of the gross proceeds of the rural sector are absorbed past the farm gate, is it any wonder we are not able to compete in the world market? When 25 per cent of the mining industry's outlays go in wages, is it any wonder that we cannot compete?

We now have Brazil coming on stream with 35 million tonnes of iron ore every year-one-third of our total annual production. That country is far more competitive than Australia. We have rigidities built into our system which deny us an opportunity to be competitive. We have bizarre work practices, as has been demonstrated recently, particularly in the iron ore industry in the north-west of Western Australia where, irrespective of what equipment is required for a day's work, the union will decide what will be used. A scraper or a drag line might be required, but if the union decides that a water truck should be used on a wet day, so be it. Up until now Mr Burke and Mr Hawke have been saying that there is something terribly wrong with mining companies seeking to object to that type of blackmail by the trade union movement. As a result, we find the Government failing to make any provision in its economic management for the times when, as we have now, there is a downturn in the economy.

The Government having led Australia into recession, let us now look at the action it has taken at the last moment, late as it might be, to seek to overcome some of the problems. Let us start with the Commonwealth Budget. As I said, the Budget is providing us with a deficit of $3.5 billion. A total of $3.5 billion more than is being earned is being spent. In an effort to reduce the Government's current account deficit and to prop up our ailing and failing Australian dollar, the Government has taken two forms of action: It has held interest rates at abnormally, intolerably high levels and it has, in part, begun to prune the deficit. As we all know, there are other more realistic and practical strategies which this Government could use to reduce last year's $13.7 billion current account deficit. If time permits I will discuss those alternatives later.

Let us turn to interest rates. This Government has given Australia record interest rates, the highest ever interest rates, in a desperate attempt to attract foreign capital and to hold up the Australian dollar. If it were not for the fact that the Reserve Bank was interceding, interfering and involving itself, the Australian dollar would be considerably lower. We no longer have a clean float; we now have a dirty float because the measures the Government has adopted have been found wanting. The effect of this has been to cause the onset of a recession and to place our export industries at yet another competitive disadvantage. Inevitably, the wondrous J-curve has not arrived. That is because, first of all, we do not have the capacity for import substitution and, secondly, we do not have investment in the manufacturing sector which allows us to export. That is due largely to high interest rates and companies' reluctance to invest in capital equipment.

One might well compare the interest rates on long term government bonds. In July in Canada long term bonds carried an interest rate of 9.36 per cent; in the United States of America a comparable figure for June was 8.23 per cent; and in Japan it was a mere 5.95 per cent. In Australia, under the present Labor Government, the interest rate on long term government bonds in June this year was 14.4 per cent. These interest rates are only indicative. As we all know, real interest rates are the cost of commercial borrowings, which are essential for the investment and growth which this country needs. These interest rates are far higher in Australia than in other countries and far higher than long term government bonds.

For an arranged overdraft with Westpac Banking Corporation, the interest rate is typically around 19.75 per cent, although this can vary up and down marginally depending upon the customer. For an unarranged overdraft from the same bank the rate is 21.99 per cent. If a person is, like many, unable to arrange finance from a bank and has to go to a finance company, the interest rates are a great deal higher. If he wants to purchase machinery and goes to Australian Guarantee Corporation Ltd, he will be paying 21 per cent, but if he is borrowing money on second-hand farm machinery he will be paying 24 per cent. We wonder why there is no investment! Even the day to day consumers feel the effect in a commercial sense of these interest rates.

Interest rates on credit cards start at around 18 per cent and peak at around 22 per cent. We wonder why consumer demand is down and why the consumption of whitegoods is down. At those sorts of rates, who can afford to consume at the levels we have in the past? Not surprisingly, the economy has begun to contract under the weight of these intolerable interest rates. Not since December 1985 has there been a comparable month in which the number of motor vehicle registrations has exceeded the figure of 12 months ago. I have to say that the decline has not been marginal. The number of motor vehicles registered in July 1986 was 21.7 per cent less than the number registered in July 1985. The Federated Chamber of Automotive Industries predicts that, while last year 500,000 motor vehicles were sold, only 385,000 motor vehicles will be sold this year. A similar story occurs in relation to dwelling approvals. This time it is not since October 1985 that new dwelling approvals have exceeded the comparable figure for the previous year. Once again the decline has not been marginal; it has been significant. In July new dwelling approvals were a massive 16.8 per cent less than in July 1985.

The Government's interest rate policies are doing nothing more than driving Australia further and further into recession. At the rates of interest which are prevailing under this Government business simply cannot afford to invest. Private expenditure on new capital equipment in seasonally adjusted constant prices, in 1979-80 dollars, has been falling since September 1985. The proportion of gross domestic product devoted to business investment in Australia compares poorly with other comparable economies. The percentage of GDP in Australia is 9.9; in the United States of America it is 13.2; in the United Kingdom it is 14.9; in France it is 15.4; in Canada it is 15.8; and in Japan it is 17.9. That is a reflection of the level of confidence in the present economy and the present Government. People are simply not putting money into capital equipment; they are chasing the high interest rates. One wonders why we do not have exports in the manufacturing sector. Surely that answers the question.

Let us look at the other part of the mechanism used by the Government to seek to rectify the state of the Australian economy, and that is the Budget deficit. The Government claims to have reduced the Budget deficit by $2,223m from $5,726m in 1985-86 to something like $3,503m in 1986-87. It is worth looking at the methods that the Government has used in achieving this figure. The Government has not been courageous, as it would have us believe; it is not that it has put the knife in; it is not that it has wielded the axe; it is simply that it has increased taxation. The deficit has been reduced by increasing taxation. There is nothing brave, courageous or clever about that. It is simply compatible with the philosophy of the Australian Labor Party-big government spending and higher taxes.

Despite the claims that the country is heading towards being a banana republic and that we face a crisis that is as great as that of being at war, the Government has not been prepared to cut expenditure in real terms. In fact, government expenditure this year will increase in nominal terms by 6.9 per cent. The Government has done no more than to hold its level of spending constant in real terms. There have, however, been no spending cuts. Last year the Government spent $69,917m; this year it has spent $74,764m on outlays. Commonwealth Government outlays now are still higher as a percentage of gross domestic product than in any Budget brought down by the Fraser Government, running at about 29.4 per cent. The Treasurer, in his Budget Speech, claimed to have cut $3,000m from existing programs. As has been pointed out by John Howard, in his reply to the Budget, many of these cuts are really not cuts at all; they are primarily deferrals.

This is a Budget that is supposed to have charmed, encouraged and excited both Australians and the overseas business community. It has failed to do so because they have seen through the sham that has been put forward by the Treasurer. The National Australia Bank's Monthly Summary states:

Where the Budget begins to lose credibility is in the areas of expenditure cuts. These were largely achieved through deferral of indexation flow-ons and increases in charges. In this sense the Budget was not a `small government' Budget which, given Australia's economic situation, was essentially what was needed.
The National Australia Bank goes on:
For example the deferral of increases related to pensions and scheduled fee rises for Medicare and hospital benefits, while saving $388m in 1986-87, are not ongoing expenditure cuts.
Again the $100m repayment of capital and advances from Telecom relates mainly to 1986-87. Notwithstanding the rhetoric, few really tough decisions were taken.

There is of course the other side to the reduction in the Budget deficit, and that is the increases in taxes which the Government has chosen to thrust upon the community. Taxation receipts are to increase by 11.4 per cent and non-tax receipts, such as government charges for services, are to increase by 26.7 per cent. When given a choice between reductions in government expenditure and increases in taxation, Labor will always opt for increases in taxation. Taxation now is 25.5 per cent of gross domestic product and at the highest level in Australia's history. Despite claims by the Government that it wants to alleviate the burden faced by pay as you earn taxpayers, PAYE taxation will rise by more than 10 per cent. The ratio of income tax receipts to total tax receipts will rise from 61.4 per cent to 62.9 per cent. So the Government has chosen to reduce the government deficit by a substantial reliance on increased taxation.

Reductions in spending have been small, and in many cases they have been reductions which will have an effect but only once. The Government, true to its habit of opting for patch-up solutions, in 12 months time when it can no longer take advantage of these short term measures for Australia, will have to look again at spending reductions. As Senator Button has publicly said, notwithstanding the fact that he has been chastised for it, there will have to be a mini-Budget. Already the figures have been demonstrated to be so rubbery that just to maintain some credibility with the present figures there will have to be a mini-Budget for either increases in taxation or, more likely, reductions in expenditure. Naturally the longer this is delayed the more severe will have to be the reductions.

I would like to look now at the effects which the Government's policies have had so far. I have already referred to the domestic effects that they are having. Quite simply, as I have said, they have sent this country into recession. They have also had little impact on the economic aggregates that the Government hoped to effect. Australia's gross external debt increased from $68.7 billion in June 1985 to around $86 billion at the end of June 1986, and it is expected very shortly to reach $100 billion. This is the equivalent of $5,460 for every man, woman and child in this country, or for a family of five a debt of $27,000. That ought to give some idea of the scale of Australian indebtedness.

Commonwealth debt, for which all Australians must eventually pay, is now almost $65,000m. When the present Government came to office the total debt for the Commonwealth was around $40,000m. In three short years it has increased it from $40,000m to $65,000m. Sadly, most of the increase in the Commonwealth debt has been incurred to finance Budget deficits. Last year the Commonwealth paid $7,053m in interest to finance its debt. This year it is expected to pay $7,240m in interest, or almost $20m per day.

TALK.START.PARA: —A lot of that is State debt. All of that is interest on State government debt.

—I am just talking for the moment about Commonwealth debt. The truth of the matter is, of course, that that debt is blowing out of sight, with little prospect of the increase slowing down in any way. The Government has achieved no more success in holding up the exchange rate. In March 1983, the first month the Labor Government was in power, the trade weighted index was 76.1. On Friday, or exactly one month after the Budget upon which this Government had placed so much hope, it was 51.8.

SPEECH.PARA: In the three short years this Government has been in power the value of the Australian dollar against the Japanese yen has decreased by something like 57 per cent. Against the American dollar it has decreased by around 37 per cent. As we all know, in recent times the American dollar has been weakening. Had that not been the case, of course, the depreciation would have been considerably lower. In terms of the trade weighted index, the Australian dollar has fallen by something like 32 per cent.

This Government has failed on every front. It has failed to stimulate growth domestically. Because of the crisis it has got itself into, it is now seeking consciously and wilfully to dampen down domestic demand. As I have said, that is having the compounding effect of dampening down the capacity of business to invest in fixed assets and is reducing its capacity to export or to replace imports of the same nature.

One might ask what the Government is doing to encourage exports. It is doing absolutely nothing. Until such time as it has the courage to make the decisions that it quite properly ought to be making, until it has the courage to deregulate the labour market, which is totally compatible with deregulating the finance market, the economy is going to deteriorate. In the short and medium terms, nobody could be optimistic, given the prescription that we have had served to us by this Government, that the economy is going to improve in any way.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Parer Sen W.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —We are debating this evening the motion that the Loans Bill 1986 be read a second time, to which the Liberal-National Party Opposition has moved the following amendment:

SPEECH.PARA: but the Senate notes with concern the continuing increase in the nation's indebtedness, the continuing balance of payments and trade crisis, the continuing high levels of interest rates and the government's cosmetic approach to the reduction of its spending outlined in the recent Budget.

The outlays exceed revenue by some $3.5 billion. My colleague Senator Crichton-Browne went into some detail as to how that was achieved and the phoney methods that were used. The important thing, however, is that the deficit is very rubbery and is based on a 2 per cent growth rate. Because of prevailing economic conditions, irrespective of the protestations to the contrary, the Government cannot go the next 12 months without a mini-Budget for either expenditure reductions or an increase in taxation.

I should like to discuss the various factors that are of great concern to the Australian public. By almost every statistic known, under this Labor Government our economy is probably in the worst situation since the Depression, possibly in our history. Taking those statistics in some sort of order, our foreign debt increased from $35 billion when the Hawke Government came to power to $86 billion by June 1986 and, according to a leaked Treasury document, could reach $100 billion by June 1987. The level of foreign debt has risen alarmingly for a number of reasons. Persistent large current account deficits have been financed largely by foreign borrowings which add to our foreign debt. The Budget Papers estimate that 85 per cent of the current account deficit in 1985-86 was financed by debt. Excessive expenditure by the Hawke Government has directly and indirectly added to our foreign debt. In addition, there has been a depreciation of the dollar. As most of our debt is in foreign currencies, when the dollar declines our foreign debt automatically increases. We have restrictive foreign investment guidelines which have favoured overseas borrowings rather than high investment.

Admittedly, the private sector is responsible for most of Australia's net foreign debt. However, the government sector's share has risen sharply over the last few years and is now responsible for some 35 per cent of the nation's net foreign debt. Our net foreign debt rose in 1985-86 by $22 billion whereas equity capital inflow amounted to about $2 billion. The cost of servicing Australia's net foreign debt was equal to almost 14 per cent of the value of Australia's exports of goods and services in 1985-up 4 per cent from 1981. Foreign debt need be of no concern to the nation if the borrowed funds are used to finance investment activity that in due course generates a flow of goods and services. Foreign debt can, however, rapidly become a concern when the funds raised are used to cover non-productive consumption spending, and that is now happening. To highlight the magnitude of the problem, a $100 billion foreign debt represents 35 to 40 per cent of gross domestic product. It would generate an interest bill of $9 billion, or 3.5 per cent of gross domestic product, which is considerably more than the Government spends each year on health, education and defence. To pay off completely our foreign debt would require approximately $6,000 to be taken from every man, woman and child in Australia or, alternatively, it would require almost $25,000 to be taken from each and every Australian family.

Australia's balance of payments is in total disarray, having deteriorated considerably in the past two years. In 1985-86 our current account deficit reached a record level of $13.7 billion, or 5.9 per cent of gross domestic product, and it is continuing to go down at the rate of something in excess of $1 billion per month. The current account deficit blow-out of almost $14 billion compares with Budget forecasts for the year of $10.7 billion. International comparisons show up the seriousness of Australia's balance of payments difficulties. The Organisation for Economic Co-operation and Development forecasts that in 1986 Australia's current account deficit as a percentage of gross domestic product will be the largest in the OECD area. The OECD forecast of current account deficit as a percentage of GDP indicates that Australia's prospective minus 6 per cent is way out of line with every other major industrial economy. By way of comparison, it is forecast that Japan will show plus 4.2 per cent, West Germany plus 3.4 per cent, France plus 1.1 per cent, and so on. Of the OECD countries, the United States of America, with minus 3.1 per cent, is the closest to Australia's.

I now turn to the exchange rate. The value of our dollar has fallen dramatically under the Hawke Government. After holding up during 1983 and 1984, the dollar fell during 1985 and in the first half of 1986. I do not think anyone would have expected, just a few years ago, that the value of the yen would be more than the value of our cent. The value of the yen has moved from a figure of approximately 210 or 220 to the dollar when the Hawke Government came to power to around 92 to the dollar. The trade weighted index has shown a reduction from 82 or 83 to 53 or 54. The value of the Australian dollar in US dollar terms has dropped from about $1.12 in 1981-82 to about 60c today. There has been a complete collapse of our dollar. It is often forgotten when people talk about so-called high profit increases that, if the dollar is not worth very much, one is getting paid a very small amount.

Let us look at interest rates. The prime rate for big business is about 18 per cent, compared with 14 per cent at the time of the last election in 1984. The savings bank home loan interest rate is currently 15.5 per cent-the highest ever-compared with 11.5 per cent at the time of the last election. The small overdraft interest rate is currently running at about 19 per cent, compared with 14 per cent at the time of the last election. What is the effect of that? From a business point of view, it is an absolute disincentive to investment. People would be more interested in collecting the proceeds of high interest rates than in taking the risk of investing in developing our manufacturing sector or other business sectors. Compared with the rest of the world, our interest rates are the highest in history. For example, the current short term interest is 4.4 per cent in West Germany, 4.7 per cent in Japan, 5.6 per cent in the United States of America and 8.4 per cent in Canada.

The other side of the coin is the interest rates that are imposed on the home buyer. It has been estimated that, for a home buyer with a $50,000 mortgage, from December 1984-at the time of the last election-to June 1986 repayments have increased from $508 a month to $660 a month. It has been estimated also that the average Australian home buyer with a $50,000 mortgage pays $70 more a week in interest than does anyone from a comparative country. Is it any wonder that people revolt when they hear the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) say: `Tighten your belts'? The response which I bear from people who telephone me is: `How can we tighten our belts when we have to make those mortgage repayments? How can I buy a house for my wife and family?'

The inflation level is probably the most worrying statistic. While inflation levels in the rest of the world are decreasing, our inflation rate is between 8 and 9 per cent. How does that compare with the situation of our trading partners or the OECD? The estimated current inflation figures are 0.5 per cent in Japan, 1.7 per cent in the United States, minus 0.2 per cent in West Germany, 2.3 per cent in France, and so on. Worse still is the OECD's most recent inflation forecast, as at May 1986, for 1987: Australia, 6.25 per cent; Japan, 0 per cent; West Germany, 0.25 per cent; the United States, 2.5 per cent. The OECD average is estimated at 3 per cent. How on earth can we compete with the rest of the world when those inflation rates are forecast for the next 12 months?

It is perfectly clear that our attitude must change. It is not just a matter of looking at our wage rates and interest rates. It is vital that we look at the work practices that were forced on industries in the 1970s and genuinely address these problems. After Peko-Wallsend was castigated by the Prime Minister and by the Premier of Western Australia, who even threatened to see whether he could take the leases from the company, there is recognition of the fact that, somehow, these work practices must be looked at. Will that be done in a genuine way? I doubt it. I cannot for the life of me believe that some of the work practices which have been forced on people over the years will be given up so easily by the more militant trade unions.

I shall give some examples of work practices. First, there is compulsory unionism. The Prime Minister said in the other place in answer to a question that unionism was not compulsory in Australia. Who on earth did he think he was kidding? There are people who know darned well that there is no way in the world that they can get a job without joining a trade union. A kid who gets a part time job at a supermarket has to join a union whether he wants to or not. The money is taken out of his wage whether he wants that or not. He has no choice. Try to get a job in any of the major industries-mining, maritime, steel, et cetera-and see how easy it is to get a job if one is not in a trade union. It is impossible. What is wrong with unions being invited into the competitive world that exists for everyone else, whether in the financial market, the consumption market or whatever? If they are perceived to perform, they will not have any worries. If they do not perform, people will leave them in droves. That is what the competitive market is all about.

Another example concerning work practices is the inflexibility of the labour market. I draw honourable senators' attention to an article in today's Sydney Morning Herald which refers to the jobs of residents of Christmas Island being under threat because they have become uncompetitive. Apparently, the work force offered to take a 25 to 30 per cent pay cut to keep the men in work. That offer was rejected by the Federal Government, which employs everyone on the Island, either directly or through the Phosphate Mining Company of Christmas Island. How inflexible and absurd can a wage-fixing system be when everyone on the Island says `We want a pay cut so that we can keep our jobs' and that offer is rejected by the main employer?

Another example of the work practices forced on industries concerns productive work. Productive work in, for example, the coal mining industry is permitted to be carried out only from Monday to Friday. No productive work is allowed on Saturday and Sunday. The reason is steeped in history and ignorance. It is that the majority of the people who control the Miners Federation-not all of them, by a long shot-take the view that, if they increase productivity and are prepared to trade productivity for dollars, the net result will be that the life of the mines will be shortened. Nothing could be further from the truth. Once workers become more productive, they will make coal reserves more economically mineable, lengthen the life of the mines and make our products more competitive on world markets.

TALK.START.PARA: —Are you talking about the Loans Bill, Senator? It might be appropriate to refer to it.

—Yes, Mr Acting Deputy President. I am coming to the reason for our problems and why we have to have these loans. I could cite ad infinitum a series of other work practices that have made us less competitive throughout the world, and, hence, the reasons why we are now required to borrow increasingly large sums of money to fund ongoing expenditure.

SPEECH.PARA: We have an accord mark 2 on union superannuation. It is worth referring honourable senators to the open letter to the unions from the Business Council of Australia. Let us bear in mind that this open letter was sent only a couple of days before a so-called meeting, another summit, to talk about work practices. The following comment is made: `How can you expect business to maintain employment, keep prices down, export and invest for our future when you are forcing destructive strikes and bans on to your membership in pursuit of superannuation?' That was an open letter to Mr Crean. The letter draws attention to the fact that major unions, with the active support of the Australian Council of Trade Unions, are targeting exclusively those companies in which generous and long standing superannuation systems already exist. Those are the sorts of things that I am talking about. They are the sorts of things that we as a community must address and do something about unless this country is to slide further and further into the mire. Until and unless these bottom line questions are addressed, we will borrow more and more to finance current rather than capital spending outlays.

SPEECH.PARA: but the Senate notes with concern the continuing increase in the nation's indebtedness, the continuing balance of payments and trade crisis, the continuing high levels of interest rates and the government's cosmetic approach to the reduction of its spending outlined in the recent Budget.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the Senate. As people know, high interest rates have affected investment. That has already been mentioned by many speakers. Not only have they affected investment; they have stifled it. This Government continually tries to blame low investment for the state of the economy. SPEECH.PARA: Nothing was done about taxation in the Budget. The fringe benefits tax is another disincentive to investment. We cannot even get an answer as to how log books should be kept for motor vehicles. Additional capital taxes are another disincentive to people who want to invest.
