The longer interest rates remain at such high levels, the longer the period of economic adjustment and lower living standards.

The Bank is not impressed with the latest economic efforts of this Government and nor is the rest of the community. Nowhere is this more apparent than in the rural industries. We have disastrous terms of trade. The trade weighted index is at a post-war low. What about our account deficit of $14 billion last year with a $1.5 billion current account deficit for July and $1.2 billion for August? That is not really conducive to an Australia that is going places. That is due in large slabs to the efforts of this Hawke-Keating Labor Government. The slump in the dollar has done nothing, as I have already said, for the economy. It has not helped the export incomes as it should have. Obviously the world rural commodity markets have added to our internal financial difficulties. But that is not the only problem. Overseas problems cannot be blamed on this Government, but, as I have said, internally our problems are even worse and they are the direct result of irresponsible and inappropriate economic management. The wage-price spiral, foisted on to the economy by the trade union movement, combined with the irresponsible activities of the Reserve Bank in supporting the dollar, has also caused havoc.

The Budget offers no hope for improvement. It predicts higher unemployment, less business investment, less housing investment and a continuation of our disastrous balance of payments problem. The Government is now aware of the state of the economy but appears to be unwilling or unable to do anything about it. Six months ago the Treasurer of this country, Mr Keating, told Australians:
What we have is an entirely healthy economy . . .
He said that the Government's economic strategy had been entirely appropriate. I shall read some other quotations. This one from the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) is from Hansard of 13 February 1986:

As far as the Government is concerned, we assert that the economic fundamentals of policy making in this country are right and will continue to deliver to this country the economic and the employment growth which has put the performance of this country so far ahead of anywhere in the rest of the world.
I read another quotation, from the Treasurer at the Economic Planning Advisory Council meeting on 7 March 1986. He said:

I remain confident . . . that with domestic demand slowing and the depreciation having produced a large improvement in our competitive position, a downward trend in the current account deficit will emerge clearly during 1986.
I further quote the Prime Minister's words, from the Hansard of 12 March 1986:
We believe that evidence is starting to emerge of the turnaround-
referring to the current account deficit-
we have been looking for for some time.
The Prime Minister also said:
The Treasurer and I have emphasised that we expected and anticipated that progress-
in overcoming the current account deficit-
would occur consistently through 1986.
I quote this time from the Treasurer:
We have had tolerable current account outcomes which must prove conclusively to any interested observer that the J effect has been working right through calendar year 1985.

I think that they are quotations for posterity. Now, of course, we have the Prime Minister saying to us that we have a problem. Indeed, the Prime Minister's words in August were that `the party is over, finito. We are now in a crisis which is as great as the crisis of war'. That, I think, indicates that the problem is very severe indeed. Maybe the so-called world famous best Treasurer should now collect banana peelings rather than antiques. However, there is no joke about what is happening to the economy. The comparisons with Argentina are becoming more alike every day. Argentina is an exporter of wool, meat and grains. It exported these things to Europe and it was an importer of capital and labour. In other words, Argentina has an economy structured similarly to that of Australia. However, it has been traditionally recognised that Australia's higher living standards were the result of our superior export record. However, the Whitlam Government-I think that it can still take a bit of the blame for a lot of the problems that we are having-was responsible for high wages and falling profit ratios, rising unemployment and a worsening external situation. I believe Mr Whitlam was the Prime Minister at the time somebody called Mr Khemlani was approached for some money to pay off some overspending. That is what has to be watched with the Bill that we are discussing here tonight.

I return to the Argentine. At the same time, the Argentine suffered from an oversized public service, soaring inflation and a declining balance of payments situation. In Argentina, chronic Budget deficits, compounded by the prominent place occupied by the public sector, fuelled inflation which started the circle off once again. That was not much different from what is happening here in Australia. We are rapidly falling into the same vicious circle and it will take more than the cosmetic approach of this Government and a rubbery Budget to improve the situation. I quote some words attributed to Mr Keating in an article in the Australian Financial Review of Monday, 8 September by Mr Richard Hubbard. Mr Keating said:
Some may have interpreted our stated intention as implying that we will seek to reduce interest rates without proper regard to these other factors.
He went on to say:
While the Government has established the foundations for a reduction in interest rates, it will not engineer a premature reduction.
To do so would put at risk the prospects of financial market and exchange rate stability.
At the end of that article Mr Richard Hubbard said:

The Government's economic strategy as outlined to EPAC remains based on restructuring the economy towards export production and import replacement through maintaining the improved competitiveness which has come from wage restraint and the depreciation.

But the problem is that it has not, and I do not believe that it will. The Treasurer claims that tighter policies would result in overkill. That, of course, means that the Government is quite happy to continue with excessive interest rates. As can be seen from what I have already quoted, the Treasurer does not agree with such a reduction at all. If what has happened to the Australian dollar in recent months is regarded as financial stability, I would hate to think what the Treasurer regards as financial instability. Perhaps at least Senator Walsh has a more realistic view of his Government's policies. He is quoted as saying, on 28 August:
The high growth strategy pursued by the Hawke Government during its term of office has always been fraught with a high degree of risk.

Furthermore, he acknowledged criticism of the Budget that it was aimed at the foreign exchange market rather than the demands of the domestic economy. That may help to explain why the parlous state of the rural economy in Australia is apparently of so little interest to the Government front bench. Perhaps Senator Button has the most appropriate response to the Budget-and I suppose he is a lot happier after the weekend. He announced only two days after the Budget that the Budget is here today and gone tomorrow. This may explain why the Government is simply unable to address itself to the long term economic problems of this country and why this Government, which is here today, should definitely be gone tomorrow.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Baume Sen M.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Opposition's amendment seeks to add the following words at the end of the motion:

SPEECH.PARA: but the Senate notes with concern the continuing increase in the nation's indebtedness, the continuing balance of payments and trade crisis, the continuing high levels of interest rates and the Government's cosmetic approach to the reduction of its spending outlined in the recent Budget.

As my colleague Senator Messner says, that list is, regrettably, shameful. I believe that it underlines in summary the basic failures of this Government and the inevitability of the recessive forces that will make their presence felt in Australia in the future and meet the forecasts of so many expert commentators around Australia. Quite recently the Westpac Banking Corporation and Melbourne University Institute of Applied Economic and Social Research leading index of economic activity clearly indicated that Australia was on the edge of a recession and the Westpac chief economist, Mr Bob Graham, warned that factors dampening investment and employment creation indicated that the recession could be protracted.

One is not crying gloom, one is not damning the economy and talking it down by facing up to reality. The reality is that there is no need for the Australian economy to be in the crisis in which it now finds itself.

TALK.START.PARA: —Bad management.

—As my colleague says, it is bad management. It is regrettable that that element, which was avoidable, has now become so dominant in our misfortune. The reality is that the terms of trade have gone against Australia. We are now getting less for our exports in value terms, even though the volume has gone up, and we are paying far more for our imports which we can afford less and less. That creates an economic problem. It creates a great deal of pressure and a great requirement of discipline on any government in Australia. Unfortunately, that discipline has not been expressed by the present Government and to that extent the Government's own policies have worsened the problem into a crisis-a crisis that we must all now meet.

SPEECH.PARA: The Senate will have noted that the economy has become so accustomed to crisis that as bad news comes up-such as Australia's downgrading as a borrower from AAA to AA; such as the latest figures which confirm an inevitable $14 billion to $15 billion deficit again in the balance of payments for the year-the money markets shrug it off because they are so accustomed to disaster. They expect disaster.

TALK.START.PARA: —That is a profound disappointment to you, isn't it?

—It is no profound disappointment to me, Senator. What I find disappointing is that this economy was talked up in such a phoney way for so long by you and your colleagues that many people lost very large amounts of money. They made investment decisions that were disastrous. I can remember your colleagues telling the money markets when they were much higher than they are now that they were full of ruffians and mad men to be marking the Australian dollar down.
—`The times will suit us' was your Leader's comment.

—Now we see the Reserve Bank of Australia confirming this much reduced level of the dollar which you say, by way of your curious interjections, would have been wrong to have come down to. Your colleagues at the time claimed that people who made these forecasts were ratbags and ruffians. Now we see this current low level of the Australian dollar not only confirmed by the Reserve Bank, which now interferes in the market-place to maintain it, but we also see the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) himself saying that he would like to see this new low level maintained, even though it was a level that he and his Treasurer (Mr Keating) were regarding as impossible and ridiculous only a few months ago.

SPEECH.PARA: In those circumstances it is reasonable to look at the current situation and to see that the level of expectation in the market-places is for continuing disaster. The market-place has marked Australia's currency down at what is, compared to recent times, a disaster level. It will remain so. The big question is, having created this problem: Is the Government setting out on policies that will correct it? We have seen in the Budget a whole range of actions which are alleged to fit into the set of policies that the Treasurer says we need. For example, he says we need to keep costs in Australia down to a level which will not destroy our competitive position with the rest of the world. Yet we have an inflation rate now of 8.3 per cent-three to four times that of the average of most of our trading partners. It is eight times that of some and infinity times that of certain major trading partners, particularly Germany, Japan and the United States of America which have inflation rates ranging from 1 per cent down to nil. We have an inflation rate of 8.3 times that is rapidly destroying the advantage that has been acquired by our devaluations.

That inflation rate is certain to rise quite rapidly and soon because of the increasing price of oil which, while bringing us some benefit in terms of our exports-in the last couple years we were a net exporter of oil until the latest oil price destroyed our exports-will also bring to us considerable increases in costs internally. On top of that there will be the enormous impact of increased State charges and taxes which will inevitably follow this Budget. This morning the newspapers in New South Wales forecast very substantial rises across a whole range of items and I understand that those will occur this week. So on the inflation front, which the Treasurer himself says is very important, this Budget clearly fails.

The question of restraint in government spending is supposed to be very important and we have heard from both the Treasurer and the Minister for Finance, Senator Walsh, what a magnificent job the Government has done in cutting government spending. Despite the 3 per cent slash in our national income to which we are all supposed to adjust, the Government is increasing its own spending in both money and real terms this year. These cuts are simply against what the Government wanted to spend and what its existing programs would have involved. But Government spending is still at a record high of $74.8 billion this year. In real terms and in money terms this is higher than last year. It is a record, the highest ever, yet all we hear about from the Government is its cuts. Those are quaint sorts of cuts that leave government spending at a record level. For government spending to adjust in accordance with what the Government says is a 3 per cent slash in our national income, the Government would have needed to cut another $2.2 billion off its spending.

According to the Government, the nation has had a 3 per cent slash in its income. It is fascinating that at the same time this Government is increasing its own spending, even in real terms. Everyone else has to suffer the cut, the 3 per cent slash in income, except the Government. Somehow the Government itself is above the people. It can increase spending, but the rest of the nation must cut. We can see that sort of approach in the way the Treasurer approached his own financial arrangements for living away from home. He receives something like a $100 a night living away from home allowance in order to enable him to live in Canberra with his family.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is hypocrisy.
—As my colleague says, it is the kind of hypocrisy that goes not only behind the Treasurer's own personal activities but also behind the Budget that he has brought down.

SPEECH.PARA: Such a spending cut should have been put in place instead of the Government raising an extra $2.2 billion in revenue through new taxes of $1.5 billion and $800m in profits from its selling off of our foreign exchange reserves while it doctors the deficit to make it look less than it really is. On the question of restraint in government-forget it! There has been the rhetoric of restraint, the claims about cuts, yet the reality is that the Government is spending more this year than ever before. It is spending more of the people's money on its own schemes because it has not had either the political courage or the economic intelligence to face the reality of what is needed by this nation.

Higher growth is one of the Government's targets. That is what it is seeking, what its economic policies are supposed to be all about, apparently, judging by what one reads of this Government's curiously changing and unstable objectives. But instead of growth rising this year, as a result of this Budget internal economic growth is forecast to slump from 2.4 per cent to 0.5 per cent and net external growth is to rise by a widely disbelieved 1.75 per cent, as exports are budgeted to rise by 2.5 per cent and imports to fall by 6.5 per cent. This is expected in the Budget Papers to bring a cut in gross domestic product from last year's 3.7 per cent to 2.25 per cent and, quite frankly, this level is excessively optimistic. Even on the Government's own figures, this Budget will bring a reduction in economic growth and so on that score cannot be seen as a success for the Government.

Stronger employment is the keystone of this Government, but ever since it came into power it has doctored the economy to create a situation where jobs can be created artificially-and they will be temporary jobs, as the figures are beginning to show. The Government's heroic forecast that employment will rise by 1.75 per cent in this Budget, or three and a half times the rate of economic growth in the internal economy, is absolute nonsense. It cannot be achieved. There is to be an economic growth rate of 0.5 per cent in the Government's internal economy, and it is talking about a growth in employment of about three and a half times as fast. That strikes me as extraordinary. Even the figure the Government is talking about will result in an increase in unemployment, with the Government's own figures showing a 36,000 increase this year in the number of those who will be on the dole. That is arrant nonsense. I would be overjoyed to hear the Minister for Finance at the end of this debate give us his view of what the unemployment figures will be and see whether he agrees with the nonsense that is put in the Budget Papers on this score. I do not think Senator Walsh would damage his own integrity by backing those rubbery figures.

What about investment? It is investment on which our economic recovery, if we are to have one, must be based. If we are to replace imports and increase our exports we must do it through investment in the private sector. Unfortunately, this Budget will do nothing to help that. Under this Budget there will be a one per cent fall in business investment, a 2 per cent drop in non-dwelling construction, and a one per cent drop in new equipment purchases. How will we cope with the essential requirements of recovery-investing in new plant and equipment, increasing our capacity to compete with imports, so reducing our import demands and enabling us to get out of this disastrous balance of payments crisis-unless we invest more? Yet this Government is presiding over a Budget which diminishes private sector investment. But do not worry, because the Government is increasing its spending. Rather than the private sector doing so, we shall have this enormous and continuing rise in government spending.

I mention at this stage that over the past three years there has been an $11.4 billion jump in government consumption spending. That is a real terms record that is even worse than Whitlam's. For a government that is claiming restraint, an 18 per cent real rise is more than double the 8.4 per cent rise in real private consumption expenditure over the same period and demonstrates what has gone wrong with the economy.

The private sector, on which our eventual recovery must depend, is having to cut down its demands to an increase of only 0.5 per cent, but naturally the Government is holding its figure at a point that is three times higher at 1.5 per cent. This is further evidence of this Government's and this Treasurer's total failure to exercise anything like the self-control needed over the excessive rises in public sector activity while the private sector is hit harder, taxed tougher, and then blamed for not investing more. This kind of continual abuse of the private sector goes on. Figures last week revealed that manufacturing was going down, but in particular some further figures showed that the public sector remains far more active than the private sector, on which real recovery depends. Last week's building statistics showed that public construction projects accounted for 60 per cent of the total construction projects in the June quarter and that the bulk of private sector activity was limited to large natural gas development and gold mining. This left very little over for the rest of the private sector, and this trend is also evident in the Reserve Bank's gloomy review of fixed investment in Australia. The most dismal aspect of the Reserve Bank survey was the fall of 5.5 per cent in capital spending on new plant and equipment over the three years since the 1982-83 recession.

TALK.START.PARA: —Who was that under?

—That was under the worst drought this nation has suffered and under a world recession, neither of which this Government has been prepared to accept or acknowledge. Along with the other things this Government has not been prepared to accept or acknowledge is--
—You had better get Steve Martin to write an article on this.
—Steve Martin has made the occasional mistake--
—You put out a bogus prospectus for Patrick Partners and now you write bogus articles.
—I thank the Minister for his interjection. I am glad to get on record the fact that--
—That you are a fraud.
—Order! Senator Walsh, you will withdraw that remark.
—In recognition of the fact that the Standing Orders are the test of what is acceptable here instead of what is true, I withdraw.
— Order! Senator Walsh, you will withdraw that remark unconditionally.
—In deference to you, Mr Acting Deputy President, I withdraw.

—I thank the Chair. I note the sensitivity of the Minister because whenever the truth is being spoken to him, he has not the capacity or the decency to accept it. His only retaliation is continual personal abuse.
—Drag up your scungy past and your scungy present.
— Order! Senator Walsh you will withdraw that remark as well.
—I withdraw.
— Senator Baume, I urge you to get back to the Bill we are supposed to be debating.

—The point I wish to make is that I have been attacked and accused by the Minister by way of interjection of having done something improper. His withdrawal was reluctant and offensively made, if I may say so. I think it improper that I should not be able to state the facts on the matter which he has drawn to the attention of the Senate by way of disorderly and unpleasant interjections.
— Order! Senator Baume, I ask you to disregard the interjections and go back to the Bill we are debating.

—I suppose that, like a pothole in a country road, it is possible to steer around it, but it is still an excrescence. I was saying that under this Government the public sector has been given a far greater share of the nation's resources and is still being given a larger share, despite the claims by the Government, in particular by Senator Walsh, who is able to say anything at any time, no matter what its relevance to the truth. This trend by the Government is one of the major reasons that we are in this serious economic situation, from which under the Government's present policies we will not emerge, as the Opposition has said, quite strongly. It is interesting to note that, in the circumstances, the Government has started to change ground and has started to admit that perhaps there is a need to renegotiate the accord, as we have been saying, and perhaps there is a need, as Senator Button has said, to have another look at Government spending before next year's Budget, because this Budget obviously did not do enough. In other words, the Government is being dragged screaming and reluctantly to reality.

SPEECH.PARA: What are the other failures of this Government in the Budget? The Budget says that we should save more, yet the Budget is based on exactly the opposite. We have to invest more, but to invest more we have to save more, and we have to reduce spending because spending will flow over into imports, which will worsen our balance of payments crisis. That is the theory-that is what the Government says-but the Budget ends up indicating that there is to be a decline in the savings ratio this year because this will be needed to supplement the rise of 0.5 per cent in disposable household income if the Budget's forecast demand figures are to be met. On all major grounds where areas of economic recovery are absolutely vital, this Budget and this Government fail and we are facing a harder task than we would have faced had we had more correct and rational economic policies than this Government has provided to us.

Now let us come to the daddy of them all, our external account. Last year's record current account deficit of $13.7 billion is budgeted to worsen to about $14.7 billion as we continue to spend more overseas than we can sell and as the terms of trade keep deteriorating. This Government is sending us broke at the rate of $30,000 a minute, yet its policies, Budget and actions have done nothing to reduce last year's record deficit; on the contrary, they have made it worse. Last month's balance of payments current account deficit figure was $1.2 billion, which is exactly on track with about $14.5 billion for the year, yet the markets were relieved that things were not even worse. There are forecasts around that in the next few months we will have deficits of $1.6 billion and $1.7 billion. I fear that those figures look very reasonable and I am concerned, when I look at the crisis that so many of our exports are still in and the inevitability of continuing import demand, that we are a long way from being out of the woods.

Now we see that all these things have emerged from the Government's Budget. I am not saying that there would not have been problems-on the contrary, the problems were there-but they could have been solved and handled better. A result of this Government's activities is that last week we saw official production statistics revealing a further 1.7 per cent fall in manufacturing production for the June quarter, following on from the March quarter's decline and providing the first successive quarterly falls since the 1982-83 drought and world recession. This Government's economic policies are causing further falls in manufacturing and the inevitability of further falls in employment. The sharp fall in domestic demand, high interest rates, uncertainty over rising labour-not just wage costs-and anti-business taxes are all factors in this failure. As a result, manufacturing production is now about 7 per cent lower than its 1981 peak, despite what the Prime Minister and the Treasurer have chosen to describe as Australia's greatest ever economic recovery and despite the Government's confident predictions that the record devaluation of the Australian dollar would provide a major stimulus to manufacturing by making local producers more competitive.

These things have been overwhelmed by the end of the economic recovery which the Government had artificially stimulated with public sector spending in order to window-dress its performance on employment and economic growth. The reality is that the enormous increase in employment that took place under this Government was bought at the taxpayers' expense. I restate that there has been a $11.4 billion jump in governmental consumption expenditure, Federal and State, over the past three years, at a higher rate than took place under Whitlam, and this 18 per cent real rise is more than double the real rise in private consumption expenditure.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is also at the home buyers' expense.

—As my colleague Senator Messner says, it is at the expense of home buyers. This Government's spending has created this phoney recovery. The phoney part of the recovery is that part on top of what would have inevitably happened at the end of the drought and the end of the world recession, for both of which the Australian Labor Party takes credit. The phoneyness and the cause for concern we now have is that the Government overheated the economy with public funds, created temporary jobs with public money and, as these evaporate, as manufacturing industry falls and investment continues to decline, we will find it harder and harder for the Australian economy to pick up.

SPEECH.PARA: It will be largely as a result of Government policies that, when we return to office, we will face a very difficult recovery period. It would be wrong for any government to hold out false hopes of how long it will take to recover. It is like a repeat of the Whitlam situation. The Whitlam years were marked by difficulty overseas. The oil crisis obviously had an impact on that Government, but its economic policies worsened the situation. They were exactly the wrong economic policies at the wrong time. The Hawke Government is repeating exactly that situation. It has learnt nothing, yet as a result of its activities we are now having an economic problem which is being turned into an economic crisis. As a result, I strongly support the amendment moved by Senator Messner, which I repeat in conclusion:
. . . the Senate notes with concern the continuing increase in the nation's indebtedness--
It is up to $86 billion now and the cost of servicing it alone, excluding repayments, rose by $1.1 billion to $6.4 billion, or about 20 per cent of our total export receipts.

TALK.START.PARA: —Most of it is company debt, private sector debt.

—The interjection is that most of it is from the private sector. I would hope that was so, but regrettably one of the major problems is that an enormous proportion of it is from the Government sector.
—Most of it is private sector debt.

—Naturally, it should be, because the private sector involves about two-thirds of activity in Australia, whereas the Government should have been leading by restraint. The Government did not show that restraint and a major element in this increase has been the doubling of public sector borrowing overseas in the last three years in a disgraceful and irresponsible way. As a result, I have very great pleasure in supporting Senator Messner's amendment, which strongly and properly criticises the Government's recent Budget and its economic policies.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Alston Sen R.K.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to speak on what was originally thought to be a fairly innocuous Loans Bill, but which on closer examination almost amounts to a request for carte-blanche. It is probably instructive to start at the point at which my friend Senator Michael Baume finished, which was in relation to the level of public and private sector borrowing. The fact is that public sector borrowing overseas is of the order of $30 billion and the balance is private sector borrowing, simply because of the high level of interest rates that prevail in this country. There is no option but for corporations to go off-shore to take advantage of rates which are at times less than half the level of those prevailing in this country. What troubles me is that the Bill, as Senator Messner quite correctly described its predecessor on 17 October 1985, gives the Government a blanket power to borrow money year upon year in perpetuity in order to meet its deficit. I was intrigued when I went back to look at the original debate to see that the second reading speech by Mr Hurford, who presumably was speaking in his capacity as Minister for Immigration and Ethnic Affairs and Minister Assisting the Treasurer--
—Did you read what Carlton said?
—I have read that. I will come to that in a moment. The Minister said in very bland and harmless terms:

SPEECH.PARA: The purpose of this Bill is to make provision for the financing of the prospective Budget deficit in 1986-87 and in subsequent years together with the associated prospective deficits in the Consolidated Revenue Fund.
He then went on to say that successive governments have used an annual form of borrowing. He said-this is no doubt the point that excites the interest of Senator Walsh:

In view of the non-controversial, accounting nature of the legislation, which has been acknowledged by all the major political parties in the Parliament, the Bill has been drafted as standing rather than annual legislation.

He then concluded with something else which was similarly harmless. In all of that there was simply no explanation whatsoever for the need to have this form of legislation. In many ways it is an affront to parliamentary accountability and it would enable governments to undertake borrowing without informing the Parliament. As much as Ministers might like to suggest that this does not necessarily follow, the fact is that the option is there and would no doubt be taken advantage of if the Government thought it was appropriate and that it would be able to get away with it. But what is so striking about this in the present economic climate is that it goes against the whole approach that has been taken everywhere else of very strict financial discipline and fiscal responsibility. It is light years removed from the approach that the United States Congress is now taking with the Rudd-Gramm-Hollings Act. The whole thrust is to try to balance the Budget to understand why we have these massive deficits and to expose them to the greatest degree of scrutiny.

The consequence of a Bill such as this is to absolve the Parliament from all responsibility, to allow the Government simply to go outside the confines of the chambers and to undertake any level of borrowings that might be necessary to fund the deficit. In my submission that has to be the greatest level of irresponsibility. The Bill is couched in such broad terms that the Government or the Treasurer has power to borrow whatever is necessary, the amount that at the time of borrowing the Treasurer considers to be the greatest amount by which the money, lawfully available, is likely to be used. In making payments the Treasurer can then appropriate it to the credit of the Consolidated Revenue Fund; in other words, it is open slather.

Given that the problems that are so manifest in the economy and the Budget are now recognised on all sides-there is even talk of an accord mark 3, which we know will make little or no difference-it certainly will not assist in freeing up the inflexible wages market or in reducing business costs; it will simply keep industry and business in a strait-jacket. But, given all of those problems and the very real difficulties that this Government has had in getting anywhere near a respectable Budget deficit, one would have thought that the temptations would be irresistible if they were not exposed to annual scrutiny. Perhaps it was thought to be an heroic effort to achieve a Budget deficit of $3.5 billion. In fact it is a result of economic legerdemain. There has not been a display of responsibility; rather, the deficit has been achieved by an increase in revenue, which is the very opposite of what is required at present. That is indicative of what is wrong with this Loans Bill.

At the very time when there is a need for much closer scrutiny and a much closer degree of supervision, we have a Loans Bill that is couched in such general terms that it is symptomatic of a reluctance to take those hard decisions. As we know, this Budget is a public relations Budget. Many of my colleagues have eloquently established its shortcomings. If it is necessary to come up with a deficit, and to ignore all the other fiscal imperatives and all of the virtues that flowed from balanced Budgets, the least that could happen is that parliament should address itself on an annual basis to the reasons for breaching those disciplines. In fact, this Bill goes in the opposite direction. It ignores the unprecedented rate of change and the problems that can occur almost overnight. As we all know, the dollar fell in dramatic terms almost without warning to the foreign exchange markets and certainly to the Australian stock exchanges.

Senator Walsh has chosen to rule out a mini-Budget. We are not sure whether that encompasses a further economic statement or whether it means that there will be no new fiscal initiatives in the current financial year. The fact is that one simply cannot take account of the problems that are likely to occur with an economy as fragile as ours and with a foreign debt that is accumulating with the rapidity of ours. Against that background, with classic structural deficiencies which have built up in this country over many decades and which have seen Australia go from being close to the top of the international league table to barely in the top 20, one would have thought that the most effective way of keeping the pressure on both Ministers and the Government was to ensure that the level of public debt and the level of expenditure borrowing that might be required was subject to the greatest possible degree of scrutiny. Yet that is simply not what is happening here. We have a debt service ratio approaching critical levels. All the economic indicators are very unhealthy indeed when compared with our major trading partners. I instance the present high level of inflation, which is about three times the average of our Organisation for Economic Co-operation and Development partners, and the inflation rate of 8 per cent forecast in the Budget. Clearly that is a very significant warning signal. Let us put that alongside the current high level of interest rates, the rising level of labour costs, the balance of payments deficit that we are now carrying-at about 6 per cent of gross domestic product, it contrasts very unfavourably with the positive current account position of several of the Western economies and is certainly much higher than any of the others even on a deficit basis-an exchange rate that has fallen dramatically and the fact that government expenditure as a proportion of GDP has not fallen by any extent since the last financial year. It is quite clear that none of those parameters augur at all well for the state of the economy, yet the Government is choosing a method which would involve much less scrutiny, much less supervision and much less responsibility.

I come back to the provisions of the Bill and what was said by Mr Hurford when first introducing it. A proposition which has led to no re-think on the part of the Government, has certainly led to a substantial re-think on the part of the Opposition. This Bill must be viewed as an insidious proposal. It does not take account of the real needs of either the Parliament or the national economy. It is simply a recipe for encouraging the fiscal irresponsibility that we deplore. Until the Government can come up with a cogent explanation for the necessity for this Bill, I am forced to conclude, as I am sure will others, that it is simply a form of back door dealing, that there is absolutely no economic necessity for it and that it will simply exacerbate the present problem.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Watson Sen J.O.W.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Senate is debating the Loans Bill 1986, which contains the usual mechanisms to enable the Government to raise funds by loan to finance the Budget deficit. For the second time now the Government is trying to make this Bill a standing Bill rather than an annual Bill. In effect, this Bill as it stands, provided it goes through unamended, provides for standing legislation in order to eliminate the need to seek the permission of Parliament each year to borrow money from the Loan Fund to finance the Budget deficit. In other words, the Government is seeking to deny this Parliament the opportunity to debate increased loans and increased government expenditure, which are indicative of an increased incompetence on the part of the Government. The elimination of the need to present a loan Bill annually could have serious consequences for the management of a deficit and the accountability to the people of Australia because it would allow the removal of some items of expenditure from Consolidated Revenue and their inclusion in the items paid for from the Loan Fund. This is a possibility as a result of what is put before us today. They would therefore not be subject to the sort of scrutiny of, say, a Senate Estimates committee, and the Government could mask the real intent of an ever-increasing deficit on this nation.

SPEECH.PARA: The servicing of our debt is costing this nation more and more each year. The Government has failed in the 1986-87 Budget to reduce effectively government spending to a level which would, in even a small way, reduce the overall debt. While the Government has estimated that it will reduce the deficit to some $3.5 billion this financial year-the figures is rubbery-it also admits that the prospective deficit in the Consolidated Revenue Fund will be around $5.1 billion. The only way to reduce the cost to the Australian taxpayer of financing this huge debt is to reduce government expenditure. But it is in the area of expenditure cuts that this year's Budget loses its credibility. We have seen the deferral of indexation flow-ons and increases in taxes and charges. We have seen the deferral of pension increases and scheduled fee rises for Medicare and hospital benefits.

What about ongoing expenditure cuts? The Budget loses its credibility in this area. Zero real growth, however pleasing to some, means that expenditure has really not been cut at all after allowing for the effects of inflation. As a result of this Government's failure to make the necessary hard decisions, government receipts had to be increased by 11 per cent, or 4 per cent in real terms, in order to cut this phoney deficit to $3.5 billion-an increase in taxes. These receipts will rise to a record 28 per cent of gross domestic product. Where are these major revenue item increases coming from? They are coming from increased excise on petroleum products, the introduction of the iniquitous fringe benefits tax, rises in sales tax in certain areas, increases in the bank account debits tax and rises in personal income tax. Despite the proposed personal income tax cuts which will take effect on 1 December this year, pay as you earn tax will still rise by 10 per cent this year. This will result in the movement of salary and wage earners into higher and higher tax brackets because of inflation. In other words, wage and salary earners will be paying a higher proportion of their incomes in taxes and charges during 1986-87 over and above a greater contribution to Medicare and higher excises on petrol.

Who are the people who are having to pay the costs for this increased debt burden? It is the ordinary workers of Australia, the blue collar workers, the people who put this Party into government. These are the people who are having to pay the price of our high indebtedness today. These are the people who will be forced to suffer wage discounting. These are the people who will have to suffer decreases in their standards of living, et cetera. Instead of cutting expenditure, this Government has chosen to increase taxes as a means of reducing the deficit. Now our external debt is being eaten up by a growing share of our national income. Each succeeding year less and less of our national income is going into constructive ends. I think the Minister for Finance (Senator Walsh) agrees with this. Unfortunately, it is not going into those projects which are capable of providing employment and yielding returns to cover the debt in future years. The fastest growing item in our external debt now is the interest required to service this debt.

There is no real basis to expect that there will be any great improvement in the situation in 1987. The real beneficiaries of this sort of situation, from what is being put forward by this Government, are the financial markets. The financial entrepreneurs have done very well, thank you very much. The people who have been the real sufferers are the productive investors, those who have tended to put their money into productive, long term investment. The deliberate policy of making the taxpayer foot the bill for an increasing government expenditure has left this country in a very sorry state.

The overseas financial markets have also reacted to what they see to be the financial mismanagement of our country. What have they done? They have not only devalued our currency but they have also devalued and decreased our credit rating. Australian business is indeed losing the confidence of this Government. It now recognises the sorry fact that no real progress in overcoming the nation's crisis is in sight. Our overseas current account deficit is likely to be higher in nominal terms and our overseas debt is expected to rise even further this financial year. Our gross national debt is expected to approach $100 billion. This external debt burden is creating a downward pressure on exchange rates. The more the exchange rate falls the more onerous becomes the debt in international currency terms. As a result, our inflation rate is likely to remain well above that of our major trading partners, thereby reducing our ability to compete on international markets. Business investment is not expected to increase markedly because of continuing high interest rates which have discouraged new investment which is so necessary to turn the economy around. Taxation rates continue to rise in Australia while other countries tend to lower taxation rates, particularly in the corporate field or in the business area.

Who is taking the risks for this increasing debt? Where is the risk falling? It is not falling on the financial entrepreneurs; it is not falling on the banking community. Instead the risk has been transferred to those who create the wealth of Australia, the real wealth-the farmers, the miners, the manufacturers and so on. What is happening? The banks have effectively insulated themselves and their profit margins by transferring this risk to other people, including the farmers. That is the deplorable state in which people find themselves because the element of risk taking has been transferred from the financial community to the productive sector of Australia. That is the sector that can least afford to take that risk as well as pay these extraordinarily high rates of interest at present. Unfortunately, we have now entered an environment in which the Government's wages policy is also completely out of step with its monetary policy. For example, while it is anticipating a growth rate of 2.25 per cent-this is highly unlikely because of conflicting statements within the Budget Papers-it is estimating a 6 per cent growth in wages. This is not compatible with the expected worsening of our terms of trade.

The Australian people are now a wake-up to this Government. Reduced household disposable income reduces the incentive to save, and therefore we have less investment. Also we find that business costs will be higher-these costs will be passed on to consumers-with such associated government measures as the fringe benefits tax. The Government has led the people of this country to believe that a devalued currency will benefit business and thereby improve employment and business prospects. Unfortunately, a devalued dollar is really of no benefit to a manufacturer of products that are not competing against imports. The Government seems to forget that fact. Even where there is some competition and there is still a reliance on imports the imported cost has gone up and the inflationary effect is putting up on-costs and added values as well. The real beneficiaries are governments which get increased taxes as a result of this inflationary pressure.

Unfortunately, this Government fails to recognise the link between a devalued currency and a high inflation rate which is associated with this policy. The Treasurer (Mr Keating) in his Budget Speech said that Australia must maintain control over its own destiny. However, such a low valued currency effectively makes Australian assets so much cheaper to acquire. It is not surprising that the financial markets overseas are getting bargain basement prices in the share markets and are buying into real estate and other areas. I only wish they would start making a little productive investment in, say, manufacturing or something that is going to give some real term future to this country.

In fact, the Treasurer in his Budget Speech went on to say that there is a need to become more efficient and to invest more. How can we invest more when more and more disposable income is effectively being taken by government in the form of increased taxes and charges? How can we expect business to invest more when there is no certain climate for the future? How can we expect business to invest more when an artificially high value is put on machinery to produce goods, machinery that essentially must come from overseas?

What is the Government doing? The Government says that it must spend less and borrow less and therefore improve the climate for lower interest rates and more private sector investment. Nobody will dispute that those are fine words; but it is a pity that this rhetoric is not matched with action. Interest rates have in fact gone up two percentage points since July. Taxation for business and pay as you earn taxpayers will increase. There is no incentive for the private sector to invest. The servicing of our debts is costing this country dearly, and it is poor servicing indeed when debt is used to finance current consumption. The legislation before us is essentially a measure to bridge the gap between expenditure and receipts by borrowing.

What is the way out for this country? We must have improved prosperity, which must be used for the future and not diverted to government taxes or corporate asset redeployment. The takeover mania has been a feature of this Labor Government. In fact, it has received encouragement from the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke), who blames bad management in Australia for some of our current problems. Unfortunately, we now have a situation in Australia in which there is an unhealthy emphasis on cost reduction. While it may be important to reduce costs as a result of bad work practices and so on which make our industries uncompetitive with overseas industries, this unhealthy focus on cost reduction just to keep one's head above water at the expense of all other management objectives inhibits a rapid management response to changes in market conditions. This country needs a greater degree of flexibility-flexibility in work practices and flexibility in management attitudes.

c It is regrettable that only 6 per cent of Australians are employed in the export sector and that, therefore, 94 per cent are employed in the domestic sector. This leads to an unhealthy inward-looking attitude, to high regulation and to intervention by government. Our present overseas debt position, the low prices for our mining and rural products, and our adverse balance of payments have a stronger resemblance to the 1890s Depression and the eve of the world Depression than any other example in the last 25 to 30 years. In the 1890s Depression Australia suffered because almost 40 per cent of its export earnings were devoted simply to paying the overseas interest bill. We are rapidly approaching that situation. Because of our inward looking attitude, our exchange rate does not respond quickly to changes in our level of exports and inputs to the trade account. The exchange rate really is driven by the movement of foreign funds into and out of the domestic economy-the capital account. Unfortunately, as a result, adjustments to the value of the dollar, which should flow from fundamental changes to our export performance or underlying cost structures, are far too slow. So our salvation really lies in being able to develop processes, products and designs which other countries cannot match.

I urge the Senate to refrain from making this Bill a standing Bill and, instead, adopt the amendment which will mean that it will be annual legislation subject to the scrutiny of this Parliament, thereby increasing people's awareness of just how government is managing the economy.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Short Sen J.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —I join with my colleagues in this debate in supporting the following Opposition amendment to the second reading motion:

SPEECH.PARA: At end of motion, add:

`but the Senate notes with concern the continuing increase in the nation's indebtedness, the continuing balance of payments and trade crisis, the continuing high levels of interest rates and the Government's cosmetic approach to the reduction of its spending outlined in the recent Budget'.

I think it is very timely and necessary to look at each of these four points in some detail because the first three are merely symptoms of the economic crisis facing Australia today. The fourth point, the failure of the Government to tackle its profligate approach to its spending of taxpayers' funds, is one of the causes of the crisis. I make the point first, however, that if the decision of the Australian Labor Party to include John Halfpenny on its Senate ticket for the next election results in his election to Parliament and if similar extreme left wing Labor candidates are elected, even the profligacy of this present wanton spending Government will look like small change. In that context, it is worth having a look at Mr Halfpenny's remarkable career to date.

According to Mr Santamaria in a recent report in the News Weekly, Mr Halfpenny comes from one of Australia's strongest communist families. His education proceeded through the Eureka Youth League in which, to quote Mr Santamaria, `his qualities of leadership became so apparent that the Central Committee of the Communist Party selected him to go for higher training to the Soviet Union'. He studied full time at one of Moscow's party schools for about fifteen months from 1961 to 1963. Since then, of course, his industrial ascent has been meteoric. In 1972, Mr Halfpenny became Victorian State Secretary of the Amalgamated Metal Workers Union, which is today the dominant influence in the Australian Council of Trade Unions. He also became a member of the Communist Party's national industrial committee and later a member of the ACTU Executive. Mr Santamaria points out that Mr Halfpenny, our Senate candidate, visited the Soviet Union again during 1971. During 1978, he made another visit to the Soviet Union. In 1979 though--

TALK.START.PARA: —He was put in on top of Senator Button.

—Yes, he was put in on top of Senator Button and, in its wisdom, the National Executive of the Party reversed that decision. However, the fact remains that Mr Halfpenny is still in a key position on the Labor Party Senate ticket. Interestingly, Mr Santamaria points out that when in 1979 Mr Halfpenny left the Communist Party to join the Australian Labor Party, he carefully emphasised that he had not changed his views but only the vehicle through which he would seek to realise them.
—Order! I find the remarks of the honourable senator quite interesting but I would ask him to relate them to the motion for the second reading of the Loans Bill, which is now before the Senate.

—Thank you, Mr President. Can I put it to you that my remarks are extremely relevant because Mr Halfpenny and the Labor Party faction from which he comes are dedicated to major increases in government spending, major increases in Budget deficits and, therefore, major increases in the requirements of a Loans Bill, the purpose of which is, of course, to fund the deficit.

—I will hear the honourable senator but I will listen with great interest to what he has to say and constantly remind him that it is the second reading of the Loans Bill, not the first reading, that is before the Senate.

—Thank you, Mr President. I will be guided by you. I conclude my remarks about Mr Halfpenny with the comment that when he left the Communist Party the State committee of that Party issued a statement concluding:

SPEECH.PARA: We look forward to continued work with John Halfpenny as we do with others in the labour movement.

I believe those statements are significant in relation to the Bill presently before the House. As I said, the facts are relevant to this debate because it is about a Bill to make provision for the financing of the Government's Budget deficit in 1986-87 and, if the Government got its way with the Bill as presently drafted-which, of course, the Opposition opposes-it would cover also the financing of deficits in any future years. Members of Mr Halfpenny's faction in the Australian Labor Party are hell-bent on massive increases in government spending and, therefore, massive increases in Budget deficits, with all the attendant miseries of soaring inflation, interest rates and unemployment and plummeting economic growth that result from them.

The continuing increase in Australia's indebtedness is a matter of the greatest concern. There are two elements to this debate: One is the total debt of the public sector-Federal, State and local governments-and the other is our debt as a nation to the rest of the world. The public sector debt has exploded in the past decade and most of that explosion has occurred since the Hawke Government came to office. But, at 30 June 1976, the level of total public sector securities on issue in Australia was $28.9 billion. On 30 June 1986, the figure was $117.4 billion-a more than four-fold increase.

As a percentage of gross domestic product, the public debt rose from 39.8 per cent to 50.6 per cent over those 10 years. A public debt of $117.4 billion is more than $7,300 for every man, woman and child in Australia. For every taxpayer in Australia, it is more than $17,000. The interest bill on the Federal Government's share alone of that debt is more than $7 billion this year. It will constitute more than 10 per cent of the Federal Government's total outlays, which will make it the third largest item of Federal Government expenditure this year-more than it spends on this nation's defence, education or health. This debt is a crippling millstone around the neck of every Australian. Through its effects on taxation, inflation and interest rates, it destroys incentive, investment and productivity; yet the Government's policies will inexorably increase this debt burden.

The growth in our foreign debt has been even more dramatic and carries with it even graver dangers. In the past three years alone, our foreign debt has increased from less than $30 billion to almost $90 billion as our balance of payments on current account has accelerated into deficit. Last year-1985-86-that deficit was $14 billion; this year it will be higher, even on the Government's own estimates. On this basis, our foreign debt will exceed $100 billion by the end of June next year. Our foreign debt is increasing by $40m every day of the 365-day year.

The Government has attempted to hoodwink the Australian public into believing that this disastrous state of affairs has developed entirely for reasons outside the Government's control. What nonsense. It is true that part of the problem has been a decline in our commodity prices overseas, but that is only part of the problem. Even that is, in part, a result of the massive decline in the value of the Australian dollar, a decline that has seen its value fall against the other currencies to its lowest in our history and has seen a fall against our history and has seen a fall against our major trading partner, Japan, of no less than 60 per cent in the past 18 months alone. There is no doubt that that decline has been due entirely to the Government's budgetary, monetary and wages policies.

The attempts in the past few months by the Reserve Bank of Australia to support the Australian dollar are ill-conceived and fraught with danger. They are causing a haemorrhaging of our international reserves. Well over $2 billion of our international reserves have been lost in the past two months alone. The actions of the Reserve Bank, obviously supported by the monetary authorities, are giving speculators a no-risk, one-way option. That is something that the Treasurer (Mr Keating) claimed as recently as July at the Australian Labor Party National Conference in Hobart he would not do. So much for consistency in economic policy from the Government. So much for economic responsibility and integrity. The Government has demonstrated beyond any doubt that it has no consistency, responsibility or integrity.

The increase in our total foreign debt has come from both public and private sector borrowings overseas, but the relative increase in public sector borrowings has been astronomical compared with that of the private sector. Ten years ago, the total outstanding foreign debt owed by the government sector was $1.3 billion. By 30 June this year, it had grown to $27.3 billion-a more than 20-fold increase. Most of this increase has occurred during the life of this Government. No wonder the Treasurer uttered his now infamous `banana republic' statement. He conveniently forgot to say, however, that his and his Prime Minister's economic policies were in very large measure responsible for that calamitous situation.

The Treasurer might also at the same time, had he been honest with the Australian people and particularly with the people of Victoria, have explained how it came about that an agency of the Hawke Government, in the form of the Australian Industry Development Corporation, came to take a 10 per cent equity stake in the Portland aluminium smelter project and why last year the Hawke Government gave the Cain Labor Government in Victoria a $1.5m grant for the project with no conditions attached when it was obvious to anyone with half an ounce of business understanding that the project was in serious trouble. The Hawke Government's role in all this has been, at best, irresponsible. The Cain Government's role has been nothing other than scandalous. As a result of its criminal ineptitude, the Cain Government will have to pay out about $200m to get the Portland project operational. That $200m is over and above the $450m which it has already sunk into the project through its 35 per cent stake.

TALK.START.PARA: —But a Liberal Victorian Government started the Portland project.

—But not the arrangements which have been entered into in the past four years. The longer term financial implications of this scandal for both the Cain and the Hawke governments cannot be accurately quantified at this stage, but it is clear that the cost, not only to Victorian taxpayers but to taxpayers in the rest of Australia as well, will be significant, at least into the 1990s.

SPEECH.PARA: This will be just one more of those policies of Labor governments in Australia that have the direct effect of pushing up both interest rates and inflation. Australia is now well out of line with our trading partners on both these fronts. Real interest rates in Australia are approaching double digit figures. They are well above those of any major Western country. Our inflation rate is more than three times that of the average of our major trading partners. It is no wonder that the outlook for the Australian economy seems so bleak to so many people and observers. It is the Hawke Government's policies that have led to this state of affairs.

I have talked this evening of only some of the Government's policies. Time prevents me from outlining in any detail its other policies about which one could speak so freely, such as the anti-business taxation policy or the wages and industrial relations policies through which the Government has sought to appease just a handful of militant trade union leaders, including Labor's new Senate candidate, John Halfpenny. This appeasement has been at great cost to the fabric of the Australian economy. In that context I note with very considerable interest the sudden emergence of the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) as an advocate of an examination of work practices in Australian industry.

TALK.START.PARA: —And management practices.
—And management practices; I accept that quite readily.
—Some of your colleagues don't.

—Both management practices and union work practices need to be looked at. But the interesting thing is that the Prime Minister called people who advocated an examination of work practices `troglodytes' and `lunatics' and the Minister for Trade, Mr Dawkins, called them `treasonous'. But within a matter of days of comments like that, they had turned around and tried to jump on the band-wagon-but it was too late; they had missed it-of catching the very widespread mood among people in Australia who believe that there are many things going on in our economy that, quite frankly, we can no longer afford. For the Prime Minister to try now to lead that band, when beforehand he exercised a complete lack of leadership, is something that will not go unnoticed by the Australian public.

SPEECH.PARA: Many Australians are still unaware of the economic minefield on which Australia is treading as a result of the policies of the Hawke Government. The Government must change direction. It must restore responsibility, consistency and integrity to government. However, day by day the evidence mounts that the Prime Minister and his pack are increasingly unable to govern. I understand that there is some talk of an early election in the wind. It cannot come soon enough. Otherwise, Australia may truly be unsavable.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Walters Sen M.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —We are debating the Loans Bill 1986, which is described as `a Bill for an Act to authorise the borrowing and expending of money for certain purposes'. This Bill allows the Government to borrow additional money to finance this year's Budget. The second reading speech applauds the fact that the Budget deficit is $3.5 billion. According to Government members and to the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) the Budget deficit of $3.5 billion represents a fantastic effort that involved a lot of cutting. They have said that difficult questions had been answered and important decisions taken.

SPEECH.PARA: But more important still was the response of overseas finance markets. Let us look at their responses. As soon as the Budget deficit was announced the dollar went up for 24 hours but, of course, straight after that the dollar fell by over 1c. Interest rates went up 2 per cent and are now hovering around 19 to 20 per cent. The promises made in the Budget were supposedly the good news. The good news is continuing high inflation-this was promised by the Treasurer (Mr Keating)-increasing unemployment, high balance of trade figures, reduced private investment and reduced growth. According to the Treasurer, that is the good news; those were the Budget promises.
The very latest comments that have been put out about the Budget were by the National Australia Bank Ltd. The heading of its news release of September was `Budget falls short of target'. It stated:
Last month's Federal Budget has done little to restore domestic and international confidence in the Australian economy . . .
On the surface the reduction in expenditure growth and the size of the deficit is impressive . . .
However . . . the Budget begins to lose credibility when the expenditure cuts are examined more closely.
These cuts have been largely achieved through deferral of indexation flow-ons and increased charges.
Notwithstanding the rhetoric . . . few really tough decisions were taken.
. . . the reduced deficit has been achieved through increases in government receipts of 11 percent, or four percent in real terms.

As a proportion of GDP, government receipts have risen to a record 28 percent . . . despite the tax cuts from December 1, net PAYE taxation will increase by more than 10 percent, well above the forecast increase in earnings and employment in 1986/87.
This is good stuff, is it not? It continues:
. . . higher levels of taxation will stifle private incentive to save and invest.
. . . the Budget also damages investment through high interest rates.
The longer interest rates remain at such high levels, the longer the period of economic adjustment and of lower living standards.
It also states:
Of the three major variables-fiscal, monetary and wages policies-it is obviously wages policy that is furthest out of line and consequently imposing the greatest strain on monetary policy.
It ends by stating:
. . . no real progress in overcoming the nation's crisis is in sight and there is little to restore the confidence of the Australian and international community.

That sums up the Budget better than anything else has done to date. Of course, we have also had the reaction from Moody's Investor Services Inc. of the United States of America. It has put our credit rating down from an AAA to an AA rating. That means that an interest loading will be put on our borrowings from overseas. But Mr Hawke and the Government have played that very low key. Indeed, we have all become so used to bad news that the Prime Minister brushed aside the fact that for the first time in our history our credit rating has been lowered to an AA rating under a Labor government. It is the natural disgrace of a Labor government that this has occurred. Is it any wonder that Moody's has done that when we look at our present competitive situation?

Let us compare our inflation rate, our interest rates and our labour costs with those of our competitors. Australia's inflation rate at the moment is about 9.2 per cent. In Japan it is 1.1 per cent, in the United States of America it is 2.3 per cent and in West Germany it is 0.1 per cent. Interest rates are 19 per cent in Australia, about 6.4 per cent in Japan, 8.8 per cent in the United States of America and 8.7 per cent in West Germany. Let us look at labour costs. Australia's increase in average weekly earnings last year was 6.5 per cent, in Japan it was 2.2 per cent, in the USA it was 2.4 per cent and in West Germany 3.3 per cent. Yet Mr Keating had the hide to tell the Economic Planning Advisory Council that the rate of increase in average earnings in Australia has recently been quite close to those of our major trading partners. Is 6.5 per cent close to the others at 2.2 per cent, 2.4 per cent and 3.3 per cent? I would like to see what he really means by that. Average unit costs, which, of course, are also added on to labour costs, for member countries of the Organisation for Economic Co-operation and Development are slightly over one per cent, but for Australia they have been 4 per cent.

All these problems have given business a headache, as one could well imagine. Yet it is business that has been blamed by Mr Hawke. Businesses have been told that they are not playing their part, that they ought to get out there and invest and that they should be doing something to right the mess into which this Government has got the country. The unions have been abusing businesses and telling them that they are not out there investing. There would not be a business in Australia that would not be willing to invest if the climate were right; but, as I have just indicated, the climate is wrong and there will be no chance of them investing. Mr Hawke has told them exactly that and yet he still blames them for not investing. Mr Hawke has told us all that Australia is facing a situation as grim as that of a country at war, and our Treasurer-you know, that best Treasurer in the whole wide world-says that Australia is nothing short of a banana republic. Yet business is blamed for not investing. The thing that would assist business more than anything else would be, of course, a wage freeze. But the Prime Minister has ruled out a wage freeze, and all that business has to help it invest is more taxes for this Government under its Budget. In this Budget alone taxes went up by $1.4 billion, and that great trilogy that the Prime Minister promised us and Australia that he would stick by has gone-shattered for the second year in a row.

Since this Government took office personal tax has gone up $14 billion. Commonwealth tax paid by business has gone up from $5 billion to $8 billion under this Government. Total tax revenue has gone up $27 billion since this Government came to power, and total Commonwealth outlays went up $26 billion in that same period. Despite supposed cuts, outlays in this Budget, although the increase is slight, have still gone up in real terms. The interest paid on behalf of the Commonwealth is up from $1.8 billion to $5.5 billion in that same period. Just paying interest on the deficit that this Commonwealth Government keeps on giving us is driving this country broke. Yes, we are facing the banana republic stage; we are facing a crisis as grim as that of a country at war. On that I agree entirely with the Treasurer and with the Prime Minister.

But what we as an opposition have been calling for is a more flexible wage system. Honourable senators can all remember-indeed, I am sure you do, Mr Acting Deputy President-when our industrial relations and wages policy first came out. The Prime Minister ridiculed it; the unions would not have a bar of it. Honourable senators remember also when Mr Charles Copeman spoke about the work practices. The Prime Minister called him a troglodyte. Mr Burke threatened to take away the licences of his company. Honourable senators will remember him calling Mr Copeman a traitor. Honourable senators will remember all these extravagant expressions used by the Australian Labor Party. Well, yesterday's comments by Mr Hawke, Mr MacBean, Mr Simon Crean and Senator Button indicate that they are all now talking about a more flexible wage system and telling the unions that they have to be more flexible, that they will have another wages accord and that it has to be more flexible.

Is it not extraordinary how just a short time ago the Prime Minister was ridiculing our industrial relations and wages policy? Yet now, of course, he is picking it up and using it as though it were his own. Is it not extraordinary how such a short time ago he was abusing Mr Copeman about work practices that are unforgivable in any climate? Mr Hawke, when he is accused of being responsible for these work practices that started, were fought for and were instigated under him as President of the Australian Council of Trade Unions, has the hide to say: `Well, it was a different era then'. These work practices were never correct; they were never right. There was never a need for strikes over the fact that there was only smooth peanut butter and not crunchy peanut butter in the canteen at lunch, that the canteen provided only two flavours of ice cream, not three, and that there would need to be three men on standby where one man was doing the job. Yet these are the sorts of things that occurred under the present Prime Minister as President of the ACTU. He excuses his actions by saying that it was a different age. What a ridiculous way to carry on.

As I said, we now have both Mr Hawke and Senator Button saying that there has to be a new and more flexible wage policy. We have Mr Hawke now deciding that he will call a summit on work practices and that he will get more co-operation from the unions on some of those work practices about which Mr Copeman spoke so scathingly and which he decided would make his company unable to compete with overseas companies if they continued. Mr Hawke has suddenly decided that he is not such a troglodyte and that he will hold a summit and see what he can do about those work practices. Is it any wonder that business does not have a clue what the Government is on about? Is it any wonder that business does not really know whether Mr Copeman is a troglodyte in the Government's eyes or whether he is a knight in shining armour who is bringing to the attention of the Government these work practices that are so destructive to our competitiveness overseas? That is the situation, and I know that the business community at this stage is probably rather reluctant to have yet another summit with the Prime Minister.
