DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Detention of East Timorese in Jakarta

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: The PRESIDENT

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! It being 10.30 p.m., under sessional order, I put the question:

INTERJECT.PARA: The the Senate do now adjourn.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: McIntosh Sen G.D.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to draw to the attention of the Senate and the Government some recent disturbing events involving the arrest and disappearance of three East Timorese students in Jakarta. East Timorese in Australia have approached Amnesty International, the Australian Council for Overseas Aid, as well as Senator Robertson and me, asking us to do whatever is possible to afford some protection to those arrested. In speaking on this matter tonight, I am also representing the interests of Senator Robertson.

SPEECH.PARA: At about 10.30 a.m. on 3 September, just under three weeks ago, three men in civilian clothes, believed to be from Indonesian military intelligence, arrived at Atma Jaya University in Jakarta. At the university, the three men abducted a student, who was at the time drinking coffee with friends. He was forced into a grey car with licence plate number B1136V. The 34-year-old student was doing final year law at the university. His name is Antonino Goncalves and he is from East Timor. Antonino Goncalves is a nephew of a former Indonesian-backed Governor of East Timor, Guillerme Goncalves. He was in the Portuguese army at the time of the Indonesian invasion and apparently became an active member of the armed resistance until his capture or surrender in 1978. His parents, his wife and his wife's parents all died in the East Timorese countryside that year-as did so many others during that time of intense military operations and subsequent famine.

In 1981, Antonino Goncalves received a scholarship to study in Jakarta, where he has been since. This detailed information comes from an Amnesty International action alert, issued on 5 September, just two days after the abduction. According to Amnesty at that time, efforts by students and concerned church personnel in Jakarta to establish where Mr Goncalves was taken, and why, were unsuccessful. Now, almost three weeks later, still nothing has been heard from or about this man. Amnesty issued its alert, expressing a fear that he may be tortured. This fear is based on Amnesty's knowledge of evidence of the use of torture during interrogation in Indonesia and East Timor. Amnesty has called on the Indonesian Government to make known the whereabouts of Mr Goncalves, to make known the charges against him and to ensure that he has access to friends and lawyers. As of today, Amnesty has had no response from the Indonesian Government.

The Australian Department of Foreign Affairs was informed of this abduction within a day of its happening. I understand that both Amnesty International and the Australian Council for Overseas Aid have sought from the Department assistance to obtain official confirmation of the abduction. I further understand that the Department has made informal inquiries through non-government contacts in Jakarta and has confirmed that the abduction did occur. But there appears to be a reluctance on the part of our Government to take the matter any further.

In the Senate last Tuesday, I asked the Government to seek from Jakarta a formal confirmation of the arrest of Mr Goncalves, to express formally concern for his welfare and to ask that he be granted access to lawyers and relatives. I was told that the Government did know of the arrest but nothing of the reasons for it. The Australian Embassy in Jakarta is continuing to make inquiries and I would be kept informed. I was told. I have heard nothing since. I now ask the Government to tell the Senate what further inquiries need to be made. Given that the Government is aware of the arrest and given the expressed concerns of Amnesty International, why will the Government not simply signal to the Indonesian Government its concern for the welfare of Mr Goncalves?

This question has become more urgent because last week similar arrests of East Timorese took place. At midnight on the night of 16 September-that is, Tuesday of last week-29 year-old Joao Freitas da Camara was arrested in Jakarta. A few hours later, at 5 o'clock on the morning of 17 September, Francisco Fernandes Carvalho, aged 30, was also arrested. Like Mr Goncalves, both men were also students at Atma Jaya university. Amnesty International has issued action alerts on both these cases, calling on the Indonesian Government to make public the charges against them, to reveal their places of detention, to ensure access to lawyers and friends and to ensure that they are humanely treated while in custody.

The Australian Government has made many claims about its concern for human rights issues wherever they occur, including Indonesia and East Timor. Here the Government is presented with some detailed, specific human rights cases, almost immediately after they have occurred. The reasons for the arrests of these East Timorese men is irrelevant. What has happened-abduction and being held incommunicado-is not acceptable or justifiable behaviour in any country. Formal representations from our Government about their welfare could offer those men some form of protection. This is the rationale behind Amnesty International's call on the Indonesian Government. So I again call on the Australian Government to make formal representations to the Indonesian Government about these men in line with the reasonable requests made by Amnesty International. If the Government is not prepared to do this, I believe the onus is on the Government to explain why it will not do so.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Archer Sen B.R.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Attorney-General, upon notice, on 5 June 1986:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) What changes have been made to the laws relating to the revealing of beneficial ownership of shares since recommendations 63, 64 and 66 of the Stewart Royal Commission of Inquiry into Drug Trafficking, which relate to current banking practices and the availability of company information, were presented.

(2) Has the Treasury and the Reserve Bank given consideration to the banking reforms suggested by Mr Justice Stewart; if so, what banking reforms, if any, have been implemented in an effort to improve banking practices.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Attorney-General has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) The Companies and Securities Legislation (Miscellaneous Amendments) Act 1985 made a number of amendments to the Companies Act which has increased the level of disclosure of beneficial ownership of shares. A shareholder in an unlisted company is now required to disclose in a notice to the company details of shares held by him in a non-beneficial capacity when a transfer of shares is lodged. Furthermore, an existing shareholder of an unlisted company is required to notify the company whenever there is a change in the capacity in which the shareholder holds the shares. Previously, details of interests in shares were only provided to the company in respect of listed public companies and certain declared bodies in accordance with the substantial shareholdings and tracing (s. 261) provisions of the Companies Act.

Another amendment requires the above information on the beneficial ownership of shares to be included in the register of members of unlisted companies. This will ensure that such information is conveniently available for public inspection.

In addition, the power of a company to trace the beneficial ownership of its shares, which has hitherto been restricted to public listed companies and declared bodies, has been extended to unlisted companies.

(2) The banking reforms suggested in recommendation 66 of the Stewart Royal Commission were also the subject of recommendations by the Royal Commission on the Activities of the Federated Ship Painters and Dockers Union, headed by Mr Costigan, QC. These latter recommendations were subsequently examined by a Working Group of officials, the establishment of which was announced by my colleague the Treasurer on 17 April 1985. The Government still has under consideration the Working Group's report on the matter.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Transport, upon notice, on 20 August 1986:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Does the Minister for Transport state that coastal waters such as defined in my previous Question on Notice No. 1001, Hansard, 29 May 1986, p. 3060, Section 1 (a) and (b) within Australian Territory are not under the jurisdiction of the Commonwealth and are therefore not entitled to have warnings for hazards broadcast via the Sea Safety and Surveillance Centre, unless someone with responsibility for the coastal waters containing the hazard requests such warning.

(2) (a) Would the Minister agree that his Department must abide by International Association of Lighthouse Authorities (IALA) rules as he recognises his Department as a member of IALA; if not, what explanation can the Minister give.

(b) if this is the case, does the Minister agree that the South Passage Marker of Fremantle Harbour, transformed into a hazard on the 16-17th December, 1984, was a ``New Danger'' as defined in IALA Buoyage System Book 7; if not what are his reasons.
(c) if the Minister agrees, does he agree also that the rules of IALA require the danger to be promulgated.
(d) does the Minister agree that the danger was not sufficiently promulgated.

(e) would the Minister describe the destruction of a light for navigation, such as the South Passage marker, being destroyed and another light buoy placed supposedly to mark the danger, as buoyage changes.
(f) if the Minister would not describe such alteration to the navigational markers as buoyage changes, how would he describe it.

(g) if the Minister agrees that there was a buoyage change caused by the ``New Danger'', and the new danger requires promulgation as required by IALA, how can the Minister maintain in his previous answer (Section 3b) that IALA does not refer to promulgating buoyage change.

(3) (a) Does the Minister state that because the yacht ``Leschenault'' was under Australian registration, and Fremantle was its home port, that it becomes a domestic issue that could be handled (but was not) by the State of Western Australia, accordingly relieving the Minister of his responsibility under International Law to issue warnings to all those concerned, given that in his previous answer to my Question on Notice No. 1001 (Section 3a) the Minister acknowledges responsibility for International Law and then states that the domestic obligations ``can'' (not must) rest with the Australian State.
(b) does the Minister acknowledge that ``Leschenault'' is a vessel that travels inter- nationally.

(c) does the Minister acknowledge that the owners and crew (2 of whom hold the internationally recognised certificate of qualified Yachtmasters) have sailed ``Leschenault'' approximately 100,000 miles covering most of the major oceans of the world as experienced International mariners.
(d) is the Minister aware that the ``Leschenault'' has an International Radio Licence and Call Sign-V.L.H.B., and that the Skipper and one of the crew hold international radio operator's licences.

(e) would the Minister expect that a yacht on the Australian Register, with the Skipper and the crew all Australian Citizens, would be entitled to the protection of International Law, Agreements, Conventions and treaties to which Australia is a signatory, when outside Australian Territorial Waters and in the territories of other signatories.

(f) does the Minister state that because the yacht ``Leschenault'' was sunk in Australian coastal waters the owners and the crew could not expect protection under those same International agreements, conventions and laws.
(g) does the Minister state that had the vessel been a registered foreign craft it would have been entitled to protection under the same international agreements and been warned of the hazard.

(h) as the Minister acknowledges the Commonwealth responsibility and obligations under international agreements, and all concerned should therefore have been warned, how does he relate this to his department's denial of responsibility for sending out radio warnings.

(4) If it is inept to speak of the Minister handing over responsibility (Section 4b) and only co-operative arrangements exist between the States and the Commonwealth, could the Minister inform the Senate-

(a) who has the overall responsibility for overseeing international agreements and conventions signed by the Commonwealth, and Commonwealth Acts of Parliament covering the Warning of Hazards once a co-operative arrangement has been entered into.
(b) if another party, whether it be a State or a Department of that State has assumed responsibility, why is it then inept to say that the Minister has handed over his responsibility.
(5) (a) Could the Minister inform the Senate if the shared responsibility for which the Commonwealth is responsible results from written arrangements between the Common- wealth and the States.
(b) which actual documents arrange for the sharing of responsibility for radio warnings.

(c) is the normal range of the Fremantle Port Authority radio 18.6 nautical miles; if so, how can he or his Department claim that the Fremantle Port Authority (FPA) radio facilities were adequate to warn all concerned when this nominal range does not even cover the FPA outer harbour limits.
(d) does the Minister agree that a nominal 18.6 nautical mile range would indicate a possible difference in the order of 5-8 miles either way.

(e) would the Minister agree that if, as is claimed, the letter from the Prime Minister of 1934 does not include radio warnings, that his Department is responsible for warnings within the FPA area, and is therefore responsible, or at least shares the responsibility for the sinking of ``Leschenault''.
(6) (a) Could the Minister clarify his previous answer to my Question on Notice (Section 6 (a)) regarding the effects of Acts on the domestic exercise of jurisdiction by the Commonwealth.
(b) does the Minister state that international law does not apply to coastal waters even though those coastal waters include navigational aids to assist entry to a major port.
(c) can the Minister provide a definitive answer as to who has the overall responsibility, States or Commonwealth:
(i) for sending out required radio warnings, and
(ii) for making sure facilities are adequate to carry out such warnings when the Commonwealth has an agreement with the State.
(7) (a) In reference to his previous answer (Section 7 (b)) is the Minister aware that the Prime Minister's letter of 1934 to the States does not refer to radio warnings.
(b) is the Minister aware that the letter, while referring to lights, buoys and beacons, makes no mention of radio.

(c) why does the Minister believe radio could be covered by the 1934 letter given that radio for ship to shore was operated by private enterprise in 1934, and neither Commonwealth, State or the FPA had radio for navigational purposes.
(8) Can the Minister further explain how the author of a letter written before any relevant departments had radio facilities could foresee the requirements of radio and the control of it.
(9) (a) Is the Minister aware that the Prime Minister's letter of 6th July 1934 refers only to Section 51 of the Constitution.
(b) is the Minister aware that Section 51 of the Constitution mentions Navigational Aids only in one item, namely item (vii) which refers to Lighthouse, Lightships, beacons and buoys.

(c) does the Minister affirm that the Prime Minister in his letter of 1934 forgot to add the proviso that should radio communication develop and be taken over by the Commonwealth, it would become part of the intent of his letter of sharing responsibility with the States.

(10) Does the Minister justify the shedding of responsibility by his Department, and does he consider it absolved from any obligation to a Commonwealth law that states that it is to carry out certain duties, when they enter an agreed arrangement with the State for that State to administer that law, and in turn that State both passes legislation that forbids civil action to be taken against it for negligence in administering that Commonwealth law, and fails to administer the same law through negligence, by which negligence property loss is caused to Australian Citizens.

(11) Does the Minister believe that the Commonwealth is protected by the State legislation that prohibits an Australian Citizen taking civil action against the State for administering Commonwealth law; if so, can the Minister reconcile this position with Section 109 of the Constitution that states `When the law of a State is inconsistent with the law of the Commonwealth the latter shall prevail, and the former shall, to the extent of the inconsistency, be invalid'.

(12) Does the Minister acknowledge that the intent of the Acts of the Commonwealth Government covering navigational warnings to all concerned, International Agreements, conventions and treaties for navigational safety etc., was to assure the world at large and in particular all those directly concerned with the safety of navigation in Australian waters, that they could fully rely on Australia as a responsible country who would honour its obligations under such treaties.

(13) Is the Minister aware that internationally-read sailing magazines are already reporting the sinking of the `Leschenault' as a case of an international traveller who was not entitled to be warned by the Commonwealth of a known danger to navigation (See also answer to Question on Notice No. 735, Hansard, 11 February 1986, p. 140).

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Gietzelt Sen The Hon A.T.

TALK.START.PARA: —On 18 September 1986 (Hansard, page 598), Senator Powell asked me, in my capacity as Minister representing the Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for Youth Affairs, why female groups making applications under the program of assistance to youth organisations-PAYO-were unsuccessful in obtaining grants. I undertook to provide her with an answer to her question. The Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for Youth Affairs has supplied the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: The basic objective of PAYO is to help non-government youth organisations strengthen and develop their programs and services for young people. PAYO is not intended to provide on-going funding for youth organisations and it is unfortunate that some organisations who have received funding in successive years for discrete but distinct projects have overlooked this long established provision.
For 1986-87 a total of 73 applications were received for grants amounting to $2.6 million.

These applications were assessed against the Program guidelines and the Government's priorities along with other applications. The assessment process included consultations, wherever appropriate, with line departments, including the Office of the Status of Women, having primary responsibilities for the activities being proposed. Given the funds available compared to the total funds requested, it simply was not possible to fund the applications to which the honourable senator refers.
The Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for Youth Affairs has announced 18 grants totalling $812,480 already.

The balance of funds available have been reserved to meet the costs of evaluating the Program and as a provision for additional grants. In this respect three organisations which proposed activities of high priority have been asked to clarify aspects of their proposals to enable the Minister to finalise his deliberations.

PAYO does place particular emphasis on the requirements of organisations representing or providing services to disadvantaged young people. This year some $250,000 were earmarked for this purpose and grants to this level were in fact made. One should not overlook the fact that many of these organisations cater for both young women and young men.
